description:
Absolutely amazing spot up some stairs in the heart of Chinatown. Authentic, cheap, and plenty of food for everyone. My group had Mongolian beef, Kung pao prawns, beef chow mein, Chinese broccoli with garlic, and potstickers. If I can get excited about vegetables among other things, which I did here, that must mean the food is about as good as it gets. Everything from the shrimp to the broccoli was very fresh and bursting with flavor. The food was so good here I couldn't stop eating it even after I felt stuffed. The service was great as well, all of us there were learning Chinese and they were very patient and willing to help us out a little. Highly recommended. I can't wait to return!

So the consensus I think from everyone in my group was that the really cool spot combined with some of the best Chinese food we'd ever had gets it 5 out of 5 stars, easily.
author: Dakota C.

description:
This place is 非常 legit! 

Best potstickers I've ever had. Excellent veggies? And their beef was also the best beef I've ever had prepared at a Chinese restaurant. 

Nestled up stairs in the center of china town, this relatively small Chinese eatery boasts amazing food, super nice servers, and a cozy atmosphere. 

I will most certainly be returning.
author: Colby W.

description:
A few of my Chinese friends had told me to try this place because you can get authentic Chinese dishes. Our adventure began with trying to find the place. The previous names of the restaurant are still on display and we walked past it 3 times before we managed to use Google Maps to pinpoint the location. After climbing the stairs we walked into a small dining area. We were seated at a large table that could seat more than 10 people. We ended up sharing the table with a Finish tourist who was nice. (Two other tourists had come in, but they didn't seem brave enough to try the menu.)

The theme of the day was trying something new, so we decided to try Salt & Pepper Frog. (It was that or Spicy Jelly Fish.) We also ordered Chicken Curry Clay Pot (something familiar) and Chinese Broccoli and Beef (something recognizable, but still new). The curry was a little disappointing, it just didn't taste right. The beef and broccoli was great! The beef was tender, the broccoli was packed with flavor and the sauce was much less "American" (sweet and salty?) than the regular beef and broccoli I've had before. As for the frog... the flavor was good, but the amount of small bones made it inedible for me. My wife gave it a go because she is a bone-in kinda lady, but the tiny bones were too much for her too in the end and we gave up.

The experience definitely did not match the expectation. I might go again if I had some friends that really wanted to try it out, but otherwise I have a few alternatives that never fail to satisfy.
author: Nick M.

description:
Be prepared to wait in line, but it may be worth it because the food is pretty good and you get your bang for your buck! My friends and I came for dinner on Saturday night around 730pm and waited about 15 min before being seated with another group at a round table. We ordered the 3-person deluxe dinner B special and had one potsticker each, wonton soup (2 per person), cashew nut shrimp (they say prawns on the menu, but they're not prawn-sized), Mongolian beef, sweet and sour chicken, and shrimp fried rice. It's a pretty good deal for dinner and we got a lot of variety!

Oh, and you also get a fortune cookie @ the end of dinner. Very China-town-y!

When we finished dinner around 8:30pm, the line was out the door and down to the bottom of the stairs!!
author: Sherry W.

description: Great authentic Chinese restaurant.  Friendly people and great service.   Very small place that doesn't seat too many.  I'd recommend taking the food to go.
author: Ellie L.

description:
If you're not looking carefully, you could miss this place tucked away upstairs on Grant Ave. There was a line when I got here with a friend Saturday evening around 6-7 pm but we only waited 15 min or so. It's a cramped place with big round tables for large families or shared parties and smaller tables for parties of 2-4. 

We decided to get the Deluxe B for $14.95 per person (not including tip) to try fried dumplings appetizer(only 2), wonton soup(basically two and a half bowls worth), sweet and sour chicken, Mongolian beef and shrimp fried rice. It's a pretty good deal if you're not looking to try their signature clay pots. These dishes are more on the cheaper side and considered more "western" I'd say as the Deluxe dishes can also be found at your local Panda Express. The Mongolian beef was too salty for my taste and reminded me of pig ears because of how thick and dry the slices were. The shrimp fried rice tasted like dry rice drenched in soy sauce, though they did have some big pieces of shrimp!
I would come back to try the clay pots however :)
author: Leona C.

description:
Hard to spot, could use the renovation and extremely delicious food!

The place is very unnoticeable from the outside. Went by review and made a right choice. Sunday line to get in was down the stairs, which is telling that it's a must. 

 The place definitely need some renovation and additional room to accommodate all the guests. Usual, expected service and this is the reason of earned three stars. However the food has the right taste and spice level on everything you touch. Will highly recommend sweet and sour chicken, tofu fish, Mongolian beef.

Will be back for more pleasant experience and, hopefully by then, to renovated location.
author: Slava C.

description:
Yum! Great food and good prices!

We especially loved the fish and bean curd clay pot, lots of flavor!

Also loved the eggplant chicken pot, authentic and delicious. Definitely get the clay pots And stay away from the tourist foods the restaurant offers
author: Cynthia X.

description:
The food was below average. I don't understand all the good reviews. I'm guessing those people haven't had better.

The main Chinatown in San Francisco is a tourists trap. Everyone goes to SF thinking every dingy restaurant in Chinatown is good, but that's not true.

You have to search for the good restaurants and that will take some effort.

Won't RTE.
author: Dominic C.

description:
After a long morning of traveling from Arizona to San Francisco, we saw this place and decided to give it a try. It is located upstairs in one of the buildings. 

I ordered the chicken, mushroom, and sausage clay pot and the ginger scallion stirfry lobster. The lobster was priced at $26.95. The flavors weren't bad, but there was a bit too much starch, not enough salt, and the lobster needed to be cooked a bit longer to release the flavors of the ginger and scallion. The portion was mediocre but it is seafood so not too bad.

As for the chicken claypot, it should have been called chicken onion claypot. There were way more onions than mushrooms or sausages and the flavor was mediocre. Also, they charge money for rice. We paid $2.50 for rice so that was a bit ridiculous.
author: Cindy N.

description: Very unique and authentic experience, similar to what you'd experience in Hong Kong.  Best dish is the fish and tofu clay pot.
author: Isabel L.

description: Delicious food!!! Amazing place in Chinatown. The prices are incredible and the food is to die for. Favs are spring rolls, won tong soup, dumplings and fried rice. Service is fast and friendly. Definitely my go to Chinese place from now on.
author: Isabel P.

description:
This place was awesome.  Up some stairs, down a little hallway.  Just how I like it.  

A friend and I went when visiting the city one day.  We started with a couple beers and an appetizer, salt and pepper frog.  I'm not sure if they just chop up frogs and bread it and deep fry it, but goshdurn they was absolutely delicious.  My buddy had the oxtail hotpot and it was better than whatever I got, which was also pretty good tho.  The oxtail was super rich and yummy.  

Highly recommend if you want less traditional boring restaurant and less common, more adventurous (to some) types of food
author: Brandon F.

description: Their classic menu is mediocre, was not much difference between sesame chicken and sweet and sour chicken. The seafood chow mein was more egg noodles than anything. The pot stickers are good. Can soda are served. Very pleasant people and good service. Will try the clay pots menu next time.
author: Derrick F.

description: Closer to 5 stars than 4. Knew we were in for a good meal with the line extending down the stairs and out to the street at times. Spring rolls good. I had the clay pot with Black Sea bass- awesome but cumbersome to eat with whole fish bones and all. Hot and sour soup was authentic (as is every dish here). Noodles dish we got for table to share was underwhelming. Kung pao chicken and beef with broccoli dish were both great. Didn't even need rice for any of these dishes because they aren't drowning in sauce (that most Americanized Chinese restaurants have ). Just simple good and fresh ingredients cooked nicely.
author: Hameed A.

description:
Solid guandong restaurant - the tofu in the seafood clay pot and oxtail clay pot is delicious when it's soaked in the sauce. I also really like the eggplant clay pot. 

There does seem to be some variation in quality though, as sometimes the oxtail is tender and sometimes overcooked.
author: Michelle X.

description: This place promises authentic food and I guess I don't know what that tastes like but I hated it. I tried to order something 'healthy' by getting shrimp and vegetables but it was toot salty and pretty much tasteless. Then I ordered a chicken in clay pot because that's their specialty but it's equally as bad.
author: Apoorva D.

description: I've been coming here for over a year now and this place never disappoints. The service is quick and the ladies who work here are super nice. I tend to order the same thing every time I come here because I always am satisfied with my food. I get the potstickers (so thick and yummy), hot and sour soup, shrimp chow mein, sweet and sour chicken, and most recently, honey walnut prawns. I would recommend any of these dishes, they are soooo good!!!!
author: Natalia C.

description:
Dinner was good, and considering the price, probably great, however I have to mark down the experience for one main reason. For the price, I can't look past the red solo water cups that are washed and reused. I can also forgive the uninspired and uninteresting food. What I can't let go is the lack of a real Gluten Free option, despite describing themselves as having such.

To be fair, they were lovely and knowledgeable. They seemed to take great care to ensure there would be no issues with my son's food. The problem is that they don't have Gluten Free soy sauce or other Gluten free ingredients to replace the regular ones. None of their meat is gluten free, accept the Hong Kong chicken, which was cold and without flavor. The vegetable fried rice, without soy sauce, was no good either. I give them credit for being aware, but I would not call the restaurant Gluten Free Friendly. At least not for those with Celiac.
author: Michael P.

description: The service was really good, we got tea and water and got to sit in a huge table because it wasn't crowded at the time we went. There were clean restrooms, and a really authentic ambiance. However, the signature 'clay pot chicken' dish was disappointing in taste. The only flavor I could taste was salt. We also got steamed vegetables with shrimp and it was pretty tasteless.
author: Akshay P.

description:
After living in downtown SF for a few months, I finally decided to visit Chinatown... and I had a great time! We wanted to stop for lunch around 1pm  today, so instead of stumbling across somewhere, I just googled 'best food in Chinatown' and Hong Kong Clay Pot came up. 

*NOTE* this restaurant is on the second floor, above a small store. It's easy to miss. 

We walked up the stairs, and the first thing I thought was 'great this place has no AC and it's hot AF today', but we were quickly sat and the heat no longer bothered me. This place is clean. I am very picky about where to eat, and I was impressed by their cleanliness. 

When we arrived there at 1ish, there was only 4 other tables sat. By the time we left at 2, almost every table was full. They do great business.

The waitress was very friendly and quickly brought over menus and hot tea. 

We skimmed through it and then noticed they had a special on the back of the menu. 
$15 per person (2 people minimum) and you get.. 
*wonton soup-which was delicious. 
*potstickers-it was good but very average. I've yet to meet a potsticker I didn't like
*sweat and sour chicken-heavy on the sauce but the chicken was cooked perfectly. Delicious. 
*beef with peppers and onions-amazing 
*shrimp fried rice. 

Not only was the food super tasty but it was also very affordable compared to SF prices. 

Most of the tables were 6tops I believe, so this is a good place to go to with a group of friends. Check this place out!
author: Tati C.

description: I ordered from this restaurant. Early dinner. Wanted to try several things because I was hungry and I could save it for later. The sweet and sour shrimp was not sweet and sour shrimp. I was disappointed. The food was drenched in sauce. No matter what it was. The spring rolls were over cooked. Meh..
author: Olive R.

description: Awesome spot to come with friends and family. Customer service is amazing if you're cool with them they will provide you free soup and dessert. We got some Peking pork chop that was delicious and sweet. Snow pea spouts that is always delicious and flavorful. And when you go to clay pot spot obviously gotta get the lamb clay pot. Famous dish! Oh and the fish was made perfectly as well. Lastly the frog legs were bomb af!
author: Christopher G.

description: It's a traditional Cantonese place. We need to go up a narrow stair to the second floor. I am not picky about the food quality, I am just thinking it's a little pricy for the environment and the food size. But it's San Francisco chinatown, they are all overpriced. At lease I get good food at this place.
author: Yanzhong L.

description:
Oh my. 

2nd floor. 
Minimal signage outside.
Was packed out shortly after we got here.

We chose the ox tail & duck clay pots -- SOLID.
Dried scallop noodles. - pretty good.
BBQ Pork & Shrimp fried rices. 

Family of 5...didn't finish everything.
Oh, we also got the tempura calamari & pot stickers, also worth it. 

Get here early if you want a seat. So good.
author: Ben H.

description: Good food. Eat family style.  Sweet and sour chicken was great. We order the dinner for four two there was plenty to try.
author: Dana D.

description:
Roughly ten years ago, my family would frequent this placed for their clay pot rice. I came back hoping their signature dish was still there. Unfortunately it wasn't. 

Nonetheless, I wanted to see what dishes this place was able to cook up in the heart of Chinatown. On Grant Ave, this place is surrounded by gift shops, and souvenirs, making it a prime spot for tourists. When I first stepped into the place at around 6PM, it was already pretty crowded. We ordered four dishes: pea sprouts with garlic, salt and pepper cod, braised beef with tofu clay pot, chicken and salted fish fried rice. The total price with tax + tip = $53 for two people. 

Let's start off with the pea sprouts. It would be impossible to overcook these. Nice and crispy, the pea sprouts were crisp. Also not too salty. 

The salt and pepper cod. When it comes out fresh, it's delicious. HOWEVER, it is definitely missing salt and pepper. The batter of the fish was close to flavorless. 

Braised beef with tofu clay pot. There were several pieces of braised beef that were extremely tough and some that melted in your mouth. The fried tofu compliments the sauce well. Beef needs a work in progress. 

Chicken and salted fish friend rice. TOO MUCH SOY SAUCE AS COLORING. The rice was a dark brown color (most likely used dark soy sauce to color and flavor the rice). While it was good, it was on the salty end. 

Overall, the dishes were pretty small. For the price you pay, doesn't quite match the quantity.
author: Teresa C.

description: We found this restaurant on google as recommended to eat at China town in San Francisco. It wasn't difficult to find just hit the google map then the map will give you a direction to get there. The restaurant is on second floor. The price is the most less expensive which the foods quality is awesome. We were enjoying our lunch there. The people who work there must be a family running the business. They were very nice. Foods came out fast. I would recommended if you wanted something good with more reasonable price.
author: Penwarat S.

description: Good CHEAP spot. Hole in the wall. Spare ribs chow fun was awesome! Service was slow and they were busy, but no big deal.
author: Awmber M.

description:
A family friendly atmosphere is what you find here. Everyone sits at a large round table where food is places in the center where one can turn to get your hot tea waiting for you. This also helps for your food to be placed and foe your whole party to enjoy. 

Cumin chicken in the clay pot was a bit bland, but she asked earlier bow spicy I wanted it I asked for mild. Next came the broccolli and beef, which was soft a delicious, each order came with a self serve large bowl of rice. 

Sweet and sour, had real chunks of pineapple and had the perfect taste it was shared among our whole party.

Service was fast might be because we beat the lunch traffic, but it started pouring in. When we started to leave. Received foetune cookies on top of our check, but one must check out the fortune cookoe shop down the street because it doesnt compare.

Enjoy
author: Frances H.

description: If you want to get seated you need to come right by the opening hour because this place gets packed, literally from the hour they open. The food is delish but service is ok due to the lack of workers and more customers
author: Elina C.

description: Best food in China town!  Let the reviews speak for themselves.... the place itself is very small though so you'll probably have to wait!  The tables are big so you will also probably have to sit with other people!  My son and I sat at a 4-top with a couple we didn't know.  The price point here is excellent, my son and I shared "Deluxe dinner A; for 2" $25 for both of us and came with appetizer, soup, fried rice with shrimp, pork fried rice and leafy greens!  The portions are great and we had lots left over! We ended up giving our leftovers to a homeless couple (please do this if you can't take it home: so many people without homes in SF) and they were extremely grateful!  Bare with the staff as they are EXTREMELY busy but oh so sweet!  I was getting frustrated at the beginning because I had asked 3 different people for water and no one came until I asked for about the 5th time very frustrated!  After that the service and food was great!  Again, they are very busy so you may have to wait a bit for a table or your food but it's oh so worth it! :)
author: Krystal Z.

description:
We used to have a Chinese restaurant when I was a kid, I remember one of the chef's would prepare a beef claypot dish. It became my favorite dish. Claypot is super heated, and stew was cooked differently then lastly stew is poured into the claypot. Best eaten with a white rice.
Meat - beef with some (tendon) and fats
Tofu - deef fried then placed into the stew.
Health conscious? Not for you.
Is it good? Heck yeah.. 
Worth the long wait? So so.. depends if you are a Chinese and familiar with the food definitely worth it. 
If you are adventurous with an open mind, definitely go for it..
If you are trying this restaurant for the first time based on reviews.. take step back.. people have different tastes and different views on things ambience, mood, the company.
author: Steven C.

description: We were visiting San Francisco and we were in the mood for Chinese food this place popped up and we decided to stop by and check out the place. We had dumplings peppered beef orange chicken fried rice everything was so delicious. You have to go up some stairs for some reason we had favor on our side when we walked in there was only two tables that had customers we were sent down immediately. Right after that there must've been like 80 people showed up waiting in line down the stairs into the street. Everybody in this restaurant was very nice to us service was on point the food was amazing. Definitely recommend it if you really want authentic Chinese food.
author: Nick D.

description: Very authentic and delicious food at an unbeatable price!!!! Would totally recommend. We arrived at 6:30pm and was relatively empty, by the time we left at 7:45pm it was almost full... so go early! :)
author: So P.

description: Great, authentic Chinese food. The clay pots are excellent. The braised tofu clay pot was our favorite, and the curry chicken is good as well. They have some communal tables which makes the wait shorter than I expected!
author: Lola K.

description:
Not very impressed. Service was poor and food was mediocre at best
We stopped because we were hungry. Not coming back
author: Cecil W.

description: The food was great. Reasonable prices. They demanded a tip on a service for four people even though we left 18% tip on our bill. They confronted us and when we told them we have it to a waitress and she confirmed then they left us alone.
author: Cindy A.

description:
Nothing really special ... ok, not great, probably wouldn't come back

The Breakdown:

potstickers: quite thick wrapper, too much dough for my taste - not hot

fish filet clay pot: nice mild flavor, but nothing special

quail clay pot: generous helping of quail pieces with lots of onion, by far my favorite dish I tried ... if I did return, this is what I would order
author: Jeremy J.

description:
Food was good. We had Sweet & Sour chicken - nice balance of tastes. Our favorite were the potstickers- they were huge & tastes great!  The chicken chow mein was also very good. 
The tables were all family style with lazy susan's, so that was fun. Place gets packed in with customers, so gets loud.
author: Kim R.

description:
This is a popular place in Chinatown, kind of hard to locate, once you do it have to go upstairs and you'll fine the tables. We had the Deluxe Dinner
($14.95 per person). This special includes potsticker, wonton soup, Mongolian beef, sweet and sour chicken, shrimp fried rice. The chicken was delicious, the rest was good. Everything was fresh and plenty. We ate a lot and took the leftovers to go.
author: Jonnathan J.

description: The clay pots are so good. I like the dried bean curd ones in particular. The sauce is so good with rice.
author: Elva Y.

description: Got the braised tofu clay pot w/ rice on the side. Feels like home.
author: Josh L.

description:
Came here during the recent moon festival and it wasn't crowded even though every other place on the street was. This should have been a hint but most places in China Town are pretty good. 

Not to say that the food wasn't good and the prices were average, it just doesn't stand out in the crowd of restaurants in the city. If you are really hungry and every other place is packed, this place will be a great place to have a quick lunch/dinner. I wouldn't recommend it as the to go place to bring friends from out of town.
author: Andrew V.

description:
After a long day of waiting for buses and ferries in Sausalito, my family and I just wanted to get some good, authentic food in Chinatown. I do enjoy me some clay pot dishes, so I decided to check this place out. We walked up the stairs and were greeted with a small, sparsely-decorated room. I know that might turn some people off, but it actually filled me with hope! I've had some amazing meals in this kind of unassuming venue.

We ended up waiting about 20 minutes for a table, which wasn't terrible at slightly-past-peak dinner time. The four of us were seated at a big, round table along with another party of one who was waiting at the same time. I didn't have an issue with it, but the people at the table before me were two parties of two, so uh, maybe don't bring a date here.

Anyway, we finally sat down and looked at the menu. The selection was certainly large, but I'm not a connoisseur of Chinese food so I didn't recognize most of it. I got myself a curry chicken. Or rather, I ordered myself a curry chicken after about 20 minutes of being left alone by the waitress. It was busy, but I shouldn't have to wait that long to order. Clearly more staff were needed.

And then I waited. And waited. It took about 40 minutes for the appetizer to be brought out, followed by the rest over the next half hour. Again, yeah, it was busy, but you have to draw the line somewhere.

The food started off great. The pot stickers were delicious, nice and warm on the inside with a spicy pork flavor that meshed well with the sauce. Unfortunately, it only set the rest of the food up for failure.

Everything else was super underwhelming. There just...wasn't much taste. Even the curry, which is usually a very spicy, powerful dish, totally fell flat. There was nothing offensive, the veggies and meat were cooked well, but the flavor was totally absent. Combined with the slow service, I was super underwhelmed. The only thing keeping this from a one-star review was that it wasn't *bad*; there was simply not enough flavor to dislike.
author: Shawn W.

description:
one of my new favorite restaurants in Chinatown! It's also conveniently located next to Ten Ren :P (added bonus!) 

This restaurant is not for the faint of heart. It's very traditional and dgaf. They will make you share large tables so if you're looking for nice ambiance, I suggest you search elsewhere. 

If you come here, order the clay pots as they are named after it. Their clay pots are delicious. So far i've tried the chicken with salted fish, and the cat fish clay pot (the pricier one under the fish section). I also tried the quail clay pot but I wasn't a huge fan of the last one. Clay pots are very popular in hong kong, while this restaurant cannot fully compare to an authentic hk clay pot joint, it's one of the better chinese restaurants in chinatown in my opinion. 

They're also reasonably priced! (another added bonus)
author: Annie Z.

description:
Awesome hole in the wall place that you'd probably never find if you didn't know about it already.  Located on the second floor right off the main road of Chinatown.

Had the curry chicken pot and the quail mushroom and sausage out with some spring rolls.   The spring rolls were vegetable and leaves something to be desired.

Quail isn't my thing since too many bones but it tastes similar to duck if you've never had it before.

Chicken curry was fantastic and what was wafting when you walk in.

Overall, it's reasonably priced and authentic.  Hard to find and decent.  Definitely recommend to any that are working around that area or tourists looking for a bit of legit food.
author: Ben H.

description: Amazing food, especially the honey prawns. The place is very small,  but the wait is worth it.
author: Stephan M.

description: This place couldn't be any more perfect. I loved the location right in the heart of chinatown. Small entrance, with a narrow staircase but wow the inside was great with tables right along the window. Food was amazingly great. Our waitress was kind, and helpful. Each dish was hot and portioned perfectly. Our waitress insisted in serving our soups to each of us which was very nice of her to do. friend squid was the best. I hate when places overly bread the calamari, this was lightly breaded and taste great! salt and pepper pork chop and honey walnut prawns were delicious. My mom had garlic bachoy and it was surprisingly very good and flavorful. I would definitely recommend this place to anyone looking for some place to eat. It is so hard to decide with so many options to choose from; but I am so glad I chose this one!
author: Hazey B.

description: Can I just say omg!!!! The food is amazing. Be patient with the service there is 3 people working the floor and the line goes rather fast so don't be intimidated by the line going down the stairs.
author: christina w.

description: The food was spot on.  We came here about 4 years ago and the food tasted just as great then.  I came here twice during our visit and it was also good every time.  They are very consistent.  They weren't too busy on a Sunday evening - they started to get busier around 7:30 though.  It became harder for guests to find tables.  If you could get a window table, I'm sure you would get a nice view of the streets of Chinatown.  We got the chicken and mushroom claypot.  The chicken was seasoned so deliciously.  We also got the crispy noodles with pork and fish in corn sauce.  The noodles were delicious but the corn fish wasn't as tasty.  We also got pea tips, which was also not as yummy as the other two dishes.  Overall, very yummy food.  The waitresses were very helpful.  They were willing to take our family photograph and even helped me carry down my stroller from the second floor to downstairs.  She volunteered since I had my baby with me.  I was blown away by how nice they were.
author: Grace W.

description: As authentic as I've ever had.  It is upstairs above a souvenier shop and very easy to miss.  The curry chicken clay pot was wonderful.  Really creamy, tasty.  You need to order rice seperately. Very communal vibe, due to the shared round tables. My only complaint was that I had to ask for water 3 times, and it took a long time to get our check.  They were very busy though, and it didn't ruin the experience.  Great!
author: Scott S.

description: My favourite restaurant in Chinatown. The clay pots are great, but everything else is amazing too. Prices are good and the dishes are always tasty. This time we had the salted fish fried rice and the lobster- both were great and flavourful. I've had the Egg Yolk Crab here (so yum!), the Snow Pea Sprouts with Garlic, the Sweet and Sour Pork, the Chinese Broccoli Beef- all terrific! I don't know where the bad reviews are coming from- possibly people who think Panda Express is legitimate Chinese food. This restaurant is authentic!
author: Andreya W.

description:
Cashew prawn was good.
Curry chicken was okay, could have been spicier.
The place smelled abit like musty carpet but if u don't mind the smell and focus on the food it will be okay
author: Stacey W.

description:
The place is on the 2nd floor, no signs except in Chinese so beware
The fish clay pot was ok, nothing phenomenal. The veggie dishes were great, meat dishes not so. We tried chicken and pork, the only thing great were the snow peas. 
Be careful when you don't have a full table, people will join you which cd be fun or not so much. Service was good but a bit rushed.
author: Vicky S.

description:
We had high hopes for this restaurant, but it was a really unique experience but not on the entirely positive side. 

We scouted some Yelp reviews and the chicken clay pot and a fish clay pot. The chicken one seemed to draw the most rave reviews so we opted for that one and was looking forward to it. Sadly it was really salty and a bit flat in flavor. Not much else to say about it. However my fish clay pot was better. The pieces of fish were nicely cooked and the sauce was pretty good. Both pots were about $12 each. Oh we also got fried shrimp for an appetizer but that was really disappointing. Literally it tasted like it came from a bag of frozen shrimp from your local supermarket with they typical bright red sweet n sour sauce from your average Chinese American restaurant.
author: Bob K.

description: What a great experience! Although the service left something to be desired, the food exceeded my expectations. I would highly recommend the water; a brisk, refreshing taste with a hint of soy sauce. All around, a great place. If you're in China Town hit it up, if not, no worries you'll find something else.
author: Anna C.

description:
Popular restaurant in Chinatown for locals. You have to go up a flight of stairs and it's pretty hot inside since there's no AC. The service was quick although not the most attentive.

Dishes are about $10 each which is super reasonable. I really liked the fish fillet clay pot. The eggplant clay pot was sweet and sour and the chicken, mushroom, Chinese sausage clay pot was good too. I highly recommend the snow pea with garlic. It was flavorful and had great texture. The beef chow fun was tasty but a bit oily.
author: Linda X.

description: It is on the second floor so you have to walk up stairs.  The food was okay, even their namesake dish. There was a good mix of local and tourist so it has it's following. The namesake dish was similar to restaurants, but the deco was definitely Chinese.  There will be a line if you go there at noon, no sure about dinner, so be prepare to wait. For the price and quality, it is okay.
author: Tony C.

description:
We were rejected by a Vietnamese noodle house down the road, and needed a place to eat. This place had good reviews, and we meandered over. Why is this relevant? Namely because the attitude of the folks running the place was 100% different - they welcomed us with open arms, and were incredibly awesome to us in every way.

We ordered a ton of food. Here's a breakdown:

1. Spring rolls - great, but nothing unique. 

2. Sautéed tender greens - best bok choi ever.

3. Seafood hot pot - so good. Tender fish, shrimp, etc in amazing sauce. Incredibly good.

4. Pot stickers - get them! They were a little doughier than I expected, but great seasoning and consistency.

5. Fried squid - simple but tasty. A bit more seasoning could help, but great in general.
author: Dave S.

description:
I was in SF for a conference and went to Chinatown to get my favorite tea.  I decided to give this place a shot after seeing their good reviews on Yelp.  Oddly enough their were not many places open on a weeknight at 7 pm.

Occupying the second floor of a storefront, this place is a little funky in several respects.  The dining room is not very nice, the bathroom is a bit decrepit, and it is noisy.  

The food however is pretty good, and quite reasonably priced.  So if you are tramping around Chinatown this might be a good choice to stop in at.
author: Dave G.

description:
I only ate here once but would do so again when back in town.
The place is upstairs, and seemed to stay pretty busy.
The service was fast and pleasant, and they were able to deal with a non-Chinese speaker without making me feel awkward or stupid.
I got a vegetarian Hong Kong style noodle dish which was excellent, and a pot of tea which also hit the spot.
No frills, so not a place to impress a first date, (but probably ideal for a second date), good food, and a giant lazy Susan in the middle of the table for large groups who want to share - or people like me at an empty table who just like seeing the sauces go round and round.
author: Anne T.

description: Oh my god! Authentic Cantonese. Fresh super fresh  food. We have brilliant spring rolls, kinda okay quips and black bass with mushroom clay pot. I don't know I have had this good Chinese ever in my life. Compare ng with one of the best Chinese clay pot place in Shanghai, the clay pot here might not be that huge but equally fresh and tasty. A must try.
author: Madhubanti B.

description:
Disappointing! Max 2 stars.
I made a reservation 2 days ago for a party of 6 for dinner at 6 pm but when I got there they don't have my reservation. 
Food portion is small, this is why their prices are lower than similar restaurant in the area. Taste is not very good, definitely not authentic Chinese cooking.
Restaurant is very small, tables are set very close to each other. This means very little space left for seating, very uncomfortable.
There is only air conditioning at the entrance. I sat way at the end of the restaurant, no A/C at all, everyone in my party were sweating through out the dinner. Not pleasant.
Staff is quite friendly but they are too busy in taking orders and serving food, so don't expect any service at all other than placing order and getting your food.
Will not go back!
author: David D.

description: Got 2 of the clay pot dishes delivered. Portion sizes are good. Food is extremely oily though. Like each dish probably had a cup of oil in it. So that's a big negative. It was hard to appreciate the taste with this amount of oil. Dishes do not come with rice (at least not for delivery) - just FYI.
author: Amanda C.

description: This restaurant was delicious! The price was more than fair compared to the amount  of food served! Service was friendly, quick and fantastic. Every dish was delicious! Highly recommend Hong Kong Clay Pot!
author: Gabriela S.

description: Generous serving! Everything that we ordered was so good! Especially the honeyed shrimp and the seafood claypot. Would definitely go back if ever I get the chance to be in Chinatown.
author: L C.

description:
I loved my whole experience. The cashew chicken was outstanding. The vegetables were fresh and crisp, chicken seasoned and cooked excellently, and the dumpling my neighbor shared was delicious.

Communal seating was different, but nice to chat and meet new people. If you were seated next to people who are antisocial it might be awkward. Extra charge for rice was odd, but still a very reasonably priced meal.
author: Josh G.

description:
Peking Pork Ribs isn't pork ribs as one would expect but like pork....just pork.. :( 
The chicken wings were really good and they came first, so I had high expectations. But everything else were just okay. Would NOT recommend it.
author: Kathrine R.

description:
I'm glad we were here at 4:59 pm for dinner when they opened the gate. This place filled up quickly with tourists and locals alike.

I judge my Chinese food by the Hot & Sour soup. This is the best I've ever had.
author: Tammy B.

description:
Delicious & Reasonable !

Very good Chinese food.  Nice selection of seafood & vegetarian dishes.

The decor is dated, but the food is delicious & very reasonable.  Service is good, but you have to flag down the server to get faster service.

I had mixed seafood with green vegetables.  Flavorful & aromatic light broth with hints of ginger - yummy !  The hot & sour soup is quite good.

Gluten-free options are available, but you have to ask.  Some chicken & fish dishes are fried and are not available gluten free.  Seafood & beef dishes are more gluten-free friendly and they'll use corn or potato starch.

One recommendation is that they offer GF soy or tamari sauce.  Their house soy sauce contains wheat (and is not gluten-free).

I recommend this restaurant in SF's Chinatown.  Convenient, reasonable & delicious.  Go with friends.  Tables hold 6-8 people with a lazy susan.

Gregg from Chicago, IL
author: Gregg F.

description:
Hong Kong Clay Pot is what you'd expect in old Chinatown nowadays with dingy lighting, a run down restaurant, and generally, unappealing place to eat. The line for this restaurant is crazy, and it looks like large groups of families love to come here.

I'm not really sure why. The food is super mediocre. Maybe I'm used to much tastier, more modern, and cleaner Chinese restaurants all along South Bay.

The only item that was notable was the seafood in clay pot. Clay pots usually make for a flavorful dish with many ingredients mixed in. This one was good, but the portion was pretty small. The other dishes of pan fried noodles, sweet and sour pork, and salt and pepper fish were fine and typical of most Chinese restaurants.
author: Alice T.

description:
When in Rome.........oooops, I mean, when in Chinatowm...why not go with a local restaurant tucked up a steep staircase on the second floor above a souvenir shop?!?! 
I loved the adventure. We were among local folks eating lunch in their neighborhood. People watching was awesome. 
I ordered the chicken and tofu in a clay pot......I got chicken and curry in a clay pot. Ha. Who's to argue.....I was more than pleased with the mix of flavors and the size. Wow! Luckily I had a willing participant to help me out with the quantity. Lol
The women's bathroom was tucked behind a small flowered material curtain (yes, there was a door behind the curtain!) It was very private. 
I'm glad we ventured in to this place. I would def recommend it. It was clean and our server was cute and charming. She spoke little English but was more than willing to take pics of us at our table. SMILE...click click!!!
author: Missy R.

description: Great lunch spot. I went there a few times and always enjoyed the generous authentic Chinese dishes...I recommend this spot to a lot of friends and family!!!
author: Silvia T.

description:
I don't normally write reviews but this one takes the cake. 

Slow service, they have more workers on the floor than actual cooks. Takes 20 mins per dish to be ready.

PS:  If you're hungry, stay far away.
author: Willie W.

description: One of the most authentic Chinese restaurants I've ever been to, and I've been to hundreds. The line was out the door, but we got still got seated quickly and the service was very fast. Get the pot stickers and pan fried noodles, they're amazing. Definitely going to be coming back here as much as I can.
author: Rafael D.

description: This is a place for tourists.  I took my family here while traveling San Francisco.  The place was packed with tourists, noisy, and the service was slow.  Price was reasonable but the food was also mediocre.  I can't speak for authenticity of the food, but I had better clay pots, for me, before.
author: SangHa C.

description: Great hole in the wall in Chinatown! Highly recommend the Chinese broccoli and dried fish. The duck clay pot was excellent.
author: Emily A.

description: In SF for family vacation. Looking for authentic chinese food & atmosphere. This place covers both. Had 8 in our group. The atmosphere can't get much more authentic. Not much English spoken by servers, which adds to the atmosphere. Food is served family style. Food was hot, fresh and plentiful. Ordered honey chicken, walnut shrimp, kung pao chicken, chow mein, won ton soup. All so good!
author: Mr B.

description: Food poison. We ordered clam soup, half chicken, seafood tofu clay pot and bean sprouts. Only thing was tasty was the seafood tofu clay pot. The worst part was that both of I and my friends got food poison as soon as we left the restaurant...
author: Anya C.

description: We visited this restaurant while in San Francisco. I'm not much of a fan for Chinese food but this stuff is pretty good. Big portions nice wait staff. I recommend.
author: Zach S.

description: Amazing food! Best chow mien and best rice in all of china town. If you can't decide on one restaurant to go to, go to this one.
author: Bodie W.

description:
Authentic and reasonably priced Chinese restaurant right in the heart of San Francisco Chinatown area. It's on the second floor and is a bit small. 

The food was delicious and family style. Large portions. I would definitely come back with friends the next time I stop in San fran.
author: Phill N.

description: The service could be improved a ton although you aren't dining here to get service. The food is pretty good once you get over the fact they charge you for rice. I mean who orders a dish without rice?! (That should be automatically included) Yes you are nickel and dimed in Chinatown.
author: TheTruth C.

description:
Pretty good meal! This place is known for their claypot dishes. We ordered the bitter melon, chicken clay pot with chinese sausage, mushroom and onion, and rice. It totaled to $17 for two very hungry people. The staff was very friendly and accommodating. There were many locals dining there. Everyone knew everyone. It was a busy and happy environment. 

Also this place is a hole in the wall. The restaurant is in a walkup. You have to go upstairs and make a right.
author: Margery W.

description:
A hole in the wall Chinese restaurant in China town. Up a long, narrow staircase, the place itself is pretty crowded, but the food was delicious! I went with my boyfriend and together we devoured green onion clams, honey walnut prawns, spicy BBQ pork fried rice, and some pot stickers. Wow! 

Great service! We were just two so we were seated quickly (larger parties waited longer), and we were given hot tea the second we sat! Quick to take our order, but needed prompting to bring the check. 

Overall a delicious experience!
author: Liz H.

description: Great oxtail clay pot. Amazing salt and pepper shrimp. Best service in Chinatown. Highly recommend.
author: Adeena L.

description: We were on vacation and wandering through China Town. Found this place. I had the seafood noodles to be safe... it had no flavor. My kids had the kung pao beef, dumplings and the sweet and sour chicken... the sweet and sour chicken and dumplings were ok... I hope it was kung pao (beef)... the texture was ... different. No fountain drinks. Only cans and water bottles. The kitchen looks really tiny so they probably dont have room to do dishes? ... The restaurant is just tiny with huge round tables and a lazy Susan in the middle of the table so you will share a table with random strangers. I did not like that. So at least we didn't get sick but I wished our first China Town restaurant experience had been better.
author: Paula C.

description: The place is up stairs...small area to eat . nice tables with a turn table top so you can turn it and all the food goes round and round.. nice..but we just got one plate at a time with a ten min wait for the next plate..The fried rice was good.. the food was for me middle of the road.  Nothing we had knocked my socks off. The place was really busy.. the waitress was nice..the place was just ok.  I would not go back...
author: Chip V.

description:
Needed some decent hk family style dishes and stumbled upon this place. I frequent amazing canto places in LA SGV so I have high expectations. 

All the dishes were solid. Highly recommend the seafood clay pot. You can taste the "wok hay" in the dish. This is the heat coming from the hot wok they use! We also ordered the house chicken. This was unfortunately very plain. Would not recommend this. 

I notice everyone was ordering chow mein which kinda bummed me out as I can see a lot of people didn't really venture out and get other dishes. I really wanted to get the quail :( I didn't see it on the menu until I left. 

Their menu is not that diverse. In fact it's pretty small and shouldn't be compared to a legit hk seafood restaurant with fish tanks. However this small cozy family style cranks out solid food. Waiters who speak fluent Cantonese and English as well. 

Parking sucks in Chinatown as usual. Hard to find since you walk up a long flight of stairs. But worth if you are walking in the area.
author: Sarah I.

description: Probably one of the best Hong Kong clay pot places. We had the eggplant chicken with salted fish and tofu fish clay pots. Both were delicious and tasted like food from back home. They do use a lot of oil in the fish but it is full of flavor. Portions are just right and price is really reasonable.
author: Jane W.

description:
This place is as authentic as it gets. It's a little hole in the wall and up a staircase, but when you get up there, it just smells so good (like home to me!) and is a bustling space full of delicious food and hungry people.

No matter your meat or vegetable preferences, GET THE CLAY POT. Especially if you go with lots of people so you all can share the different options. It's super hot when it comes out, so be careful not to touch the pot or burn your mouth on the food, but it's honestly done so well. I'm a big fan of one-pot meals so the clay pot is perfect if you want to just dig into a bowl and eat your heart out. Always remember you can ask for rice! And you should because #whoeatschinesefoodwithoutsomesortofricebasedstaple. 

My friends and I got the chicken tofu clay pot (10/10, would eat again) and the curry chicken clay pot. We also got some barbecue pork fried rice and it was so lit it was litty. The spring roll appetizers were also delicious.

The staff is friendly and efficient, and you'll get more than your money's worth of food here.
author: Kristen L.

description: Very low prices high quality authentic Chinese food. Kind of hard to find. Look at address and go upstairs. Bathrooms tiny but clean. Good good and did not get sick.
author: William A.

description: I Have been here three times. It is a hidden place which is at the 2nd floor. Most customers are local residents. It is not a fancy place to date. It is more like a restaurant in the neighborhood you go often. Food is home-made style. I always get the live fish.
author: Fangfang O.

description: The food was great. However I waited 2 hours to have the food delivered to me. Thai the reason I gave the two stars.
author: Angie R.

description:
Chinese new year is one of the biggest event in chinese history, everyone should know that by now...
Chinese new year January 28, 2017. Me and 10 other family wanted to celebrate chinese new year and try my dad first on baking egg tards by himself, and of course getting my red pocket. 
But my experience in this restaurant was extremely disappointing, this place yelp review  was really good so i thought this is a good place to eat.

First of all this place is narrow and small, the entrance have a long staircase to walk on and the restaurant itself is really small. Since none of my family member use a wheelchair or disability problems, i was ok with that.

Now the food was average at best, my uncle didnt really in to it. I don't know what a good food but he said it tested old.

Now the most disappointing part is the management, the management of this restaurant is lacking. We order our food, rice and waited. First it came in with 3 plate and a big bowl of rice, since we have 11 people we finish that bowl of rice pretty fast. As traditional chinese restaurant goes we tell our waitress to refill it, we waited for a long time and didnt not get any notice that they ran out of rice and have to cook another, that happen twice in a row...
The most funny part is they forgot our order in the middle of us eating...one of the waitress came back and ask what we ordered...really?
I know is chinese new year but isn't it the boss responsibility to manage and get ready and expect something like this would happen?

I would give this place a low star for now, but i think i would come back one day and maybe things would get better. Thanks for reading.
author: Dennis L.

description:
You'll never find the place if you don't know it's already there but wow what a find!  We had the chicken curry pot and sweet and sour chicken.  Both dishes were delicious!  I am not a fan of curry (my daughter loves it, so that was her pick) but the curry pot was the best part of the meal for me.  Not overpowering, perfectly balanced in the seasoning.  So delicious!  

The environment was very casual; like were were eating in someone's big dining room with extra tables.  So if you're feeling snooty, you might want to find another place to eat.

We will definitely being going back there on our next trip to San Francisco.
author: Monica D.

description: This is as good as a delivery of Chinese food you're gonna get! Decent price, really good food & the portions are big. Each plate is enough for 4 people. So get a few plates (sweet & sour along with Mongolian plates were great).  A few appetizers and fried rice & you're in business for a nice night in with friends!  I'll be ordering delivery from here again for sure!
author: Aza O.

description: A great place for authentic and unpretentious Chinese cuisine.  This place has an extensive menu and great food at reasonable prices.  Not sure what to order?  There is a great dinner option for 2 for $30.
author: Christopher B.

description:
Nothing special here. We each got a clay pot meal...mine chicken, his seafood. Adding quite a bit of soy sauce helped to add some flavor - other than that it was somewhat bland. 

However, the fried baby octopus were sensational. We should have just gotten a meal of those. 

Staff was nice though!
author: Christopher M.

description:
The reviews are totally fake for this restaurant. The food at this restaurant was vile.  The meat was different colored, slimy and tasted like it was frozen.  I ate 1/4 of the dish and threw the rest away.  For $30 for 2 people it was a total waste of money! 
The appetizer of pot stickers was pre packaged costco material that had been in the freezer way to long as well.   Save your money and instead go to the "stinking rose" restaurant right down the street.
author: Thomas F.

description: Amazing service !! Amazing food !! Always a smile ... clean and cozy little restaurant. Family friendly.. great value for you money !! Thank you !! We left with a big smile and a full belly!
author: Christina G.

description: This place is BOMB!!! Walnut glazed proms....to die. Everything tastes amazing. I would literally come back here for this food any day.
author: Kerri S.

description:
Well, Yelp!-ya let me down, which is a rare occurrence, but the food here was not very good, the staff was overwhelmed and, if ya ain't Chinese-and I'm not-you might wait and wait and wait for a table while you being bypassed for Chinese patrons.  If it hadn't been Sunday, with limited options available, and following a long hike to get here, we would have walked out. 

I truly wish we had and been spared this atrocity of a meal.  The "hot and sour" soup was neither-a totally bland soup lacking any flavor or substance.  The salt and pepper frog would have been more aptly named salt and pepper BONE, as the bone-to-meat ratio was approximately 95 to 5.  The seafood fun chow was neither, either.

Now, with that being said, these people are HONEST.  My fiancee left her purse at the restaurant.  We called and called with no one answering their phone.  The next day, we drove back from Modesto and, lo and behold, the manager gave my fiancee's purse back to her with everything intact.  That is refreshing these days.  So refreshing, that I would even give this place another chance upon a return visit due to the crush of people there the night we dined.  People that honest probably make good food and just had an off night when we were there.

THANK YOU FOR YOUR HONESTY.
author: Jerry H.

description: If you blink you will miss this spot but do not let that hold you back. We were in Chinatown this afternoon and found this gem. It was quick service and the BEST potstickers I've ever had. Seriously you won't regret the extra carbs!!
author: Colleen P.

description:
This restaurant was quite underwhelming. We tried a bunch of dishes for dinner but there wasn't anything that stood out. I think the food could have used more seasoning.

The beef chow fun was oily and had some flavor but I've definitely had better ones before. The chicken clay pot tasted like generic chicken and broccoli. The bok Choy was standard. The corn soup also lacked flavor so I had to add some salt.
author: Danielle C.

description: Thank you Yelp for helping me find this place. Obviously you can tell I love it by my rating. Food was 5 stars, service was also 5. The décor was a little dicey, but we were seated by the window and it was cool to be able to look down the street from second floor. We ordered beef chow fun, braised tofu clay pot, and black and bean clams. At first we were worried we ordered too much but the portions were perfect for us two Asian girls. The tofu clay pot was an obvious star. It tasted better than meat and the sauce was amazing! The black bean clams had a slight heat, which I liked. The beef chow fun was not too greasy and melt in your mouth. I wish I could take this place home.
author: Jisoo B.

description: Very good for the price. Plates are shareable and service is pretty nice!! Try the beef chow mein.
author: Nate L.

description:
Went on a Sunday early afternoon around 1'sh with two friends. This restaurant is located on the 2nd floor with a very narrow opening to the stairs on ground floor so you would easily miss it. The Chinese (金堂閣) and English names of this place are totally unrelated.

This place is pretty tiny and features mostly big tables sitting 8-10 people each. When we arrived there were only 3 big tables opened, and 2 of them were filled with leftover dishes from previous customers - I guess the staff was really busy then. So us 3 people were seated to this huge table next to the entrance.

#Braised Beef Stew 紅燒牛腩煲: B.
The taste was very typical. Usually when it comes to 紅燒 style there should be more flavors to it but it turned out to be typical beef stew. The beef's tenderness was okay.

#Fish Filet Pot 斑腩煲: B.
It tasted very similar as the braised beef stew - really wonder whether the fish filet and beef were either braised together or used the exactly the same soup/source base. Besides the fish, every other ingredients looked almost exactly the same.

#Curry Chicken Pot 咖哩雞煲: B+.
Although it didn't taste like curry at all but more like Portuguese style chicken instead; the flavor was pretty good and the chicken was impressively tender. It's also good that finally there was a pot didn't taste like the braised stew style above.

Also got the noodles and vegetables; they were okay but nothing spectacular or memorable. I guess overall their clay pot dishes are decent but definitely nothing stands out and a lot of competitors can meet the same standard easily.
author: Simon C.

description:
Hong Kong Clay Pot is a hidden gem.  Like seriously, so hidden.  It just looks like a rando set of stairs, but don't be deceived.  It's a stairway to food heaven.  The service is whatever and the bathroom is kinda dingy, but that's how you know this place is legit. 

DINNER
Ox tail clay pot-  fall off the bone delish
Chicken and chinese sausage clay pot-  good but the least fav of what we got
Bok choy- SO GOOD.  We just randomly wanted veggies and were blown away by this lol
Rice- standard, no surprise 

I'm sure everything off the menu is equally as good and the price point is just right, plus they take credit card!
author: Lyn C.

description: Super slow service. Waited over 30 minutes to get in and another 45 minutes before my dish came out. Food is just just ok, overly sweet not much other flavors. Our waitress never stopped by to check on us and we wait at least 20 minutes to get her attention for a check. Not sure how this place get so many great reviews. Maybe as a Chinese I am used to much more tasty Chinese food.
author: Yanrong W.

description: I had a serious hankering for Honey Walnut Shrimp. Not like an 'oh, that sounds good' kind of way, but a 'I need this in my life right now or else' kind of way. People in Chinatown are constantly sticking menus and coupons in your face, so it's an overwhelming decision making process when it comes to finding a place to eat. I actually scoured menus in search of this dish. Finally we decided on HKCP due to their exceptional prices. We popped the directions onto my phone and set off to find this place. Probably walked past it 6 times before realizing it was up a hidden staircase. We walk up the dingy stairs wondering what we were about to get ourselves into. It's basically an old apartment converted to a restaurant. Tables crammed together in a tight space. We got a window table which was welcome given the stifling feel of the restaurant. We were immediately served tea and handed menus. Everything is family style - we ordered wonton soup, gyoza, and honey walnut shrimp. The soup was very flavorful and there was plenty of it. I'd never had this kind of soup before, but apparently the hubs really loves it. You would think I would know a thing like that after 6 years! The pot stickers were MASSIVE and stuffed to the gills with filling. Great prices too! The honey walnut shrimp was perfection. Literally everything I'd hoped for and more. Perfectly cooked tender shrimp in a sauce that made me melt in my seat. This really hit the spot. I'm so happy we found this place!
author: Brandi K.

description: Food was delicious! My kids all loved everything. The staff was very friendly and accommodating... when we asked for low sodium soy sauce, at first she said they didn't have any... which was fine. Then, shortly after came with a dish of some other soy sauce and said to try it, it might be better. Very sweet of her. If in China Town we would come again. Parking in the area is a challenge though! ;)
author: Tina I.

description: The place was super cute and the service was fine but the food was really bland. So disappointing because they had great reviews and I've heard such great things about the chinese food in China town- San Francisco.
author: Carly S.

description: It is very strange that on Google maps this place is 4.5 stars with a huge amount of reviews and actually voted one of the five best restaurants in Chinatown. And here on yelp it is only 3.5 stars and a lot of negative reviews. Anyway,Our experience was fantastic. If you are looking for five star service then this isn't the place for you. If you are looking for a very delicious and inexpensive meal served fast and a cool atmosphere, then this is the place. We loved it.
author: Stephen B.

description:
Place was good, not stellar or mind-blowing, but good.  Basic dish I had (chicken curry something).  Kind of tasted devoid of msg, but I'm not sure.  I ate it anyway and relaxed with a nice beer pairing. 

Atmosphere was casual...no fine-dining here, which is fine.  Good for taking a leisurely lunch, but as a tourist, this wouldn't be my first choice.
author: Nykol M.

description: I went to this restaurant a long time back. We were strolling down on the streets of Chinatown. I was looking at Yelp and figuring out which restaurant to try out. Clay pot sounded interesting, so gave it a try. The restaurant gives a homely feeling. Our server was really sweet. We were served with complimentary tea, which had nice herbal taste. I ordered lobster in clay pot, don't know if they still have it on menu. It was served with vermicelli. I was asked if I want my lobster to be cracked open and I said yes. Well, I should have said no as because of this my dish had many pieces of shell in it. Otherwise, the dish tasted yum. I will recommend this place.
author: Ruchi S.

description: Excellent Chinese food, the eggplant, chicken clay pot was amazing as well as the Mongolian beef. Upstairs and cozy in SF's China Town district. You know it's good authentic food when you see locals eating there. A must for Chinese food when in SF.
author: Craig R.

description: SO GOOD. my 2 friends and I shared the pot sticker plate and a plate of chicken fried rice and had plenty of food between us! Definitely authentic. Great service.
author: Grace L.

description: Service was meh.  Food was okay but I wasn't too impressed with it.  We ordered the honey walnut shrimp, the curry chicken clay pot, the seafood clay pot, and vegetable chow fun.  The honey walnut shrimp was okay, you kinda can't do that wrong.  The curry chicken clay pot was probably the best dish out of the ones we ordered.  There was a lot of curry powder and it mixed really well with white rice.  The seafood clay pot was meh.  It didn't have too much seafood.  The vegetable chow fun was a little oil heavy.  Definitely was drinking a lot of tea throughout the meal.  Overall, I would probably try another place in Chinatown than come back here. Although I have to say it was pretty cheap.  About $50 for 5 people so $10 bucks per person for a lot of food.
author: Cynthia L.

description:
February 13, 2017 - the out of the way upstairs "basic" Chinese restaurant appealed to me as likely reasonable price fare for take-out.
BUT It came at a high price when we ordered Sweet n' Sour chicken and Kong Pou chicken for Take Out. The chicken was stale and hard, old from maybe the day before. My partner and I became sick during the night with "it" coming out both ends so to speak for 2 days. Don't bother going to this place. 
Bryan K
author: Kelly B.

description:
Wait stop. You just probably just walked past this little, beautiful hole in the wall staircase that leads to the Hong Kong Clay Pot. This restaurant is the real deal. We were lucky to come here right after the lunch rush, so we were able to get our food quickly and had no problems with seating. It's small, can be a little cramped if it's very busy, but the food is well worth it. Since I don't eat meat I ordered the Vegetarian Clay Pot. The food came out still boiling (do not touch anything) and I enjoyed a beer while chatting and waiting for it to cool down. 

Once it cooled down enough to not send me to the ER I dug in and was very delighted. Despite the dish basically just being vegetables in a stew more or less, it was fantastic and left me feeling not hungry but not bloated and full either. 

If you're using your GPS to find the place, make sure you look for the staircase in the wall and try not to walk past.
author: Eric M.

description:
Great food. Quick service, with very friendly family staff!  It got more crowded as we sat down and started eating lunch. 

The food is amazing the vibe is lacking a little. It's cute but underwhelming. Our water was served in a red solo cup for starters. But once the food started rolling out, no more complaining. 

For a quick bite I say come up the stairs and give it a shot!
author: Phillip W.

description: A home-cooking style restaurant. Has a small entrance, and the restaurant is on the second floor. No air conditioner, so can be too good warm if you go on a hot day. Food is ok considering the price.
author: Hongni Z.

description:
In a city where i thought it impossible to get flavorless, bland Chinese food  I was wrong. The "spicy" bean curd with pork had no heat. The tender mixed greens was just baby bok choy.  Chicken curry was meh. To top it off after paying for delivery we discovered there was no streamed rice. What Chinese restaurant doesn't throw in rice when  you order curry? This place thats who!  

I've had better Chinese from the Airport Food Court in Newark.  
This was not our first choice but the other place that said they deliver through Yelp Eat 24 didn't show up after downloading it. Start over. Not a good first experience using this app.

Yelpers who positively reviewed this place must think La Choy in a can is the bomb.
author: Blair G.

description:
Tagged along with my coworkers who had some serious hankerings for some claypot. The place they WANTED to go to happened to be closed on a Tuesday (random) and a quick yelp search revealed to us this place as a another great option. 

Our dining experience was exactly as we should have had because we did not do research prior. Since it was a cantonese hole in the wall family restaurant I suspected that things would be served family style here-- my coworkers didn't believe me and insisted on order a WHOLE clay pot each. (too much food alert!) Our server (though nice), didn't fully understand us when we order 4 of the chicken and Chinese sausage claypot. After some discussion with her in Cantonese she suggested we maybe bring that number down to 3 and add a garlic pea shoot dish instead. My coworkers and I ended up sharing family style the veggies, the 3 GIGANTIC same chicken and sausage clay pots, and 1 tofu and chicken claypot. We also received free soup from the lovely waitress as an appetizer-- delicious!

Though not a huge fan of the 3 chicken and Chinese sausage clay pots (it was 70% onion) I DID love the pea shoots and tofu and chicken claypot. The tofu was not the fried kind-- it was soft silky tofu mixed with minced chopped chicken and green onions. Paired with white rice, it was fantastic. And at $8.95 a pot?! It was such a steal. 

Overall, nice service, great affordable pricing, hole in the restaurant that is a bit hard to find, delicious clay pot; and lessoned learned-- ITS FAMILY STYLE don't be afraid to share all kinds of dishes with each other!
author: Maggie Y.

description:
Tourist trap. Social bias influence!! They have 5 star reviews but the food is 'disgusting'

I wouldn't even gave them 1 star, but there is no negative stars!!!
author: sirin a.

description:
8/31/14: Amazingly disappointing.  I spent significant effort convincing my friends to get Chinese food this night, and after they finally agreed we ended up with this...

Spent about 1hr in line to get in.  The line sucks.  The restaurant is on the 2nd floor, and so you line up on this skinny stairway leading up, and every once in a while a cook would come down with containers of trash so that you can see all the wonderful stuffs they want to get out of the restaurant.  One hour.

Then we sat down.  They took our order.  ONE ANNNNDDDD A HALF!!!!!! hours later we get our first dish.  Let me repeat: 1.5hrs between taking our order and serving our first dish.  And yes, we asked what was going on.  There was a guy that came by, and after we inquired, he would say multiple times, "I don't work here but I am helping out.  I am a customer."  ...Yeah, um, right... that's what I thought too.  Look, I'm Chinese.  I've eaten at hundreds of Chinese restaurants.  Usually the food comes faster than at your typical American places.  So, 1.5hr to cook is something special.  Something very special indeed.

So fine, the food:

1. Steamed Black Bass Fish $15.95: Holy crap!  The fish was quite small and falling apart when it arrived.  Just look at my pictures.  It's a mess.  Tasted normal, but not any better than I can cook at home just steaming a fish from Ranch 99 with some soy sauce and sesame oil on top.  $16!  Gawd.  2/10

2. Chicken Fried Rice $7.95:  (No I didn't order this... see person with far lighter skin to my left.)  So, it's fried rice with pieces of chicken.  I guess it was alright.  Not much to say.  5/10.

3. Honey Walnut Prawns $8.50: Well, I've had this dish many dozens of times.  This one was the worst of the bottom 1/3rd or so.  The batter was not crispy... a tad soggy.  Walnuts and mayo sauce were fine.  The shrimp itself wasn't overcooked.  But well, being soggy kinda kills it.  4/10

4. Snow Pea Sprouts w/ Garlic $8.50: Ahhhhh.... such a needed break--this one was excellent.  Nothing over-the-top.  Just well cooked and seasoned, in a simply traditional fashion.  Vegetables tasted fresh.  7/10

5. Beef Stew in Clay Pot $8.50:  Too much tofu.  And too much of the chewy tissue Chinese use from stewing meat.  You can see that stuff rolled up in cylinders in the pictures.  It was also not cooked long enough so I think most people either threw it away or spit it out.  The beef itself was alright, but there was far less of that than the gummy tissue and tofu.  Not good.  3/10

So... most horrible experience possible leading up to actually tasting food...

Plus, probably one of the worst meals of Chinese food I've had...

(Oh, and unfortunately I don't have a picture, but the woman's bathroom is separated by a shower drapery in the dining room)... yeah, had to add that...

1/5.  Heck, 1/100.

#chinese
author: Dean C.

description: I had a really enjoyable dinner. Other recent reviews are spot-on. The room itself is nondescript, basic, and functional. One nice thing about being upstairs is that it gets natural light. The food is terrific. Expertly prepared, visually appealing, healthful, and very tasty. They serve beer, which isn't always available in Chinese restaurants, but goes so well with the food. The service is very friendly despite the bustle. It can get crowded but tables turn over at a good pace. A "keeper!"
author: Geoffrey F.

description: Definitely a hole in the wall spot, but my was the line long! My friend and I each ordered a clay pot, I definitely liked hers better though (get the fish clay pot). Be prepared to share a table (one of those asian family tables), but the ambience is still pretty cheerful if you don't mind!
author: Cheechee L.

description: If you want to go to a place that feels very homey, this place fits the bill. You can tell it's family run and if you are nice to them and can speak canto you will get free things, usually we get some seaweed soup which is a great finisher. There aren't dishes that really stand out here, but everything just feels like something your parents would make
author: Victor D.

description:
Wow! You would think this place is the real deal because the tables are full, but most people are the first timers like us!  Yelp reviews scammed us! 

This is nothing close to Chinese food! We ordered sweet and sour soup (decent) , beef clay pot (terrible), salt and pepper chicken wings (it only had garlic on it, NO SALT NO PEPPER, beef pan fried noodle (terrible, super heavy sauce that would get you sick), kong pao chicken (terrible, meat was hard, not spicy at all)

We literally told people that was waiting in line to RUN and don't turn back, because food is "disgusting"!
author: Gozde U.

description:
I love this place despite of its shady-ness. I've been there 4-5 times, every time I loved the food but wished they had a better dining environment. 

This is a real Cantonese experience. I once dined with just us and a big table of gangster looking guys at the big table, drinking and eating, and at the end, the chef joined them at that table LOL. 

I always get the lobster noodles (not lo mein, but e-mein). So good! When crabs are in season, I order crab noodles. I've tried other things too, but nothing beats the lobster noodles. 

Service is...interesting. I felt like I was taken good care of by a rude mom.
author: Wendy K.

description: This place does not get the credit it deserves. I have eaten here several times. The food is really good whether you are there for traditional Chinese dishes or even Americanized Chinese food such as kung pao chicken. I love their gai lan and their crab or lobster dishes that they have. The staff is very friendly and honest. This place is a family style restaurant and is great for groups. If you ever get the chance, the seating by the windows has a nice view of the China Town from above. I would also like to note that this places bathrooms are very clean for it being a China Town restaurant. I have been eating at China Town Restaurants my whole life. They often scream "Dead things Mikey! Dead things!" (Goonies reference). That being said, Hong Kong Clay Pot does a really good job at keeping their restrooms clean.
author: Terry P.

description: Service was good, everyone was really nice and welcoming. Food was good, nothing to write home about. Best thing we had was the half shell clam with soy sauce and vermicelli noodles! Would come back for sake and clams.
author: amal s.

description: Great dinner meal deals for two, three, or four people!  Bok choy was delicious!  Service was casual and the environment was chill. Free wifi!
author: Jillian K.

description:
I like the authentic food. It's not fake Americanized Chinese food. We had the ong choy, the salt & pepper pork chops and the frog legs. The pork chops were the best!

However, I say the entire place was kind of dirty and the frog dish barely had any frog in it. 

I think we can find a place just as dirty and authentic and get better food. Or at least more of the food we ordered.
author: Kay T.

description: I like the food! Very tasty clams with black bean sauce, Ong-Choy with beancurd sauce, mustard greens with salted eggs soup, westlake beef soup...all on point. But they stopped delivering to my condo / area. Boo!
author: Vee V.

description: The food is good if you are looking for an Americanized Chinese dinner. I would recommend this place for my American friends who has not ventured into a true Cantonese dinner territory yet.
author: Susan L.

description: Fast service, no-frills establishment. I got the seafood and tofu clay pot for lunch. The fish fillet and squid used were fresh and flavorful, the tofu struck a good balance between the slightly crispy skin and tender interior, and the shiitake mushrooms lent a rich aroma to the dish. The umami of the raw ingredients is brought out without the use of heavy condiments like soy sauce.
author: Tony J.

description:
We recently had some guests in town who wanted to experience some real Chinatown and Hong Kong Clay Pot was a great fit! The service was fast and all of the wait staff was friendly. The food was delicious, hot, and the portions were just right. It isn't the cleanest (-1 star) but definitely a good spot.

We had 4 (hungry) people with 3 chicken entrees, fried rice, (2) steamed rice, and spring rolls and walked out full and happy.
author: Heidi M.

description: They took good care of us for a party of 8, but the food was atrocious. Everything was severely lacking in flavor
author: Mitchell K.

description: Nothing to write home about. It's good for comfort, diver Chinese cuisine, but nothing fancy or too spectacular. Food is flavorful and tasty for a quick lunch.
author: Elliot F.

description:
Pretty good Chinese food. Service was average but food was pretty good. We ordered kung pao chicken, pan fried chicken noodles, and shrimp fried rice. BTW- the restaurant is on the second floor. 

KUNG PAO CHICKEN 5/5- The kung pao was quite good. It was simple yet flavorful. I was really surprised to see that they actually gave enough chicken in the dish! Most Chinese restaurants rip you off by giving you two pieces of chicken and a bunch of vegetables. This place actually gave a lot of chicken with a fair amount of vegetables. Much appreciated!

PAN FRIED CHICKEN NOODLES 4/5- Good noodles. Not great, not horrible. 

SHRIMP FRIED RICE 4.5/5- Shrimp was awesome. Rice wasn't sticky rice, but regular white rice. A little bit more soy sauce would have been nice. 

Another plus: This place is one of the nice restaurants in Chinatown (as in it's not rundown like most of the other places.)
author: Harry S.

description: Great food. Very flavorful and fresh. Good selection for vegetarian dishes. Not extremely salty but soooo good!! We will be back. Not sure where to eat in China town... come here
author: Anil S.

description:
I've been to a small theater located on the second story of a hotel, wherein I had to traverse a seemingly narrow staircase.

Why not eat at a Cantonese restaurant located on the second story of a narrow staircase as well? What have I got to lose? 

The theater was great and made a distinct impression on me, in spite of its oddity. Why should this place be any different? Or at least I tried to tell myself that.

When I am in Chinatown, I normally eat at normal places such as the House of Nanking. But this time, I wanted a change. A departure from the norm. Therefore, I sought out this odd, unassuming restaurant on the second floor.

I was prepared to be greatly surprised; especially since I was famished after a long walk.

Needless to say, my expectations were met with utter disappointment. The service was less than marginal, and the foodwas probably the blandest Cantonese cuisine I have ever tasted in my entire life. It was totally uninspired, and under cooked.

I had the Chicken Curry, the Chicken Lo Mein, and the Fried Rice. Besides the fact that it took forever for them to navigate through the myriad of patrons in this small place to take my order, they also took forever to get me my food. At least, if the food was great, it would've made up for the aggravation of having to wait.
