And when you see a bunch of Chinese people eating at a Chinese restaurant, you know that you can't go wrong. 

We were feeling piggy and ordered a lot of food: ginger crab, beef clay pot, seafood clay pot, and onchoy. 

The ginger crab was just right. The portion was small, but for the price it was great! ($16, I believe?) We probably could've just gotten one clay pot, but we were greedy to try more dishes. Since clay pot was part of the name of the restaurant, we figured it was a good bet. The seafood clay pot is made just the way I like it: loaded with various seafoods and fried tofu. Yummers! The beef clay pot was not bad, but I probably won't order it again. The cuts of beef aren't very great, and the flavor of the sauce wasn't as good as the seafood's. It also came with tofu... we were actually tofu-ed out after eating both clay pots. The onchoy is cooked just right, no complaints. 

I would come here again. It's got a total mom & pop's feel. We were actually the last table to finish eating, and the restaurant staff started eating while we were finishing up. It looks like a family business- brothers, wives, and a teenage daughter. The food was totally comfort. I would come here again, especially since the prices are really good!
author: Lee L.

description:
This review is based on one visit and incorporates ratings from my friends that joined me for dinner.  

We arrived in Chinatown and went up a flight of stairs to enter a smallish restaurant for dinner.  There we many selections on the menu, many that I was not brave enough to try.  I ordered the ribs and my friends ordered different plates and we all shared the food.  The food was good and we washed it down with cold Heinekens.

The service was OK, the restaurant cleanliness was OK, the menu selection was good, the food was good and the prices were good.  I would rate this at 3.5 stars if Yelp would let me.
author: Matt G.

description:
First off, we really enjoy Panda Express which is why we rated this place one star because apparently we really love fake Chinese food and not authentic Chinese food. We thought we'd try and be adventurous so we ordered spicy jelly fish for our appetizers. As soon as the plate arrived, one of us had instant regret. It was disgusting. They looked like cold slimy onions with the consistency of gummy worms. We also ordered kung pao chicken and the seafood clay pot which were bland. Upside, if you order 7-up, you will be served with a can of 7-up for $1.50 even though the menu says $1.35.

Also, we didn't have high expectations as far as customer service goes but the servers seemed to have forgotten about us a few times. People who arrived after us had their orders taken before us and also received their food before us. We still had fun there but we will be sticking to Panda Express from now on.
author: Wab G.

description: Wonderful place with authentic cuisine. The hot pot wirh chicken, mushrooms, and sausage was just like I've had in Shanghai. The salt and pepper bean curd appetizer is to die for. The service was attentive without being overbearing. The location was clean and had a good view of Grant Street. Overall a really good place to eat. Well worth it.
author: Kenneth S.

description:
Best Chinese food I've ever had. This is a real hole-in-the-wall, you'll miss it if you don't look carefully. It's upstairs with a street level entrance, and looks super sketchy, but it's amazing.

The complimentary green tea was amazing, and my fiancé and I both had sweet & sour chicken. It was incredible, best chicken either of us had ever had.
author: Katie M.

description:
We used to go there every week.  It's the best Chinese food in the east bay.  A hole in the world.  You can order dishes that are not on the menu.  Recommended dishes:
1. Lobster noodle - best, best
2. steam whole fish
3. bitter-melon
4. Jing Du pork
5. oyster in soy sauce
6. all the Chinese green veggies are good

Yum, yum...
author: Xiaoyan S.

description:
This is probably one of the most authentic Cantonese restaurants in Chinatown.
Free soup and dessert provided. Price is very reasonable compared to other restaurants. Servers are very friendly. 
Highly recommended dishes are as follow:
- Steamed Sea Bass
- Abalone in Clay Pot 
- Braised Black Bass w/ Garlic
- Honey Walnut Prawns
- Guai Fei Pong (not in menu)
author: Christine C.

description:
After reading all the reviews on Yelp I had to give this place a try.
This place is authetic, so if you are looking for a recreation of Panda Express then maybe you should just walk down the sketchy ass stairs and leave Chinatown.
What we got:
the honey walnut prawns, the clay pot with abalone and chicken, chicken fried rice and hot and sour soup.

My favorite hands down was the honey walnut prawns. They were AMAZING. Seriously so mouth watering good. I'm not a giant  fan of Chinese, meaning most of the time I go to a Chinese place I never feel the need to come back. But I could of eaten plate after plate of those prawns. Make sure to get those!

The hot and sour soup was also pretty tasty. It has a little bit of  kick to it and for 5 dollars you get a huge bowl! 

The chicken fried rice was probably the best chicken fried rice I've ever had. It wasn't too greasy but still hit the spot.

I personally didn't  LOVE the clay pot but my boyfriend really enjoyed it. To me it had a bit too many green peppers.

Now here is were they loose a star. I went to go use the restroom which was labeled woman. To my disgust the toilet seat was covered in pee (EW) and no toilet seat covers OR soap. Yucccccck. As soon as I left the bathroom I saw a Chinese man obviously spitting on his plate (not very appetizing either....but I guess that isn't the restaurants fault) Also, the service here is pretty much non-existent, we had to ask for to go containers and the check etc.
author: Issy D.

description: I think everyone except for my mom and I ordered their clay pot here.. the food quality was alright but I questioned how clean their kitchen was because of how old and run down the place was. It was quite stuffy, but definitely a hole in the wall kind of resturant with a lot of regulars during lunch hours. Still not bad though if you're looking for some Cantonese style home cooking.
author: Terinna R.

description: very good food. we got there right when they opened and were first to sit down. the restaurant got busy right away and the service was also great.  get there early if you can
author: Ryan D.

description: After looking at Yelp and seeing that this restaurant not only had good reviews but also only 2 $$ we were in. I love a great deal!! The won ton soup was delicious!!!! You know its going to be good when the broth alone is delectable!! We ordered way too much food but had a nice meal again so really made it cheap with all the leftovers. Trying to be healthy we ordered the Vegetarian Clay Pot and it was awesome!! My mouth is watering thinking about it now!!! We had a very nice server and a great seat at the window for people watching.
author: Kelly M.

description: I am not a big fan of Chinese food, but come on. When in Rome and all that. First, note that this is family style. That explains some of the menu prices (low prices =small plates). The sweet and sour chicken is a ho hum typical dish. You're safe with that if you are worried about what to eat. I had the clay pot fish with black bean mushroom. The fish was great; almost like little potato dumplings. There were large pieces of tofu in it which I didn't like, but others in my party did. I left full. I am glad we ate here.
author: Bruce N.

description:
We were looking for a late lunch in Chinatown and used Yelp to find Hong Kong Clay Pot.   We were seated only 45 minutes before they were to close but 3 or 4 tables were seated after us and we did not feel rushed.   

The Honey Walnut Shrimp and Salt and Pepper Shrimp were very good.   I was surprised at how light the Salt and Pepper Shrimp was.  Almost like tempura.   The Spring Rolls were good.  

The Hot and Sour soup was very heavy handed with what tasted like Louisiana hot sauce which was it's only flavor.  The vegetables in the Vegetable Clay Pot were fresh but slightly under cooked and if there was a sauce, I could not taste it.  The tea we ordered was tepid and very weak.  So weak that I could taste the chemicals from the tap water.   

We were most likely given the tourist menu, but we didn't know any better.  From reading other reviews, if I went again, I would ask for the lunch special menu and try a Tofu Clay Pot.  The meal was decent with efficient service.  Fairly rated on Yelp IMO.
author: Catherine S.

description: exellent hot pot, Especially enjoyed the lamb . Jellyfish appetizer was also a stand out.
author: Jim S.

description:
Eating in Chinatown is a gamble, and I don't have any knowledge.  So we relied on yelp.  Hong Kong Clay Pot got 4 stars, so we figured it was safe.

And it was safe.  About half the guests were Anglos like us, tourists.  The other half Asian.  The menu (at least the one they gave us) was crafted for tourists with the standard American-Chinese dishes. 

My recommendation would be to select the namesake dishes, the clay pots.  You'll get enough food for 2 or 3 people.

The food was fine.  So I'm going with "A-Ok", 3-stars.  But I wouldn't argue with those giving it 4 stars.  There's better Chinese food in the world, but I don't know were that would be in Chinatown.  If you're in Chinatown, this is a safe play.
author: TennisBum P.

description: Really quick service, good food and lots of variety! Definitely order just one dish and share with whoever you're out with (the serving sizes are quite large). We had some communication issues with our waitress and the bathrooms were awful but all in all, it was a good dinner.
author: Morgan L.

description:
I knew we'd entered authentic-land when 90% of the tables were reserved for big Chinese families out celebrating the "Year of the Dragon".  Gung Hay Fat Choy!   

A little table was pulled aside for 3 of us and, for less than $50 including tax, out came a table-full of simple, yummy food:

* Salt and pepper quail
* Spring rolls 
* Prawns and Scallops with Chinese Broccoli
* Mustard Greens with Garlic
* Hunan Beef with onion
* Tea & Fortune Cookies

Nice fresh flavors.  Quick, friendly-enough service.  Reasonable prices.  Nothing I sampled blew my socks off but the non-spicy Chinese food rarely does.  They did have a section of Hunan offerings and the entree from that section was spicy, though I wasn't blown away by any of the flavors.   

Bottom line is that this is a good place for decent, simple Chinese food and an authentic (down-market) Chinatown experience.  You can sample a whole mess of dishes without spending much money and you'll leave satisfied.  If you're lucky, you might even get a fortune like the one I got:  "New ideas could be profitable" (in bed).
author: Tracey A.

description:
Kinda wish i could give this place 3.5 stars, but if I had to lean one way I'd lean towards a 3. I got the tofu hot pot, which came with fried tofu, bok choy, and mushrooms in a watery sort of sauce. The mushroom actually had a great flavor to it, but the bok choy and tofu didn't have that much taste to them. This place is pretty cheap, open late, and takes credit cards - all pluses.

On a side note, its kind of hard to find - look up the address, and remember that it's up on the second floor (and the sign to the entrance is in Chinese).
author: Amaresh S.

description: We were visiting San Fran and tried this place out because it had better reviews than other places. Quick seating and food was delivered quickly. We ordered pot stickers, Mongolian Beef, and Kung Pao Chicken. Pot stickers were ok but we enjoyed the beef and chicken. Both were on the spicy side. If you look like a tourist (which we were) they will give you the regular menu that's much more expensive. Make sure and order off the lunch/specials menu. It's 1/2 the cost!
author: Carrie W.

description: A great place right off Grant ave, it looks like a local spot and I can see why. It is very affordable and the amount of food u get is amazing!  We ordered the meal b which came with way more food than I expected!  I would recommend this place to anyone and if I lived here would for sure come again!
author: Marcus D.

description: Excellent and authentic China town experience. Don't pass over an opportunity to eat here. I was travelling so dining alone. They made me beef and BoJ choi on rice - no onions or garlic because of fructose intolerance.
author: Kelly G.

description:
I'm not an expert of the streets of SF Chinatown, but the hustle and bustle reminds me of home enough that there's always a connection when I'm wandering around the neighborhood.  Surprisingly, Chinatown doesn't have a good reputation when it comes to Chinese food, as a lot of it is seen as catering to tourists, serving Americanized Chinese food.

Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant stands out from the touristy scene.  I visited on a Thursday around lunchtime, and as soon as I walked up the stairs, I found the place packed with Cantonese locals getting their lunch on.  It was so packed I ended up having to share a large table with some other people.  

The lunchtime specials here are cheap.  I ordered a bowl of pig liver congee and a beef brisket with vegetables rice plate for 4.50 each.  Portions were more than generous, too.

The congee was decent.  It wasn't the best I've had, especially since the , but the liver was good.  It didn't taste funny, which liver sometimes does, and the texture wasn't rubbery either.  Also, for $4.50, you get a good amount of it.  

The beef brisket was standard too.  I was actually more impressed with the veggies.  They tasted fresh and again, the portion size was generous.  I was almost full after the congee that I didn't even touch the rice.  

Also, I should note that immediately upon sitting down, they gave me a bowl of complimentary soup.  Not many restaurants continue doing that these days.  It wasn't amazing, but you can't complain (too much) about free.

Service:  Efficient and they actually smile!

Bottom line:  Bargain for lunch!
author: Denny C.

description: Great place. Fresh food and perfect for family style sit down. Highly recommend. It's also a block away from the fortune cookie factory and a boba tea place for dessert.
author: Nicole T.

description:
Been coming here ever since I was little! I always bring friends visiting from out of town here for some 'authentic' cantonese food. It's one of the only restaurants worth visiting in Chinatown. 

The waitress is consistently attentive and friendly-- same one every single time I come here. I'm sure she recognizes my face now, given my loyalty.
author: Colleen W.

description:
I think this place is better than R&G Lounge and it's for half the price. Just for that, they get an extra star. To get to the restaurant you have to climb a semi-steep set of stairs so use caution if you plan on bringing your grandparents or if you have bad knees. The minute we walked in, I immediately knew that this place is going to be good. The restaurant was small but it was packed. The other Chinese restaurants around the area were all empty.  My mom liked the fact that they sat us by the window so that she can look onto the busy street.  She's a people watcher like me. The restaurant served us our food pretty quickly and the servers were attentive.

Appetizers:
Jellyfish= tasted just like the sesame chili sauce it was tossed in. It is soft like jello but when you bite it, you get this crunchy plastic like sound. If you're a person that's picky when it comes to texture, you might not like this.
Honey walnut prawns= Yelp sheeple approved and they were right. The sauce and the walnuts really went well with the prawns. The prawns tasted fresh and was not overcooked. Loverboy said this was his favorite out of everything we ordered and I agree with him.
Potstickers= this one is OK. The flour shell reminds me of the Lingling potstickers sold at Costco. The stuffing inside the potstickers looked like it was house made but the taste wasn't too exciting. When they served this to us, it was just warm so I wasn't too stoked on it.

Main course:
Chicken claypot= the chicken was kind of bland and rubbery because it was over cooked. I think the sauce had too much cornstarch. I will not be ordering this dish in the future because it was disappointing.
Seafood claypot= my dad and mom killed this dish and they said it was pretty tasty.  I didn't try it because I'm not a big seafood eater.
Pork sweet and sour= the flavor was ok.  It's your standard sweet and sour that you can get pretty much everywhere.  The pork was also overcooked and was kind of hard. The bell peppers were too soft and was overcooked too.  I prefer them to have a little crunch.
Salt and pepper crab= my mom and dad really liked this one. They said this was their favorite out of everything we ordered.  I took a small bite out of a piece and I thought the crab tasted fresh and it had that sweetness that you normally associate with crab meat.  Loverboy said he wasn't a fan of it.  (He's extremely finicky when it comes to Asian food.)
BBQ pork fried rice= my mom and I loved their fried rice. The one they served us was not oily at all.  The rice was flavored perfectly and can stand alone if you didn't want to order extra entrees.

I definitely will come back for more.  The prices are reasonable and we were able to satisfy our Chinese Food craving. I think their food is better than the other Chinese restaurants I have tried in the vicinity.
author: Shirleyanne A.

description: Went here for lunch on 2/23/15. We were the only tourists in the place. It was filled with locals. We had the spring rolls, potstickers, honey walnut prawns, and Kung Pau chicken. Everything was really tasty. The service was top notch. Highly recommend this place.
author: Stephen M.

description: Great Chinese food in a restaurant used mainly by locals.  We had Abalone and Chicken Clay Pot, Squab Clay Pot, and the Walnut Chicken.  Everything was very good
author: Jonathan J.

description: Went for lunch. About 3/4 and service was bad and food came out slow.  Shrimp fried rice was tasteless, pot stickers had an awful filing.  Very hot in there, tables way too close together.  No clue why this is highly rated.
author: Fred G.

description:
Finally I had a chance to try their hot pot (it's not on their menu). I am a big fan of hot pot in the winter time. Hot pot (in Japanese: Nabe) makes your body and hart warm! I only like to eat hot pot with my "good" friends and family. since you shear the big pot with everyone. I wouldn't shear the hot pot with a coworker nor a boy who I just met... 

I really love HK's Clay Pot especially the seafood one with fresh tasting Shrimps, Scallops, Squid and Tofu...   http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/Sg_R67gxg9ALW2wtg13aYQ?select=L8rJBPFf0ODo9lAubDxauA HOWEVER... I didn't like their Hot pot. Their broth is not flavorful. The quality of their meat and dumplings are not as good (dumplings came out frozen to our table... which bring the pot's temperature too low) Though if you want mountain of food for good price, you will be happy with the choice since you will get, over 1 lb (per person) of green vegetables, fresh oyster, heds-on shrimps, fish balls, pork balls, wan tans, potstickers, sliced beef, egg noodles, eggs and tofu. 

The best things to order at HK are seafood and Clay Pots.
author: Chie J.

description:
We went looking for this place and walked by it four times without realizing it! It is a hard place to find. Look for the blue canopy and a yellow sign. You will know what I mean...trust me.

All in all, deliciousness. We ordered a few of their of claypots and each one was oh so sexy. I especislly loved their lamb clay pot. They braised and slowcooked that sucker to death. The meat was incredibly tender and didn't have too strong of a game-y taste. Be careful. Claypots are like primitive slowcookers. It even cooked down the bones...

A sign of a good Chinese restaurant is how well they can prepare staple dishes. We ordered my husband's favorite - beef chow fun. They knocked it out of the park. Not at all greasy. No signs of using msg. Tender and flavorful beef. Lots of sauce and onions! 

This place is pretty authentic and I would recommend people coming here if they are visiting Chinatown. We ordered six dishes and they were all cleared by the the time dinner had ended. No boxes needed! When five Asians sit in silence eating, you know it's got to be good.
author: Elizabeth T.

description:
In search of more great Chinese food, my friends and I decided to drop into Chinatown for the real deal.  Walking down the street, we dipped into a side door that led upstairs to the second floor to a packed house.  Hong Kong Clay Pot would clearly be a legit spot.  Our party of 4 decided to get their preset menu for 4 for only $48.  For 7 courses with rice, it was an incredible bargain.

For the soup course, we decided to swap out the beef soup with hot and sour soup.  Full of spice and all the good stuff, it set just the right tone to cut through the cold of San Francisco night and started our meal off right.

For the main courses, the sauteed bok choy and rice came first.  Cooked with whole cloves of garlic the aroma wafted through our noses and made me giddy with anticipation of the rest of the fabulous dishes to follow.

Next came the clay pot with shrimp, bean curd, and water chestnuts.  While I'm not usually a huge fan of the clay pot dishes, I really enjoyed the savoriness of the awesome combination of flavors in this one.

The fried chicken wings were simple, savory, seasoned with only MSG, and really freaking hot.  Sometimes there isn't anything better than the simplest things and I really enjoyed them.  I would enjoy the next dish even more.

Honey walnut prawns were luckily on the preset menu and I can eat this stuff all day.  While it wasn't the absolute best rendition I had ever had, I was no less delicious.  Somehow it's not very easy to mess this one up and I'm glad it isn't.

For the price, I'm blown away that crab was actually on our menu.  While it wasn't pre-cut or cracked, the meat was tender and fresh.  Because of the hassle in eating it, I only had a few pieces, but my friends finished the whole thing.

The last dish of the set was the sweet and sour pork chops.  I usually order the salt and pepper flavor, but these were really tasty nonetheless.  There was a bit more fat on the bones than I would have preferred, but I definitely focused my efforts on this dish.

While the service and location were kind of sketchy, the food and price were phenomenal.  I could not believe how much food we got and spent only about $15 per person including tax and tip.  This is the kind of stuff that I miss in San Diego and look forward to whenever I come back to the Bay Area.  I would kill for this stuff in SoCal.

Food: 10/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 5/10
author: Joe M.

description: I am a chauffeur and I have taken guest to the restaurant a couple of times. I took some high-profile guests their Super Bowl week.  I had read online about this wonderful walnut and shrimp  They brought me a portion of it. Wow It was terrible I'll never recommend HK clay pot again
author: Gary G.

description:
We almost missed this place. Don't let the steep sketchy looking stairs fool you - this place is delish! 
I ordered the honey walnut prawns based on other reviews. Turns out they were just as good as the good folks said they would be. 
My sisters were with me, they ordered: cashew chicken, steamed lobster, and chicken chow mein, and spring rolls. I had a few bites of their dishes and everything was fantastic! 
Great food & wonderful service.
author: Heather C.

description: Yum!  I like this place.  Good food.  Great prices!  A little hard to find since it's a doorway with stairs leading up.  My parents like coming here when we go have food with my grandpa.  Order the ginger scallion lobster.  Sooo good!  We couldn't get crab since this was during the pricing thing, but that is delicious as well.  We ended up getting the $88 set menu which included 2 lobsters (normally a lobster and a crab), chicken, spareribs, fish, etc.  There were 8 dishes in all plus chicken wing appetizers on the house!  Definitely a great place to go for cheap, but delicious Chinese food!
author: Elena N.

description:
Thank you Yelp, you never fail me even when I'm out of town. 

I was hungry and hiking through Chinatown. I already had this place bookmarked and my trusty Yelp app told me it was closeby. I looked at my map and looked around me, there were crowds of tourists walking by me and cars crawling by...and it took me a good three minutes to figure out the entrance to Hong Kong Clay Pot was about 5 feet behind me. The entrance is that small and when you climb the narrow stairway up a flight you arrive at a hunble mom an pop establishment with some pretty awesome food.

Try the honey walnut prawns. It's not too sweet and overdone like that PF Changs crap.

Be adventurous and get a clay pot dish. I had the duck it was pretty tasty. 

Maybe I was thirsty but the hot tea was great.
author: Monica N.

description:
Ask for white or steamed tofu instead of braised tofu when you get any of the clay pot dishes. It's "healthier" and that tofu is just so much better.

The snow pea sprouts with garlic is delicious!!!

The ginger & green onion crab is AMAZING. Why spend $50 on a flavorless dungeness from Thanh Long when you can just come here and get a well-seasoned, hearty crab dish for about $20-25 (seasonal).

The servers are all extremely friendly, and the demo for this place is a really good mix of tourists & locals
author: Joshua L.

description: The Duck Clay Pot was a bit low on duck meat and a bit too oily for all those who are cholesterol conscious. However, the Veggie and Fish options were very flavorful and were a hit with me and my friends. Afterwards, go to the pretty famous egg tart bakery, aka Golden Gate Bakery, that's a 1 minute walk away.
author: Shelley C.

description: Best Chinese food I've ever had!  Fresh potstickers. They were thicker than I'm used to which i like and the sauce was perfect for it. Sweet and spicy. The Kung pao chicken was the prefect amount of spicy and the meat was tender. The mongolian beef with prawns was also very good.  Fairly large portions. I would highly recommend eating here.
author: Joshua S.

description: We clearly completed the order form. We waited and waited but half our order never came. Our waiter didn't place half of our order and then acted like it was our fault.
author: Patricia A.

description: We had guests come in to town that wanted to visit the historic region of Chinatown. I sure made the wrong choice with this place. Service was so bad i was embarrassed. We were 1 of 4 tables and I still had to flag down the server...for everything even remotely reasonable of expectation. My advice for folks, if you need the experience of Chinatown and don't care that you're treated like a cattle car tourist, just be patient.
author: Jason P.

description:
I love this place!  I come here with my coworkers for lunch sometimes and we always call in ahead of time for them to have our food ready.  I love their seafood tofu clay pot, salt and pepper spareribs, on choy, and clams with black bean sauce!  My coworkers made me try frog legs here, and I really didn't enjoy them.  They were so boney, meatless, and the image of a frog just grosses me out.  Aside from that, I always have a great meal here.  They give you complimentary soup with your meal even during lunch.  For dinner they give you desert!

I took off a star because this place can improve on the interior.  It is a bit outdated, and the carpet looks old.  Aside from that, this place is defiantly worth it.  Its cheap,  delicious, and the portions are big.
author: Lynn L.

description:
True hole in the wall place that gives you authentic Cantonese food. You of course need to have the clay plot dishes -- I highly recommend the lamb one as well as the tofu one. The house special fried rice is basically yang chow fan and is quite delicious as well. They give you free soup and dessert which make the whole experience that much better. The potstickers are only okay but can hit the spot if you are dying for some.

Come early cause it does get crowded.
author: Victor W.

description: Good stuff, not cookie-cutter preparation and a very enjoyable meal. Delivery was reasonably prompt and packed courteously.
author: Erick T.

description:
This place has a tiny little entrance with stairs that lead up to the small restaurant. I thought it would be a lot bigger but instead, I walked up to what seemed like the size of a coffee shop. 

We arrived shortly after they opened for dinner and the place was full already. The waitress refused to give the 4 of us a bigger table and made us wait till a 4 seat table was available even though there were 2 bigger tables available already. We watched as other people who came in after us waltzed right into the seats at bigger tables. There was a family of 3 sitting at the bigger tables anyway. 

The service was subpar being that it was way understaffed. There were only 3-4 older women in their late 40s working there. We were sitting in front of the entrance and at one point, a family came in and stood there for 10 minutes before they were even acknowledged. Our waitress was the manager of the restaurant and she seemed a bit impatient while we ordered. She took 10 minutes to give us our check later on. 

The food was mediocre. The beef stew clay pot was a disappointment since it was mostly filled with tofu instead of actual beef. The beef was dry and tasteless.The sweet and sour chicken was hard and the vegetables we ordered were old. 

The place just felt filthy and rundown. The noise level in there was so high. The waitresses would shout across the room. 

There are plenty of other great restaurants to try out in Chinatown since this place does not live up to the hype. I will not be returning to this place when I'm in town.

I gave them an extra star because the waitresses were running around nonstop as they tried to attend to everyone's needs.
author: Janice W.

description: My wife and I were looking for the ambiance of Chinatown and good Chinese food. We found that perfect restaurant. Upon ascending the stairs the hostess welcomed us by providing immediate seating. We were served a pot of tea at once. Then we studied the many varieties in the well worn menus which indicated that most of the prices had remained unchanged for some time. We eventually chose two delicious seafood items, with the spring egg rolls for an appetizer.  What a wonderful lunch for a price under $40. We highly recommend this restaurant.
author: Bill M.

description: I have been there many times, and I am never disappointed. The seafood claypot is full of flavors, and the portions are humongous. Just don't order the combo, for some reason, the dishes are not as good as the individual dishes.
author: Kinder H.

description:
In the heart of touristic Chinatown. The dishes are solid, not amazing. If you're a tourist and want some Chinese food go here, they have all the classic Chinese American dishes you love so much like sweet and sour pork, spring rolls and noodles. 

The ladies that work there are very nice and accommodating. 

We did get one really bad dish, the sweet and sour soup. It was super watery to the point that it was just like drinking water. You can tell they tried to put a lot of hot sauce in to make it have some dimension but  hot (spicy) water was all you got. Do not order this.
author: Marissa C.

description: Cheap and good hole in the wall Chinese food in Chinatown. If you are not really looking you will miss it. Came for dinner and there was a line out the door and down the stairs. Had the salt and pepper shrimp, seafood clay pot, chicken pan friend noddles and cashew chicken.
author: Rick E.

description: I had spring rolls and Singapore style noodles.   Both were excellent.  Servings were much larger than I expected so I only ate half my meal.
author: Ken C.

description:
Boy, I am beyond disappointed!  I heard a rumor there was a change in ownership and possibly the cooks...didn't want to believe it but our recent dinner here was pathetic.

I guess they don't give out free soup anymore, that's one plus I looked forward to...it's nothing fancy but something comforting, gone.

What we ordered - note that everything was greasy and the portion has gone down.

steamed large clam w/ silver noodles - not sure it was fresh.

sauteed pea sprouts - it was ok, they didn't really remove the older parts

tender green w/ beef - very small portion with large bok choy and just a few pieces of beef - this is ridiculous

ginger scallion lobster - I love lobster but I stopped w/ 2 pieces.  

This is such a disaster that I don't know when/if I will return...
author: Gloria H.

description:
Tried a variety of foods  . Overall food was OK 

the quail and chicken wings  i noticed was too fried . The meat was dry and felt like it was under a food lamp for while.

Catfish with black bean sauce was great, Good flavor, wasn't too oily.

Mongolian beef with shrimp was good
author: Michael T.

description: we ordered 6 dishes between the two of us.  The jellyfish was delicious.  So were the XO beef, seafood lo mein, the steamed fish, and gosh, I can't even remember, they were all good.  I highly recommend getting the seafood lo mein, that's the shibboleth of a great cantonese restaurant, if they can do this well, then everything else ought to be pretty damn good.  The portions weren't small either so it was hard getting out the door.  The menu is pretty seasonal but the lo mein is quite memorable, I definitely would go back just for this.  I know the restaurant must be famous for its claypots duh but...we didn't pay attention.  Trust me when I say that I'm a huge snob when it comes to chinese food and this has got to be the best cantonese food (the best kind of chinese food there is obvious) I've ever had.
author: Tina L.

description: We decided on this restaurant based on great Yelp reviews. It was very tucked away, keep an eye out for their address on their door as the restaurant is above a store. There are probably a dozen family size tables that seat 8 ish with a lazy Susan's on the tables to share entrees. Big windows that look down onto Grant Ave. The menu has a hundred choices all easy common Chinese dishes the kids could pick for themselves. A dozen soups to choose from too! The server was very helpful, attentive and polite. Which was much appreciated with our large family. The place was kept very clean and the food was served SUPER QUICK AND HOT!
author: Heather D.

description:
Clean, friendly, and authentic enough. Easy-to-read, diverse menu. My braised tofu was the winner in my group of five. Order a side of rice with it and be aware: it's super tasty but not healthy (some may find it greasy). 

Chicken fried rice lacked meat; go for something more adventurous. Soups were out of control! One order is easily enough to share with 3-4 people as an appetizer. 

Not a traditional dim-sum spot.

Bottom Line: Good (safe) choice for lunch in Chinatown.
author: Tal T.

description: Pretty good. Very popular restaurant. Food was decent but not amazing.
author: Danny L.

description:
First, I gotta say that some of the other reviews for this place are awesome and way more entertaining than mine.  The Panda Express fans, the guy who hates Dogs,  Epic.  Go read those instead of my drivel.

I liked the ox tail* pot and the fried cod quite a lot.  Oh and the hot & sour soup was both!  The atmosphere is great, and the service is "classic".   Good legit place, I'm going back.

* - I'm not sure why restaurants call it "ox tail".  Technically, an ox is just a cow trained to pull things like wagons and plows.  It doesn't seem very likely that anyone trains beef cows to pull things just to turn around and make clay pot dishes out of them.
author: Jared L.

description:
Great service, great food (and I'm not even fond of Chinese food), and the staff was friendly. The place was empty when we arrived and within 20-30min it was completely full. 

There aren't many tables, maybe 8?? But it was no problem at all. The check was kinda confusing, didn't quite add up but I think it was only off like $3-5 so it wasn't that big of a deal to us! 

Would definitely go back again.
author: James S.

description: Food was ok but in very small serving. Quick service.  $1.25 for a bowl of rice per person.  Must be a San Francisco thing. Each dish was about $10.  I will have to try another Chinese restaurants when I am in San Francisco again. It would be a sin not to.  There are so many restaurants here in Chinatown.  So many Chinese bakeries.  We use Uber and Lyft several time.  There plenty of them here.  Another great way to see the city is to rent a bike for $17 a day plus $4 for insurance.
author: Fat B.

description: Great place. Great atmosphere. Very family friendly. The food was delicious. Great service. Waitress seemed annoyed with us, we were a large family that was not exceptionally quiet. However. That did not interfere with the exceptional service. We had the seafood, vegetable and chicken clay pot. I definitely recommend this place for an authentic Chinese meal.
author: Michelle B.

description: This place looks like a small hole in the wall, but it produces great authentic Chinese food. We had the Napa cabbage w/ shrimp, seafood chow mein, spring rolls, wonton soup, egg flower soup, and lobster with egg noodles. Everything was fresh and tasty. The servers were polite and attentive. I would definitely recommend this place and return for more food when visiting Chinatown SF.
author: Sorrel G.

description:
This is a no-frills kinda' place. If you're looking for a fancy experience--don't come here. But if you're looking for great food and warm service, come here. 

We had the Kung Pao Chicken, the BBQ Pork Fried Rice, and the Wonton Soup. Everything was delicious. We also especially liked that we received complimentary tea upon arrival. I believe it was Jasmine tea... it was so delicious (and that says a lot since I'm not a big tea drinker). The Wonton Soup was great! 

I'm a tourist and this restaurant was not a touristy spot... and I liked that.
author: Patty G.

description: This place was AMAZING!!! Yes it's very much a hole in the world but who cares if your eating GREAT Dim Sum!  The prices was extremely reasonable. My husband, son & I had a ton of food. My husband and I both had two beers bill came to $40 with a 20% tip. We will definitely be back when we visit San Francisco again.
author: Christine J.

description:
Yum. Yum x 1000. 

I came here on a whim with a friend on a random Tuesday night. The restaurant is located in the heart of Chinatown and you have to walk up a flight of shifty stairs to get to there. Open arriving at the front of the restaurant, we saw a mini sea (so like, a lake) of Asian people eating dinner. One white couple. So I knew we had hit the authentic Chinese hot spot for food. 

We ordered a fish and tofu clay pot which was GREAT. So yummy and extremely filling. The portion was also gigantic. 

Since the person I was with was a little more "white" than me, we ordered BBQ fried rice and hot and sour soup - both which were above par for Americanized Chinese food. 

The service and ambiance were mehhh. In fact, the table was pretty gross when we got there and was only wiped down by another dirty rag. But what do you expect in a Chinatown restaurant? The waitress was normal - not rude, not super friendly... but she was actually friendlier than most chinese restaurants I've gone to. She did say they preferred cash but took 2 credit cards with no complaints. 

BTW, anyone complaining about the prices.. get real. Seriously. How is 8 dollars too expensive for a crap ton of food? I know it's Chinese food and it CAN be like 5-6 bucks but really, it's not that much. 

I know this restaurant passed the test for me because I would be willing to bring my super Chinese, super judge-y parents here for dinner. That's the true testament to a good, authentic, chinese restaurant.
author: Carmen K.

description:
I got the seafood claypot and the salt and pepper pork chop. It was ok. The staff was friendly and the food was ok. The seafood claypot was pretty good and came with an assortment of good seafood. The salt and pepper pork chop wasn't very salty or peppery. It was just kind of a greasy pork chop with a lot of fat on it.

Hole in the wall place that probably has some regulars. Seems like a good family diner.
author: Ryan L.

description:
I would definitely recommend any of their clay pot dishes. Basically, we ordered a bunch of dishes and we found that the clay pot quail was the best of the lot. 

The place is generally noisy and had a rich delicious smell around. 

It is a little hard to find, keep your eyes peeled. It is on the first floor.
author: Rohit M.

description:
I found Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant on yelp and made a reservation for a large group and was happy to find it was as I expected/hoped! This place is legit! 

For how difficult a group we were (some members were unfamiliar with authentic Chinese restaurants) they were absolute saints! 

The food was delicious (the duck in claypot was divine!), the menu was diverse and enticing, the jasmine tea was spot on, the prices were right, the service was very accommodating, and the atmosphere was genuine! Having been to Hong Kong, it was the first time in America I have encountered a Hong Kong restaurant that I feel truly represents restaurants in Hong Kong! 

Please bear in mind this place is authentic, and in Chinatown, so the service, food preparation, overall style etc. may not be as expected in the States - this restaurant is not for everyone. I also think we, a group of over a dozen people, were a bit overwhelming for them. I would only go there with a smaller group of people who are respectful and open to the fact you are going to a traditional HK restaurant.
author: Katelin E.

description: This restaurant is kind of hidden on the 2nd floor, we orders different dishes, 2 orders of chow main, beef broccoli , Mongolian chicken, cung pow chicken, shrimp fried rice... comes with green tea already no additional charge and 2 cokes grand total of $61 for 4 people and still let over, loved the flavor and the color and texture of the dishes...
author: Yessenia J.

description: Really good, authentic-feel Chinese food in Chinatown. If you're looking for tourist trap, cliché-filled menu, go elsewhere. The lazy Susan on the bigger tables was great for family style - we had a party of 8 (including 4 food-shy kids) and everyone shared everything. The potstickers were particularly tasty. Ambiance is very mom-and-pop, really good.
author: Ryan S.

description: Wanted some not-too greasy but authentic Chinese food and this was it. Came around 5:30 to an empty store but it packed quickly. Very sweet host who graciously recommended the frog clay pot when we asked for something authentic. Also had the abalone and chicken clay pot. Generous portions of meat and abalone and mushrooms. Great experience overall
author: Joon B.

description:
We arrived at the Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant at about 12:30 PM on a weekday and it was packed, so I recommend stopping by after 1:30 PM, which is when the place began to empty out.

We ordered the Honey Walnut Prawns, Sweet and Sour Chicken, Pot Stickers, Chow Mein with Pork, and white rice. The prawns were very good, but my only disappointment regarding this dish was that I was expecting bigger sized prawns. The dish consisted of deliciously glazed prawns, with little walnut pieces scattered neatly around them on the plate. Very yum. The pot stickers came with a VERY delicious dipping sauce that had the perfect kick of spiciness, yet not too hot, which made it perfect for people like me who don't like super-spicy foods. It hinted slightly of tamarind, with a bit of other delicious ingredients. The sweet and sour chicken was pretty ordinary, nothing super-exciting. I enjoyed the chow mein's clean flavor, a huge difference from typical places such as Panda Express, which saturate their chow mein in oil, thus losing it's flavor.

  
In sum, I would say the food was pretty good.
author: Sonya M.

description:
King size roach?

The worst part was seeing a roach bigger then a 50 cent (not kidding) crawl on the ceiling with waitress swatting it down with a child booster chair was alarming to think how clean the kitchen makes me not want to think about it.  The funny part was watching the young American girls eyes bug out as roach could have fallen on one of them.

Ordered the clay pot chicken with mushrooms and Chinese sausage was tasty as long you don't look at the bottom with 1/2 inch of grease clay pot.

The pawns with walnut was boring and kinda small with not much flavor. Pot sticker taste like it came out of a frozen bag and definitely not fresh made.  Food is average and nothing special.
author: Rocky S.

description:
I came down here for lunch on a Friday on the first week after New Year. It's full of people here. Luckily we got seated right away. 

My coworker and I shared two dishes (scrambled eggs with prawns and chicken tofu claypot). Both dishes taste great although the eggs are quite oily. I'm slightly disappointed they don't serve claypot rice dishes here. Note the claypot dish takes a while to cook. 

It's a generous portion for the price you paid (of course we're in Chinatown). Their lunch menu is less than $5 (WOW). They definitely use MSG here, but you can tell them not to add it in your food.
author: Saran R.

description: Great food and service. We ordered the house fried rice and mongolian beef and it was great; however, the rice could have used a bit more flavor. This restaurant is a great place for a casual dinner or lunch--not super fancy. Seating is communal so if you prefer your own table, this may not be the place for you.
author: Kristin S.

description: Very authentic feel. The seating is half family style so if you are a party of 2, you will possibly sit with another party at a round style table. The food was very good. Good pricing.
author: Lani B.

description:
I read the reviews about the cheap lobster and had to try it out. I mean, who doesnt love cheap cantonese style lobster? I can eat 5 of them in one seating like some sort of savage. 

The service was a bit slow but I finally got the waitresses attention and ordered my lobster. Unfortunately it came out a bit undercooked and was not enjoyable. However, reheating the lobster next day the flavor was good and delicious..it would have been great to enjoy that at the restaurant itself.

Overall, if you're in the area, spend the extra $$ and go to RG or Great Eastern... otherwise, this is a good poor mans option
author: B H.

description: I am a fan for this place. Best buck for your bank! It's a hole on the wall in Chinatown and the food tastes as good as it is in China. All of the clay pots are soo yummy and get some green veggie. You are all set for dinner!
author: Jessica Y.

description: First time in San Francisco and we wanted to try what Chinatown can offer.  This place is very good and didn't disappoint at all.  Food is great and affordable. We did the set menu and it's money well spent.
author: Jeff P.

description: We're from Boston and Atlanta.  Yelp again came through with this excellent choice in Chinatown.  Oxtail Clay Pot and Shrimp with Vermicelli  Clay Pot were excellent.  Full house on a Monday night.  Excellent choice Yelp!
author: Joann C.

description: Initially thought it was a fantastic find.  Then we found a cigarette butt in our take out food.  We were the only anglo/Americans in there.  Obviously we were not welcome.
author: Mike G.

description: Had a wonderful lunch. The food was amazing. We had the Sweet n Sour Chicken, combination fried rice. Honey Walnuts Prawns were perfect. The service was very good too. We defiantly would go back.
author: Mark C.

description: Delicious. Hole in the wall, you can tell it was authentic food because most of the people in there were actually Chinese. We got the sweet and sour pork, sweet and sour chicken, and pot stickers. Everything was delicious. Good price too.
author: J L.

description: Very cool place. I really felt like I was in China. The food was fantastic and my girlfriend and I were the only people that were not Chinese or Chinese-American. Looking around and watching everyone was really cool. Great place to eat. It's a hidden place. The restaurant sign is in Chinese writing, so you have to ask around. Definitely recommend this place.
author: Dave G.

description: Went here last night and had a few recommendations from yelp reviewers. It was not good at all. The worst honey walnut I've ever tasted not sweet at all. Terrible Chicken dish not any flavor and I'm easy to please.Wasn't that cheap would not recommend
author: helene e.

description: Food is excellent.  Servers are friendly.  Too bad the restaurant is small and doesn't have AC.
author: Willie L.

description: So glad we found this place! Food was wonderful and servers were friendly and attentive. I would definitely recommend!
author: Katie F.

description: Don't expect to find 'pochaifan' or claypot rice here! Dishes are served in pots not cooked in them. But the food is good enough as the sauces for each dish is quite distinct. We enjoyed the cauliflower bacon, 3  claypots: eggplant w. chicken & salt fish, catfish was too bony; froglegs cut top small.. The quail w. salt & pepper was a disappointment. Service untrainted. But v popular.
author: Chuanfang L.

description:
Among the worst Chinese food I've ever had. Lousy service. 

I was a bit shocked at how unfriendly the service was. Quite strange that our potsticker appetizer came out third, and the order of each item came out totally randomly. 

As a sweet & sour pork enthusiast, I was incredibly disappointed. I know there is better food in Chinatown. I just know it.

Yelpers failed me today, which is crazy. It doesn't happen often.
author: Dan P.

description: Good quality restaurant, food comes in a reasonable time. The location isn't ideal, as you have to step up a ramp of stairs only to see the dining room. Quite affordable, they accept credit cards (big plus compared to other restaurants in China Town)
author: Antonio C.

description:
Had the beef chow fun, walnut prawns and beef tendon stew with my mum. 

The chow fun wasn't all that great -- the noodles clumped together too much and the beef was a bit chewy. I would characterize it as below average. 

The beef tendon stew was a big disappointment. The beef was so tough and chewy, I had to actually spit it out after 2 minutes of fruitless chewing. The sauce was good though and the tofu was silky on the inside and still held its shape well.

The walnut prawns were the best of the bunch. The shrimp were a bit soggy, but compared to some other places that over battered the critters, it could be worse. There were plenty of honey walnuts on the plate so the crunchiness of the nuts made up for the sogginess of the shrimp and added texture.

All in all, the food was average to below average. The place was packed though. I believe the restaurant is known more for its more exotic seafood. I saw some delicious things on other people's tables. Maybe I'll come back with more people and we can order some other dishes.
author: Alice W.

description: We ate here, family style meal, with our daughter and son-in-law.  We also had a 10-month-old with us.  The food was good and so was service.  You can choose several entrees to share plus rice and soup.  Portions were large, food wasn't amazing but very good and prices WERE very good for San Francisco.
author: Marilyn C.

description:
Definitely a four star for dirty cheap food. 

Tried their clay pot lamb, tasty and tender lamb chunks with skin, made just the way it should be. Shrimp paste potato leaves is also done very nicely, only a little on the oily side. 

A nice gem in Chinatown. It is on the second floor and the entrance is kind of obscure. 

Thanks fellow helpers for leading me here.
author: Jeff C.

description:
Have you ever eaten authentic & good Chinese food while watching a man shave his face? Thanks to this restaurant, I can say I have!

(Don't worry, the guy didn't have food on his table when he whipped out his razor and this wont deter me from coming back).

I found this hole in the wall thanks to Yelp. We ordered several dishes, which were each pretty good, but what really stood out to me was:

1) Honey Walnut Shrimp: same great flavor as other places, but without being drenched in the mayonnaise sauce. Possibly one of the best HWS I've ever had!

2) Congee: I normally loathe congee because it reminds me of the days when I was sick and this would be all my mom would allow me to eat, but this was actually really good! The consistency was perfect and it wasn't overly watery. Make sure you sprinkle in pepper!
author: Emily C.

description:
In the middle of tourist central but the food and prices are good enough for locals to eat. I recommend eating the set menus since have the most food for the buck. 

The place is not the cleanest, much like anything on Grant, especially the restrooms.
author: M C.

description: We waited for over an hour for our food, which was bland at best. The staff is rude and even getting some water seemed like an unreasonable demand. TOURIST TRAP. Stay away!
author: Maya A.

description: Food was very authentic, fast service and delicious! Very good prices, will definitely come here again. Prices were outrageously low for such good food. Very pleased!
author: Erica G.

description:
...no clue why this place has such high ratings.

We were looking for Chinese food on a Thursday night... stopped by R&G Seafood and wow long wait even at 8pm! Ended up picking this place as one of the next highly rated Chinese restaurants. 

This place is NOT authentic, I've definitely had better. We ordered honey walnut prawns which had chunks of mayonnaise on it... not to mention there's like 13 shrimps in the dish. Sweet and sour pork was just drowned in sauce... and onions were overused. Mushroom and sausage claypot was ridiculous... there were more onions than anything else, the flavor was again completely drowned out with onions. Deep fried rock cod had more batter than fish... it came out and I thought it was like frog legs or something... you couldn't even tell it was fish from the shape, let alone the texture. Lastly portion sizes were very meh... looking around other people's food looked good / decently sized, so maybe we ordered the wrong items, but I was very unimpressed... especially given the good ratings and this being in Chinatown.
author: Debbie L.

description: A nice find in Chinatown. Service was initially a little slow, but once we ordered, the food came out quickly. Would recommend the potstickers and the hot and sour soup, and if you're vegetarian, the tofu clay pot was delicious
author: Emily H.

description: You typical tradition Cantonese Chinese restaurant, this is the joint that all the locals went to eat when they grew up here. The food is excellent, but not the best I have ever had. There is always someone better out there. The food was good and EXTREMELY reasonably priced, a fresh live Dungeness Crab is only $20, which other restaurants on Pier 39 would easily charge $40 for. We had a feast of 3 for only $80, we could barely get up and walk after we ate all of the food. The duck tongue was an awesome appetizer, step out of your comfort zone and try something new and it might surprise you. The Braised Pork Belly was amazing beyond world, the pork belly just melts in your mouth. The clay pot beef is so flavorful, mixed in with vegetables, tofu and spices. I wasn't too sure about the black bean calms, but they were still good. You can't go wrong eating at Hong Kong, however, but willing to wait for a table, it might be awhile because it's a small restaurant.
author: Peter H.

description: Very good food and service. We had the delux menu with 5 dishes for only 13 $ per person.
author: Fredrik K.

description:
(In case any of you were wondering, I haven't fallen off the face of the earth; I've just been working like a good little monkey, and by the time I get home, I have no desire to open my laptop and stare at another screen.  Thanks for continuing to read!)

Boyfriend and I came across Hong Kong Clay Pot when I got out from a facial at Tru Spa around 8.  My first choice for a restaurant, San Sun, was already closed, so I looked on Yelp for a restaurant that was still open, and HKCP popped up.  I worked in Chinatown for more than a year, but I had no idea this place existed, even though I've walked down this street a thousand or so times.

The reason:  There's very little signage, and you have to walk up a flight of sketch-ball stairs in order to get to the actual restaurant.

As we walked up, I heard a lot of Cantonese going back and forth, and when I finally surfaced at the top of the steps, holy moly, ALL THESE CHINESE PEOPLE ERRWHERE.  Very authentic, it's a good sign.  This is clearly a family-style restaurant, as most of the tables are round and meant for at least 6 people.

They have soups, noodle and rice dishes, veggies, seafood, meats (including frog), and dishes clearly catered towards tourists (Mongolian beef, kung pao chicken, etc.).

Boyfriend ordered the honey walnut shrimp (OMG BEST ONE I'VE EVER EATEN), and I opted for the oxtail clay pot so I could compare it with R&G Lounge's.  I might have to say that I enjoyed R&G's better, as that one came with large chunks of daikon and you really can't beat the delicious gravy they have, but this one is a close second.  I liked the braised tofu and the flavor, but it didn't taste as hearty and rich as the other one.

Our total came out to $22 before tip.  They take credit cards!  The only negative was the service; they were severely understaffed for so many large parties, and we had to flag them down to get menus, get our order taken, and get our check.

Definitely will be returning to order the honey walnut prawns all for myself.
author: Tori S.

description: After the Eat Real Festival and a trip to the Golden Gate Fortune Cookie Factory, we were famished.  Calvin N. yelped nearby places and suggested this place.  It was a high enough rating and most importantly, nearby.  Our group of 5 ordered the 5-course family of 4 dinner that was listed at $48.  There was no doubt the food was great, but the service wasn't very friendly at all.  It was difficult to get water or extra napkins.  Plus, they gave us attitude and wanted to charge us extra to substitute another dish that was cheaper.  When we got our bill, it says $65 (including tax) and we found out that we got charged for rice ($1.25/person).  We were not aware that rice was extra and our rude server neglected to tell us.  Either way, in short, it was good food but not-so-nice service.
author: Deana M.

description: Delicious and fast. We tried so many things on the menu and they were all yummy. You must splurge on the Honey Prawns. They are like dessert!
author: Michele K.

description: Best Chinese food I have ever had.  Definitely try their clay pot dishes.  Smoking hot! And stays hot.  Complimentary hot tea.  Down to the floor prices.  My kinda place.
author: Ancy V.

description:
GOOD: Hot and sour soup is excellent.  You could go here for that alone.

BAD: The seafood clay pot has too much fried tofu as filler, and the noodles were panda express-like. 

Still, the place was authentic. The service is slow, but the food is worth it.  We were the only caucasians around, except for the 20-somethings carrying their Lonely Planet.

Pretty cheap, too.
author: Carolina C.

description: The food was good.  I love the family style dinner.  Tea was bland and the broth for the wonton needed more seasoning. We shared five dishes and each one was great. I recommend eating here.
author: Tavis K.

description:
Absolutely outstanding. I hate Chinese food and was reluctant to try it until I saw the hole in the wall up the stairs place that was packed with Chinese people. I had authentic. I let the staff and some of the diners choose for me and I was BLOWN AWAY. 

Hot and sour soup like I've never had in my life! Awesome. 

Ox tail claypot. Off the charts.

Great price, great service, great atmosphere and great food.
author: Jeff D.

description:
That was great! The service was awesome and the food just delicious! We recommend the honey walnut prawn! They are sooooo amazing and the ginger lobster was terrific! We tried the duck tongue also but it was too strange and greasy for my french taste! 
The woman even run after us wen we forgot our leftovers.
author: Anais A.

description: It wasn't as good as I expected. The beef stew clay pot was mediocre. Also had the string beans with XO sauce. I was disappointed with the clay pot dish. Nothing special and flavor was odd. Not sure why others rated it so high. But perhaps it was an odd night. I might try it one more time.
author: Mariah P.

description:
This was my first time in SF Chinatown with my family. Coming from Panda Express territory, I was surprised and delighted by Hong Kong Clay Pot.

At first, the restaurant was difficult to find, until a man behind me poked out of a door, gave us a paper menu, and pointed the way up the stairs. The restaurant itself was not fancy, simply a small room overlooking Grant Street.

We underestimated the portion sizes and ordered individually. When the food came out, it was clear by the serving spoons and rotating table center that we were meant to share the food family-dinner style. So we did.

The food was very flavorful and mostly easy to pick up with chopsticks, save for the rice and broccoli stalks. I had never had Chinese food this authentic before, but the traditional dishes were surprisingly tasty, even for the picky kids. The free tea was also pretty decent, so I didn't have to order a drink.

Overall, in comparison to the fast food and take-out Chinese I've had previously, this was probably the best Chinese food I've ever had.
author: False K.

description: Lunch specials are cheap and delicious.  Great place to grab some quick food.  It can get pretty crowded sometimes in there,  there are a lot of tourist going in.  They have a huge selection of food and the waitress and waiters in the place are extremely nice even when they are all packed.  I usually order the clams and they always cook it the way I like.  Perfect place to go for some family dinners as well.
author: Danny C.

description: This restaurant is very deceiving from its outer appearance. The food was delicious and the prices were very inexpensive. The service was great. We ordered melon walnut shrimp, Kung pao chicken, beef chow mien, Chinese sausage clay pot and 2 beers and it came out to less than 50 bucks!!!  Can't beat it!
author: Franchesca S.

description:
It was a bit hard to find the restaurant because of the small entrance. Look for the blue canopy and a yellow sign. Don't let the entrance intimidate you! I walked up the stairs into a small, crowded restaurant full of local Chinese residents and tourists.The wait wasn't that long, however we had to wait long enough that a small line was created behind us. It might of just been a busy night. As we waited, I read the menu near the door. There was so much to choose from and it all looked amazing. I couldn't wait to sit down and finally eat!

I noticed on the menu they had jellyfish and this really interested me. I ordered this, and this was the first time I would ever eat jellyfish. It was surprisingly good. The texture took some time to get used to, but after a while, I started to really like it. We also ordered fried rice, quail, and a few other dishes. They were not at all greasy. No signs of using MSG. All in all, the food was very flavorful and authentic. I would recommend people coming here if they are visiting Chinatown. 

All the workers were friendly, but the service is slow. This didn't make me mad because that's expected in the heart of Chinatown. I truly recommend Hong Kong Clay Pot, and if i ever get a chance to come back and taste their delicious food one more time, I would without a doubt.
author: Emmanuella Z.

description:
12.09.07

Food       4 stars
Service   4 stars 

Straight and simple ... had lunch based on recommendation
Visited the place on lunch time.

Whenever you order lunch rice plate at a Chinese restaurant ....
       you get a plate of rice with the entree dumped on top ... simple as that.

However ... at this place ... cost depending on the item ordered ... $4.50 - $7.50 ...

       You get soup
       You get free rice
       You get entree ... all three separately!

        The portion is equal to many restaurants' single entree order!!! 
         They do not used too much filler ... bell pepper, onion ... you know what I
                   am talking about.
   
         Better yet ... the food taste above average!

          Cheap , big portion, and above average taste ... damn it just try it.

          Even my frugal Asian dining partners with discriminating taste agrees ...
                    good food at a damn unbelievable price!

           You don't get what u paid for at this place ... 

             YOU GET MORE THAN YOU PAID FOR ...

I WILL drop by more often and update this review!
author: S.K. Y.

description:
This place is AWESOME! I have ate here with my family and few of my ex-bf's!
The parking is NOT fun to find in China Town in SF CA. If you rent the Garger near by you better carry at LEASE $500.00 They will charger thought the noise some gargers! That no lie!
author: EdwardF A.

description: I will give a negative 5 stars if possible! Ordered a lobster and it looked more like a crawfish! Apparently, they treat tourists differently from the locals!
author: David F.

description:
Used to dine here quite a bit w/an old roommate as we had pretty much sampled everything on the menu as it's damn good & damn cheap

sizzling seafood being my favorite
author: Clark G.

description:
I don't really understand how this place is a top rated chinese restaurant in SF but I went here today for lunch and went away with question marks. It wasn't horrible by any means, but it was so mediocre. We ordered four dishes : 2 clay pots, 1 veggie dish, and a seafood fried noodle. The beef claypot was the best of the bunch. 

Didn't like : the cornstarchy sauces on everything and the seafood fried noodle was more bokchoy than seafood. 

Liked: the waitress serving us was nice.
author: Antonia W.

description:
This place had highly questionable quality of ingredients and lacked flavor in the food served. 

We ordered the oxtail clay pot and the walnut shrimp. The clay pot did not have much oxtail. It seemed as if the restaurant had a universal clay pot base and just dumped different types of meats in it. The sauce of the clay pot definitely did not have the gooey richness of slow-cooked ox tail. The walnut shrimp was abysmal. It was over-battered, over-sugared, and over-cooked.

Overall terrible food and terrible ambiance. Given that it was right on Grant, I should have expected no better.
author: Julia W.

description:
This place was really good. Our table of 6 ordered various items from the menu that I don't even remember them all. BUT it was pretty eye opening for me because I tried a number of new items that are usually outside my "safety" zone. I always order Mongolian beef at any Chinese restaurant I go to. Of course this place was no exception. I love Mongolian beef and the beef here was very tasty and a good amount of spicy. It was really good even my fiance said it was his new favorite Mongolian beef. As I mentioned I did try some other items as well, and they too were good. I'm not yet comfortable with ordering anything other than mongolian beef yet, but it was definitely a good start as the food was still really good. 

I also have to make a side note about the location of this place. It is in Chinatown, but totally awesomely located. We were meeting some people here and had we not had an address, would have missed it. There is a little hall that has stairs leading up to the 2nd floor. It was kinda cool cause it felt like we were going to some back room poker game. 

Anyway, the food was good! Try this place if you can find it!
author: Lisa L.

description:
Situated in an upstairs dining room and reminiscent of your working class grandmother's home, this restaurant is what I'd truly call a serious hole in the wall. More like a drive-by induced hole in the wall, really. This restaurant is a seriously local spot that is so inconspicuous, even the locals may have a hard time finding it. Despite the occasional employee passing out menus at the front of the staircase, it is still easy to miss it amidst the chaotic sights and sounds of touristy Chinatown.

I, luckily, was able to get on it and find this mysterious place with high ratings on Yelp from locals and foodies alike. I must say that upon entering after hiking up a good set of 12 or so steps, I was surprised at the set up of the dining room. Everything is a little off, decorations a little wonky, but the warm and welcoming smells of cooking food is a comfort that is universal. 

The two of us were seated in a round table for 8 people. It was a little funny for two people but we felt like queens. They gave us a nice pot of tea, black, with real tea leaves. 

We ordered the seafood claypot and the braised beef claypot. The seafood claypot consists of shrimp, squid, fried and braised tofu, fish chunks, mushrooms and green onions in a savory gravy that is a little sweet and perfectly balanced. I really enjoyed the sauce a lot because it was gooey and flavorful. 

The braised beef claypot was a delight as well. The chunks of beef were tender, beefy and very yummy. There was mushrooms, braised tofu, veggies and green onions. The sauce was rich and beefy - precisely what the name of the claypot suggests. The only thing that I wish they added in there was daikon (Asian radish) to really oomph up the flavor and authenticity but otherwise it was still memorable. I took the rest of the beef claypot home and had it for leftovers the next day. It was even better!

I'd definitely come back next time I am in the city. Prices here are very reasonable and the food portions exceeded my expectations. All claypots are under $10.00 and one claypot can feed two hungry people. 

The service was also really good. The best is to pay in cash as you should anywhere in Chinatown.  After washing it all down with black tea, we came out of the restaurant in good spirits. Make sure you watch your steps as you take the stairs down. It's really not fun to trip and possibly die, not that it happened to me or anything.

Overall, highly recommended!
author: Jennifer N.

description: Enjoyed it greatly. Had crab / fish soup which was a little bland but zinged it up with some of the hot sauce. Chicken with pan fried noodles which were great. The seafood clay pot was also excellent.  The pot stickers were enormous. Definitely a Resturant the locals attend regularly.
author: Cliff M.

description: Came to this place after looking for a good chinese place to eat around chinatown San Francisco. The place and decor is typically for a chinese restaurant,  nothing fancy but ample space. We ordered two clay platters and they came out really quick and super hot. I would definitely come back to try the other food. I would have given 5 stars if they offer clay pot rice. Overall, food was delicious!
author: Sunny Kty W.

description: Two stars only because its Chinese food otherwise it would be one. Place was really dirty, tea cold and really Ron down. You could do a lot better at Hunan Home one block away!
author: Nors D.

description:
Yep -- hole-in-the-wall with sketchy stairs that lead to delicious Chinese food.

I don't have much to add, but has anyone noticed that items 91-96 aren't translated into English like everything else? I did, so I took a picture and sent it to my Chinese-born mother. Her translation:

91.  Steamed chicken wings with cloud ear (some kind of fungus)
92.  Steamed pork (belly with marble fat) with preserved vegetable
93.  Stir-fry pork (belly) with shrimp paste
94.  Boiled goose intestine
95.  Stir-fry goose intestine with XO sauce
96.  Stir-fry goose intestine with soy and plum sauce

...with the comment that they are "so authentic that even I wouldn't eat them."

My friend went back later and tried to order the goose intestine (by pointing at it), and was told "you don't want that." Having had my own run-ins with jellyfish tentacles and other authentic Chinese foods, I have to agree.
author: Tate S.

description: Yelp never fails me! Hong Kong Clay Pot (HKCP) exceeded my expectations -- the highlight was the catfish in clay pot -- huge chunks of ginger, browned garlic, shitake mushrooms, and big chunks of catfish all cooked together in a clay pot. The result was a salty, subtle mix of flavors (note: watch out for bones - the catfish has tons of small bones). We also ordered the honey walnut prawns, which I'd probably skip next time - they were tasty enough but they felt more like an appetizer than a main course (it is served without veggies).  If I were in SF again, I'd absolutely check out HKCP and try some of their other offerings.
author: Jennifer N.

description: What can I say, everything served in this restaurant is great!  This is a great hole in the wall authentic chinese food.  Brought me back to some good New York chinese food.  If your in town make sure its in your to do list!!
author: Stephen M.

description: The food was alright overall.  The Honey Walnut Prawns, pot stickers, and the spring rolls were great.  The Clay Pot Curry Chicken was good.  The service was so-so.  We had to ask three times for water, and twice for the check.  They also do not have Chinese Mustard, just French's.  Don't get me wrong, there is nothing wrong with French's, but at this place?
author: Joe B.

description:
Wow, great restaurant.  Being Chinese, I often find many Chinese restaurants to be rated highly but not too authentic.  But this one truly is if you are looking for great Cantonese cuisine.  The place was packed when we were there with a line snaking out the door.  Food comes out fast and hot.  Prices are very reasonable and serving sizes are pretty generous.

Taste was outstanding, ingredients very fresh, and overall meal fantastic.  Service was great (for Chinese restaurant standards - though we spoke in Chinese to them) and very fast.  Not the cleanest restaurant in the world, but if you're looking for great food at good prices this is the place to go to in Chinatown.
author: Andrew Y.

description:
Decent Chinese restaurant. Fast service, pretty clean inside. We had pea sprouts (avg), honey walnut prawns (above avg), and a clay pot (good).

Overheard young attractive couple with two kids in tow: 

Husband: Should we have sex today or tomorrow?
Wife: Tomorrow. I'm tired.


Fair enough.
author: Erika C.

description: Ok we came for crab, and they were out of crab.   So we had the dumplings and the salt and pepper shrimp ( no skin and no head)   and it was great
author: Gregory W.

description:
Pros: 1) Delicious Tofu Clay Pot with Tender Greens and mushrooms! Very robust & flavorful; 2) Generous portion! 3) Moderate prices. Dish was $6.50, side rice, $1.25; 4) Fast service!

Cons: 1) MSG, food had a healthy dose of it; if you're sensitive to it like I am, this is a factor to consider; 2) Tea was served luke warm; blech!! Asked for 2nd pot, which was hot. 3) rice tasted like it'd been sitting out a bit too long. 4) Place could use a good cleaning. 5) Service with a smile would be nice.

Bottom line: Pros were strong enough to make me want to come back!
Food: 4 stars
Speed of Service: 5 stars
Friendliness of Service: 2 stars
Atmosphere: 2 stars
Cleanliness: 1.75 stars
author: Danny L.

description: OMG, the food at this place is amazing! Quality, quantity and price are on point! If you don't know what to pick from the menu I really REALLY recommend the chicken curry plate, and to be honest I think one plate is more than enough for 2 people. The only downside is the service, if it wasn't for that I'd give it 5 stars because the food flavor really blew my mind
author: Vanessa M.

description:
This is a restaurant straight out of a movie featuring Chinatown.  From the guy in the wife beater shirt smoking a non-filtered cigarette sitting on a chair telling me "Very good, you try, food good!" to the scary as hell entrance from the street up a flight of steep dirty steps to the clanging of dishes and very loud chatter from the grimy customers looking like the prototypical "chinatown" local from a movie set.  

My wife was yelping as we were walking down Chinatown with 2 kids (5 and 9) in tow.  Needless to say, it was getting dark, cold, and we just completed an 8 hour drive so hungry doesn't describe our feeling.  After a few reviews we found this Hole In the Wall restaurant was only half a block from us.  There were 300+ 4 star yelp reviews so in we went.

Okay, we were dressed for a 4 star-5 star restaurant so out of place doesn't even begin to describe our reception.  Continuing the movie theme, we stuck out like a sore thumb and all conversation, motion, and serving stopped when we entered only to resume about 3 seconds later.  On a clean scale from 1-4 stars I'd give it a 1.5 star (generous).  Screw it, we're here and I put my faith in yelp...

Ordered a beer because the water was from the sink next to us, forced the kids to drink hot tea, and asked for straws even for the beer.  Next ordered the "Clay Pot" Chicken and Tofu, Honey Walnut Prawns/Shrimp, and Hong Kong Style Beef Fried Rice.  I didn't want to order too much as we were sitting only half way in our chairs in case we had to bolt.  

Food is cooked one at a time by a single chef who is also the dishwasher and server at times.  The glasses were filthy, the plates weren't that clean, and I felt like Jackie Chan and Chris Tucker were about to bust thru the door at any time.

The food was actually pretty good.  The Clay Pot of Chicken and Tofu was cooked to perfection and had a "gravy" texture to it.  Very good.  Honey Walnut Prawns were good but pretty typical, and the HK Beef Fried Rice was good.
author: David R.

description:
I liked it a lot. 

I saw the Yelp review and had to go there. It was good
author: Phillip N.

description:
I LOVE this place. The shrimp dishes (tried both honey walnut and salt and pepper) were okay, but their clay pots are so authentic, so amazing, and so reminds me of traditional chinese clay pots. I loved the beef stew and seafood, and especially loved the slices of tofu they threw in there.  Prices are reasonable, and staff can be hit or miss depending on how busy they are.

Really want to give this place a 4.5 instead of 5.
author: Julie C.

description: Chinatown is always my favorite area to go when I'm craving legit asian food, and never go expecting amazing customer service or a beautiful interior. I came across this place and read about their Salt and pepper crab. I was a little disappointed when I found out that the price had raised from $16 to $19.
