It was a bit too salty for my liking yet I ended up taking it home and eating it the next day and it was just right. Nothing too special or horrible about this place. Knowing that I have other favorites in the area, not sure if i'd come back.
author: Jasmine M.

description: Enjoyed this place a lot. It was hot, but great food, reasonable price, and authentic China town feel. Plus it's close to a big public parking garage ($4/hr).
author: Malcolm G.

description:
Visited San Francisco and did some of the tourist things with the family and came to China Town. 

Walking Around, we all were soon in the mood for some authentic Chinese food. 
Not knowing which place to go. We stumble across a performer on the sidewalk, handing out flyers for this place. "Hong Kong Clay Pot".  We come inside and immediately come up stairs. It was pretty empty, but nice and quiet, which is always nice in a restaurant I think. 

I ordered the Chicken Chow Mein w Won Ton soup and my cousin orders the Kung Pao Chicken.

Chicken chow mein is pretty good, definitely not bad. Soup was good.  

Kung Pao Chicken is really good.  Good Spicy Flavor. 

All in all it is simple chinese food.  This food is fresh and  pretty cheap, atmosphere was lacking, which may or may not be a plus for you.  Service was good. I would recommend the Kung Pao chicken and will definitely come again to try some better options. 

Overall, I will definitely come back again when I am in the Chinatown area. The food is cheap, simple, and good.
author: Rich T.

description: We ordered the family combo meal for 4 which serves about 4-8 people. It was definitely a lot of food!  Was there on a Saturday night around 8:30 and they were packed!  The food was awesome its authentic home made food!  Also this place is hot! You don't want to be cozy here!  :) You have to wait in a queue and when tables are open the waitress will come out to ask for who's next.  This restaurant is upstairs, just look out for the signs outside!
author: Kevin Z.

description:
The service was mediocre at best (the waitress spilled most of my tea all over the table and I had to make it a point to ask for a second napkin to clean it up myself).

Having recently moved to SF I certainly hope there are better choices.  The prices are reasonable but the food quality is below similar restaurants in Manhattan's chinatown.  Our tofu clay pot was bland and the shrimp with walnuts was edible but not at all enticing.  The pot stickers were tasty and the dipping sauce was delicious, but who messes up potstickers?

The menu still lists shark fin soup, which is abhorrent.  Pass.
author: Scott M.

description:
Service was rude. Food was very average--nothing you can't get from a hole in the kitchen place.

I ordered beef broccoli and got beef with bamboo, water chest nuts, and ginger. I also ordered kung pao chicken and got szechuan chicken. I don't know why they have menus. I should have just stuck my head in the kitchen and say, "Hey, I'm here to eat. Cook me whatever you feel like..."
author: Suzi P.

description: Decent food, a little greasy, dirty floor, Christmas decorations still up, but friendly service and DELICIOUS potstickers.
author: A M.

description:
omg for Hunan chicken............

one thumb up for ginger crab......another thumb up for the price....
ate one whole crab by myself!
author: Rina C.

description:
After reading the poor reviews, I had to ask: "Who in the world comes to a Cantonese restaurant and orders lamb?" I was raised in Singapore and Saigon the first 12 years of my life, with frequent trips to Hong Kong, and though HK Clay Pot is not as good as it used to be when Bill owned it back in the 1990s and early 2000, (he moved back to Hong Kong when the City tax structures got crazy on restaurants): I would have given this place a full 5 stars if he was still in charge. And the who knows which chef is working the night you come in. If it's the good one, hallelujah! If not, well, just order the pot-stickers.

Stay the hell away from the lamb: what are you thinkin' if you think you know real Canto food??? You got problems with oil? It's friggen Cantonse cooking, people!

Stay away from that Central China and Muslim Chinese main entree of lamb, and instead order the seafood, chicken and pork dishes. Crabs great: and pick and choose how you want it prepared. Just because it's not listed prepared that way on the menu, ask if you can have it another way. Fried sole is great. So's the jellyfish. And don't be a "white ghost", even if you are ethnically Chinese, but actually born and raised in San Fernando Valley...in other words, dont' act like a tourist: Make sure they give you a cold plate with the sliced meats along with that jellyfish and pickled veggies. 

Frankly, as one who resides with walking distance down the hill for a quick dinner at HK Clay Pot, I'm hesistant about saying how good it can be for such incredibly cheap prices...at the same time sad that Bill's no longer running this ship and keeping the chefs in line. But, hey, it's completely different town...And hey, if you speak Canto, even just few words (pickup a Lonely Planet Cantonese book, for chrissake), it does help: especially if you know to ask about the secret stuff they don't serve the guailos, and keeps them from serving the Americanized crap they give tourists...and if you plan to come here often, make friends with the servers: they will remember you, good or bad.
author: Cork G.

description:
The food was fresh and pretty cheap, however the atmosphere was kind of lacking.

My party of 7 ordered the $48 for 4 people + an additional lamb clay pot and white rice (they charge rice per person...didn't know that when we ordered it).  Despite all that, we had excess food which was great and shows that the $48 for 4 people could actually feed about 6-7 people.  The food was fresh, but I have had better.

The service was a bit sloppy as it was pretty busy with a large 3 table party going on behind our party.  It was cramped and a fire hazard in the restaurant.  Additionally, the waiting staff I think were the daughters of some of the workers here and sometimes they were just not paying much attention to the customers and were just goofing off.

Overall, taking this into consideration, I would say this place is pretty average with nothing special, but it is a cheap place to go to if you are on a tight budget.
author: Lawrence E.

description: I'm sure you've heard this before, but it has to be emphasized here: the wait is well worth it! It's a pretty small, albeit cozy, room. Very crowded, but felt very home-like. As my lady said, if the name calls out their specialty, get it. Their seafood clay pot was mind-blowing. We also got the house fried rice, pot stickers, and honey walnut prawns. Our total bill was ~$35. We had to roll out of there with how full our bellies were. If you're in Chinatown, this is one of those legendary hole-in-the-wall places to write home about!
author: Exceter M.

description:
With it's hole in the wall location it's easy to miss this place so make sure you keep your eye out for that yellow awning because this is one place you don't want to miss!!

It's family style so expect to be seated at a large table with other patrons who are enjoying their lunch/dinner.  I knew the moment I walked in to this place that this was a winner as the place was not only packed at 11:30 but everyone there was of Asian descent. 

Between the three of us we ordered enough food to feed a small army only because everything looked so good we couldn't decide what to order! Besides, you can't beat their special lunch prices ($4.40 for any dish on their lunch menu). Everything's very authentic, well prepared, and high quality. 

Their warm sake wasn't anything special but I didn't expect much from a hole in the wall restaurant on Grant St, so I enjoyed every sip with little hesitation. 

The honey walnut prawns were the best by far...OMG, so damn good!!! The prawns were sweet and savory and the walnuts were cooked perfectly (not too gooey and not to crunchy with the right amount of sweetness to them). 

My only grip is their sloooooow service. We were consistently the last to be served and checked on throughout our dining experience as we seemed to be the only white people in this establishment. We didn't mind this too much as it gave my sister and I time to teach my mom how to use chopsticks (still don't think she's got the hang of it as she resorted to her fork half way through the meal). 

Other than that our food came out pretty quickly once we finally got our order in and every dish was deliscious in it's own way and made up for the time spent waiting. 

Can't wait to go back....and that says a lot since I'm the last person to ever suggest "Let's do Chinese tonight!"
author: Kristy M.

description: We went based on Yelp reviews and we were not disappointed!  The service was a little slow but not bad. We were there at 5ish on a Saturday and were seated quickly. As a family of four we were seated at a large round table for 8 and told to take a side. Later 2 men were seated with us. We enjoyed getting to know them. We ordered the egg flower soup, chicken fried rice, chicken chow mein, and sweet & sour chicken. All were EXCELLENT!  Probably the best Chinese we'd ever had. For sure the best sweet & sour chicken.   Excellent value. When we left there were many people waiting to be seated.
author: Kathy M.

description:
Delicious!  We ordered the duck clay pot, ginger lobster, string beans which may have been overkill for 2 people, but my friend and I ended up very nicely stuffed for a total of ~$40, not bad considering we had a whole lobster.

I've heard bad things about the authenticity of the Chinese food in Chinatown (vs the Clement street area).  The Chinatown restaurants cater to the tourists.  However, I found it a good sign when the restaurant was packed, and most everybody was Asian.  The restaurant is a bit hidden and hard to find.  The sign for it is not obvious, and you have to climb up a flight of stairs in order to access it, which may be a deterrent for most, but a perk for me!  The ambiance and the food were both authentic, and it is definitely a place that I would take my Chinese parents to.
author: Jeanne L.

description:
Hole- in- the wall in Chinatown with great affordable Chinese food! We got the family dinner combo A that guarantees to feed 4.  We had 5 people and still had left overs! For only $48 the combo included soup, beef, crab, seafood clay pot, vegetable dish, appetizers, dessert, etc. 

Service was excellent for a Chinese restaurant. Our water never went empty. They were quick at refilling our tea as well.
author: Helen C.

description: This place is a little hard to find, but the food is pretty good. We ordered the fried crab, which is good but really greasy. The other dishes are ordered were good, but not very memorable.
author: J. L.

description: One of the best that I have tried. The prices are reasonable.  The place is small so be prepared to wait for a table.
author: ATX L.

description:
Love this place. It's hidden upstairs in the heart of Chinatown. Always filled with people but the couple of times I've been there, I've been seated very quickly as well.

I've taken a star off for "brief" service, but the food here is great.  From the large potstickers to the sizzling clay pots the kitchen here churns out some yummy Chinese food.  The prices are very reasonable as well and great value.

This is a place to take a visitor in the city to show that you know the insider secrets of SF.
author: Praneeth W.

description:
One thing they had going for them was a packed house and a cool bustling atmosphere. I ate here with my family after watching the Chinese New Year Parade. Grant Street was packed with tourists and shop keepers peddling their wares. We were lucky in that we got a window seat to witness the exciting celebration while we ate. 

Overall the food wasn't horrible. I checked out Yelp before we ordered and saw what people were eating and writing good things about, unfortunately, I may have just ordered the wrong stuff. Considering the restaurant is named Clay Pot, I probably should have gone with some clay pot dish, oh well. 

I ordered the following:

Honey Walnut Prawns: Honestly not very good. I have had MUCH better. This was a mistake to order in the first place. I was in the mood for steamed greens, and a nice cooked fish or something very basic/fresh/authentic...instead I went with a standard American Chinese Cuisine dish. The honey/mayo sauce was missing something and the Shrimp tasted like they had been freezer burned and boiled a long time to make them edible. 

Peking Sparerips: Very sweet candied meat. Again, I should not have ordered this int he first place, not sure what I was thinking. 

Oysters with Black Bean Sauce: This was the dish I was thinking would make it or break it. The black bean sauce actually tasted great, but the oysters themselves did not taste fresh. I stopped at one and took them away from my kids so they wouldn't poison themselves, just in case. 

I will not return to this place, though I can see that a lot of people like it and like I said, I may have just ordered wrong.
author: Michael G.

description:
The stairs leading up to HK Clay Pot can seem a bit sketchy...but once you walk up the stairs and into the restaurant, it's much cozier and less shady. 

We came on a Thursday evening after work and there were only 2 other occupied tables, which was nice for us as we were starving and were not in the mood to wait.

We ordered the oxtail/tofu/mushroom clay pot, a side of Chinese veggies, and the lobster dish. All were great, especially the lobster. It was about 8.99/lb, which is actually super reasonable compared to other Chinese restaurants that charge upwar to 20.00/lb. The lobster meat was tender, but I do wish there was more meat in it. 

The oxtail clay pot was wonderful. The oxtail was soaked in so many amazing spices and fell right off the bone. Simply delicious.

I normally am not a fan of veggies, especially Chinese veggies, but the veggies we ordered (forgot the name of it) was also great. I think it's because it was soaked in this melted bean curd, which made it nice and salty (but not overly salty).

I would definitely come back again and check out other dishes. It's A-OK - not super awesome but definitely cheap and do-able.
author: Kristina K.

description:
Things that make a good hole-in-the-wall Chinese restaurant:

1)  Really good, free tea with your meal. This is important.

2)  Delicious food, with both Chinese-American dishes (I was in the mood for comfort and ordered the sweet and sour chicken - tasted fantastic) AND authentic Chinese food

3) Cheap.

4) Locals eat there

5) Beer.

And for being a hole in the wall, it was pretty clean and cozy!  It's definitely not a fancy dine-in restaurant where people are nicely dressed.  This is a place for local families to eat at (a large 8 person group was there when I was - otherwise it was pretty empty during lunch on Thursday) with the occasional tourist walking in.

I loved it.  Casual, great food, and cheap.  It doesn't get any better than that.  I'll definitely come back at some point and try one of the more authentic Cantonese dishes.
author: Joanna S.

description:
This place is well hidden on the second floor of the way too over-crowded touristy Grant Street in Chinatown, but the claypots are a treat. My personal favorite is the seafood claypot with calamari (very tender), fish, shrimp and fried tofu. This claypot has a ginger sauce that it cooks in which is just delicious. 

Great for large groups as well, so you can try as much as possible :)
author: Doruk G.

description: We were wandering around Chinatown and decided to grab a quick lunch, we came across Hong Kong Clay Pot and decided to give it a try!  The restaurant is on the second floor so if you have problems with stairs this might not be the place for you, we were seated immediately and given the menus and some hot tea.  We ended up getting more than we intended, their menu is quite large.  I ordered the House Noodle Soup with rice noodles, my husband ordered the chicken/tofu clay pot and my daughter got the chow fun noodle all were excellent!  We will definitely go back..
author: Linda N.

description: The food was good. Had the potstickers fried prawns house noodles and house fried rice. Nice and quiet and service was good. Deff would come back here again.
author: Jevaughn J.

description:
Just placed order here....me like it thus far!!! If unafraid of younger, more local crowd and second floor walk-up, this place is for you!!

Follow-up comment:

Clay-pot contents were "good-to-the-last-drop."

I ate there twice when on business trip in Downtown San Francisco.

Menu is bargain priced.

Its an authentic Asian casual-dining experience.

Tip: "Closed" on Wednesdays

Tip: street parking is hit or miss everywhere in Downtown San Francisco.
author: Jesus B.

description:
Maybe we ordered the wrong things, but I didn't really like this place as much as others did. 

From yelp reviews, we got the Lamb in Claypot, but the meat in this dish reminded me more of pork belly than lamb. I did like the bean curd that came with this dish, though. 

We also got the Honey Walnut Prawns, which was tasty, but the shrimp was small and few. Not worth the $9.50 in my opinion. 

The Seafood in Claypot was pretty good, but again, not as much seafood as I was expecting. The sauce in their claypots are quite tasty, so maybe that's what people like about this place. 

One of our friends came late and ordered Chicken over Greens. For the most part, this dish was good, but I think the bok choy could have used more flavor.

Overall, I would probably come here again to try other dishes to hopefully see what others are raving about.
author: Katherine T.

description:
We were walking down Grant Street one day looking for a place to eat that wasn't too touristy/PF Chang's when I noticed a rather happy looking couple coming out of a doorway about 1/2 a block from us. As we approached the place we noticed a stairway leading up to ... the great unknown. Feeling adventurous we decided to ascend. Feeling even more adventurous I decided *not* to check the Yelp reviews in advance. :)

The place was bustling with activity - always a good sign. The food was awesome and the ambiance was very much the hole-in-the-wall Chinatown experience we were looking for. Service was a bit abrupt, but unobtrusive. I think part of this is the language/accent barrier - just point and smile and be patient and you'll (usually) be OK.

Lesson learned: always follow the happy people.
author: Todd H.

description: Hidden hole in the wall spot... authentic chinese food... I recommend the walnut prawns,  top notch flavor and taste... I also recommend the chicken fried rice, sweet and sour pork, and also the salt and pepper pork chops.... so good you'll definitely take leftovers home with you.
author: Roger M.

description:
Very well earned 4 stars!  We chose this restaurant in hope to find a true Chinese dining in Chinatown of San Francisco (I don't think it's a problem over there, but we wanted the best).  After the research on Yelp we came up with Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant in the heart of Chinatown.  And they didn't disappoint, I would say they impressed!

When in other reviews people say hole-in-the-wall place, they probably didn't see real hole-in-the-wall places... This place require you to climb pretty narrow stairs to the second floor, but the dining area itself is roomy and very nicely decorated.  We were sitting by the window and could see the Grand Street: booths and people walking there for the pre-Chinese New Year festival.

First of all, Honey Walnut Prawns - BEST!!  This dish is a BOMB!  It disappeared within a minute just because it was so damn good!!

We also ordered Wonton Soup which was very good, and Duck Clay Pot with some weird tasting thick noodles, which was also good, especially duck (not the noodles).

Service was great, not too annoying, not to ignoring, though, they kicked us out as soon as we finished eating (Asian thing, it's ok, was expected, they had a line already waiting to be seated).

Overall, I got what I wanted, the true Chinese dining experience, was very happy with it!  And very recommend!
author: Elena C.

description: We had the seafood clay pot, honey walnut shrimp and salt and pepper port with rice. Everything was delicious, especially the clay pot with chunks of garlic and ginger. The restaurant is in a small room upstairs.
author: Ginger M.

description:
Great service and tasty food!

Didn't have any frogs though when I was there :(

Duck clay pot was good, hot and sour soup was good, quails were okay.
author: Michael W.

description:
DO NOT, DO NOT, DO NOT EAT HERE

Ate here on Feb 5th.... thought it was great.... about 60 minutes later, the rumblings began.  was sick all night.... Had to have the ambulance come and wheel me to the ER around 1 AM.   Violent nausea, cramps, I don't want to even share the rest.....  I can't image what the ER bill will be


DO NOT EAT HERE IF YOU LOVE YOURSELF!!!!!  Seriously
author: Nicole D.

description: Glad we came here. Very fresh Chinese food, and the best tasting chicken ever! Look closely, it's hidden up a stairwell between 2 shops..
author: Laura B.

description:
We found ourselves wondering in Chinatown looking for a good, quick and inexpensive meal this Thursday night and trusting previously yelp reviews, we chose Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant.  Again, the wisdom of the masses prevailed.  It sure didn't disappoint.  

It's located on the second floor so I was a bit nervous when walking up the carpeted stairs, not knowing what to expect.  The place is populated and the two of us were able to get a place by the window.  Since we were on a budget, we ordered only braised tofu clay pot and stir fried beef chow fun.  The free tea was made with actual tea leaves, not a tea bag, so it was a definite plus.  

The clay pot dish arriving popping hot and looked well prepared,  not something just scooped out of a huge caldron and plopped into a bowl.  The braised tofu was cooked with bak choy and meaty mushrooms.  It wasn't so salty, greasy and packed with MSG as one would expect from a small restaurant.  The stir fried beef chow fun was good, too.  The beef was tender and the noodles weren't not drowning in grease and soy sauce.    

With a bowl of rice and these two dishes, the grand total including tax came to $16.75.  Not the cheapest, but not bad for a sit down meal and a pot of real tea on a Thursday night.

Clay pots are their specialty and they seem to offer hot pot in colder months.
author: Sherry K.

description:
I was craving salt and pepper crabs, but didn't want to pay the premium at R&G Lounge. I was disappointed that although they advertised crabs for 19$, they didn't have the inventory. However, I was able to substitute the crab with lobster (not on menu although ginger lobster is). The lobster was on the small side, but was tasty and satisfied my cravings for deep fried shellfish. 

Other dishes that I have tried:

1. tofu clay pot - comes with Bok choy, shittake, and tofu. Highly recommended!
2. Hot and sour soup - really spicy and flavorful
3. Salt and pepper cod - crispy and well made, but too much salt was added. 
4. Kung pao shrimp - don't get it. Too salty and shrimp was over cooked

Decor is typical of Chinatown- a little run down and restaurant was hard to find. Service was whatever, but prompt. 

I love their deep fried salt and pepper lobster and will be back to try the crabs once they are in season. Other dishes are decent and you really can't beat the prices here. I would avoid overly-Americanized dishes such as the Kung pow, sweet and sour stuff that cater primarily to tourists.
author: Ngoc N.

description:
First, let's preface this with the situation. Chinese New Year parade had just ended, the streets were slammed with people, and lines were everywhere. Based on the review, we decided to patron this place. 

There was a line into the restaurant, one which we were happy to stand in...until some snarky folks just started busting in front of everyone. The waiters had their hands full, but still...not ok. There was no system to put your name down. Gripe 1.

Gripe 2 is directly related to our food. We ordered a smattering of things, none of which hit the mark. In fact, even the dish we'd read about most, the honey walnut prawns, were disappointing. Our order was incorrect, the clay pot was disappointing, and it was only the mound of green beans that were relatively good.

We ordered, in all: green beans, lamb clay pot (which morphed into an ox tail clay pot, somehow), clam soup, and honey walnut prawns. I would eat none of them again, and I won't be returning.

The good: Family-style dining, getting to know some other folks. 
The bad: The food
The odd: plastic party cups for water.
author: Amanda B.

description: The most amazing Chinese food I have ever had!!!! Low key hole in the wall that is worth trying!!!
author: Gracie C.

description:
Very good food and ambience. I recommend ordering the duck clay pot!
That was a really really good dish!
author: Marjori P.

description:
It was definitely hole in the wall.  You have to walk up to the second floor.  

We went on a Friday night and it was packed with people.  We ordered quail as appetizer, lamb clay pot and a dish of veggie.  The quail is a must!!!  

 Reasonable price.  There was only two of us this time, next time I go I would bring a group so I can try more dishes.
author: Deb L.

description: My gf and I were supposed to go to The House for dinner, but they had no reservations until 9PM and we had a 10:30 flight out so that wasn't going to work. We got there and put our names on the list, but also looked around for other restaurants as they told us it was going to be an hour. Hong Kong Clap Pot was on the way back to our hotel, so we decided to give it a shot. I'm so glad we did because their ginger lobster and walnut prawns were so phenomenal. You know it's a legit Chinese restaurant because it looks like all the ones back in Arcadia and Alhambra in LA. The usual clientele are Chinese speaking locals and the occasional yelp yuppies (like me). But the food is super reasonably priced and the tea is plentiful. Be sure to check it out if you're ever venturing through Chinatown.
author: Won K.

description:
Fried duck tongue? I'm in!

Ha ha ha. Came here with a friend the other night who insisted we walk from the SoMA to here for some legit Chinese food. He's from France, soo I'll excuse his use of cutlery, but overall I was pleased with his choice. We waited about 30 minutes for a table-the place was jampacked with families surrounding large round tables with piles of food spinning around on them. This scene alone told us the food would be worth the wait.

Finally got a two-top and decided to order Broccoli Beef, Fried Duck Tongue (just for shits!), Sweet & Sour Chicken, and soup. The tongues were a little gummy for me with an odd crunch, but the rest of the food was "a-ok". I wouldn't say it was worth the wait but it was good. Maybe we ordered the wrong things, but I wouldn't go out of my way to go here. Luckily I had great company :)

The atmosphere was nice-lively, smackdab in the heart of Chinatown, families and friends enjoying meals together-but the food was just mediocre.
author: Leigh W.

description:
Pro: Good food and cheap lunch menu
Cons: A very long wait and slow service

If you are a tourist or local who has plenty of time to spend on eating, come here. If you don't have time to spend and would rather see more things in one day while you are in SF, don't bother coming here. 

Don't get me wrong, the food is really good and the price is very affordable during lunch time, but the wait is ridiculous. It took us about 45 mins to get a table and another 45 mins to get the food. The service is really slow as there were only 2 servers.
author: Inge T.

description: My friend and I came to this place because of the recommendation from Yelp however I was not impressed. The restaurant is located on the second floor of the main street in Chinatown. The food was middle of the road. The prices are good but the quantity is small so I guess you get what you pay for. We ordered the pan fried noodles with the honey walnut shrimp. Would I return to this place, most likely not.
author: Matthew L.

description:
Ordered the salt and pepper crab and SO got beef with broccoli. As soon as we started up the stairs, we could tell/smell we were in for some good food. I must have looked like the most clueless white girl trying to eat the crab (actually trying to figure out how to eat it) but what I was able to eat was delicious. Very flavorful coating on the crab, even though I have no clue if I ate it properly. Hub said beef and broccoli was the best he's had in years. 

Apparently they do read minds-husband's must've said, 'I can't use chopsticks; fork for me, please' and mine must've said, 'I need a billion napkins, please." He got a fork and I got a stack of napkins as big as my head, without even asking. 

Service a little slow at lunch, but friendly and food was tasty. Definitely would go back, next time I am in SF.
author: Meg A.

description:
Came back again with a couple of friends this time and ordered a wider variety of dishes.  For now i am going to hold the 4 star rating.  Solid food with fresh vegitables cooked just right.  Ordered the seafood claypot which was spectacular.  We ordered the duck clay pot as well and I must say that it was pretty bad.  Not in terms of preparation, but the cuts of meat used.  They used a lot of back and wing pieces, so all you really got was bone and skin.  I certainly would not order this dish again, but would happily come back for everything else.

Great value and really solid Cantonese diner food.  First, the portions are massive.  I had lunch there and had beef stew with rice and my friend had beef stew noodle soup.  I think we spent $11 for both of us.  The wontons were very meaty and the soup broth has so much flavor.  Just those two along were enough to make this place a winner.  The beef stew (which is the benchmark by which all Chinese diners should be measured) was solid.  Not too fatty yet still tender.  Everything came out hot and on a cold rainy day it really hit the spot.  There was a large family next to our table that ordered the full spread, with steamed fish, crab etc.  It looked so good.  For now, I am going with 4 stars.  Next time, I am going to bring a whole crew of friends to try the full banquet style gorging experience.  If it comes through on that meal, then we may have to upgrade to 5 stars.
author: Scott C.

description: Good cooking and reasonable price ! Fresh ingredients, Cantonese styles!  I do recommend it's time for them to change the carpet.  It's old smelly carpet.
author: Jack H.

description: It's perfect! Everything we ordered is delicious!! Especially 虾米粉丝煲!! Not to mention the incredibly low price. I mean who does that??
author: Artemis S.

description: This place is great! We loved the walnut shrimp dish and their pan fried noodles. Went there twice in a week! Keep in mind the location is a bit small and above the Chinatown shops. We loved it!
author: Liliana B.

description: The name displayed on the restaurant was 'Hong Kong Dimsum', so that was a bit of a throw off; but omg the food.. it's delicious!! We had the ox tail clay pot and the quail clay pot. The service was great as well.
author: Arpita S.

description: The service is horrible and you're lucky if you get a drink but the food is really good and makes up for the crappy service
author: Tatiana C.

description: Run into this place in Chinatown. It looks quite "traditional" Chinatown Chinese restaurant to me, and it turned out to be true. Greasy food, crab was not fresh, vege was over cooked, and floor was dirty! I would not come back.
author: Yuchun W.

description: The tofu clay pot was good - not great-  but my hubby's Kung pao chicken was oily and the chicken didn't taste like good quality meat. The veggie fried rice was good too.
author: Lisa C.

description: They serves us quickly and the food arrived pipping hot...  Great for when you have a large party of friends from out of town and they want to experience Chinatown. But it's not like it's a super fancy gourmet sorta place.  They have a lot of standards that Americans expect plus some dishes that  cater to local Chinese families (the restaurant was filled with them when we went) .  Bottom line, simple, fast, and actually pretty decent food.
author: Miri R.

description: Was OK food.  Not sure about it. Seemed to be rushing us.  I need a half more star to make it an accurate rating
author: Dino R.

description: Get here early cause this place gets packed. The food is legit, Mongolian beef is bomb! It's pretty crammed inside so if your shopping or have a stroller (we did) leave it in the car.
author: Rick M.

description:
Let's be honest. I'm from Colorado, and one thing that we lack in good ol' CO is a China Town. We have a few places in the Mile High City that are authentic, but nothing as quaint, and hidden-feeling as Hong Kong Clay Pot. 

The menu includes all of the typical favorites, and some things that I'd like to try when I am back in China Town; spicy jellyfish and frog hot pot to name names. We got pot stickers, pork fried rice, sweet and sour chicken and spring rolls. It was all incredible. 

So, if you're feeling like an adventure, or if you just want some delicious Chinese snacks, take the stairs and you won't regret it.
author: Megan W.

description: We just sent here on Sunday and it was a OK experience  i would say. Like we got there got seated right away and all ordered our and waited about 10 mins to get stated. Well we were suppose to get 12 prawns for our appetizer but it only came with 10!!!! I decided not to say anything well then the food came out and it was not the  best but ok to eat. The fried rice with salted fish was terrible though had a really weird smell to it. The place was dirty not the most cleanest  place service was OK they were not that attentive. After we were there for about 25 mins lot of people came in and they got extremely loud i mean LOUD.Would i want to go back here no not really unless i had no choice
author: Shaneel R.

description:
Second time here and was impressed. Clay pots are definitely the way to go here (hence the restaurant name) - ordered veggie and tofu claypots and fish. The fish was a tad overcooked, but decent.

Overall the meal came with free soup (didn't seem to have MSG, but what do we know?), tofu claypot and steamed fish and rice, coming out to $30 before tax and tip for 2 people. Very reasonable for SF!
author: Yan K.

description:
This is my 2nd time here.  We had the clams with black bean sauce, crab stirred fry with ginger, spinach with garlic, Ox tail clay pot & chicken & sausage clay pot.  

All was very mediocre at best.  The food was fresh, but the favors weren't great.  Spinach was too over-cooked.  The clams were decent, but the sauce was too thick.  The Ox-tails were a bit gamey (if that's possible).

Won't be back.  Wanted to give this place another try.  I should have stuck with my favorite clay pot place on Waverly.
author: Marie E.

description: Delicous walnut shrimp, fried rice and pot stickers I have had in China Town.  Its a major hole in the wall between to stores. Its worth coming and dont be discourage. The food is fresh.
author: Alonso R.

description:
I found this place using my iPhone Yelp app.  Wandering around Chinatown in search of a great chinese sit-down restaurant, my husband and I came across all the fabulous Yelp reviews and decided to give it a try.

We walked up the uninviting staircase towards the sound of LOTS of Chinese people enjoying their meals.  We had to wait about 5 minutes since the restaurant was packed, but the wait was well worth it.

Food was tasty, especially the walnut prawns.  I wouldn't order the seafood clay pot a second time; it was a bit too fishy for me.  Chicken wings were pretty awesome (thanks Yelp recommendation!).

Definitely give it a try if you're looking for authentic Chinese in San Francisco's Chinatown.  This restaurant was packed wall-to-wall with Chinese people.  When you find a Chinese restaurant filled with Chinese people, you know you're in the right spot.
author: Alex B.

description:
Decent for inexpensive chinese food.  And the service was actually REALLY good.  We have 2 young kids and the waitress was very attentive and accommodating.

Would love to give it higher marks, but can't because the lamb clay pot was a disappointment.  The lamb was over-cooked and ended up being kind of tough.   

The other food we ordered was decent.
author: Mike L.

description:
1. Hot and stuffy with two little fans to air out the incredibly crowded room. Needs ventilation. 

2. Slow service. Kinda rude. They don't acknowledge you when you walk in. You just stand and wait. The lady asked my husband to turn on the fan...and when we said he was too short, she said he could climb on the chair. There was a carseat there with my daughter in it, and it was extremely cramped. Not cool. Started ordering using numbers, and she rudely told us to give her the name of the dish and not numbers. 

3. Food was okay. Beef stew pot good. Beef chow fun salty with no real flavors. Peking spare ribs decent.  

4. We ordered fish. It never came. When we asked, the lady denied we ordered fish bc she never wrote it down. Seriously, I repeated it three times...and she still missed it. 

5. I don't understand why you have to ask for rice these days in Chinese restaurants! Why doesn't rice come with my dish!?!?
author: Cindy G.

description: I was here for dinner. I ordered a tofu clay pot with chicken and salted fish, and a vege. They both tasted great! The service was proactive and they even gave me a free soup.
author: Rachel Z.

description: Incredibly reasonable prices and good food! I would still deem it as a hole in the wall, but what authentic Chinese restaurant isn't? Clean. Very friendly staff! Will be back!
author: Suzie J.

description:
It's on the second level and there is a flight of stairs that I often see old people struggling to get up and down. Food must be good eh?

I've had the porridge, the walnut shrimp, some other dishes I can't really remember. But I do remember leaving feeling very satisfied. Parking is a problem, or I would go alot more often.
author: Chloe L.

description:
Most authentic Chinese food Ive ever had. When I went upstairs to this place, I felt as if I had entered China! 
The hot tea was delicious, the sweet and sour chicken was as good as it gets. (crunchy on the outside, tender on the inside) Honestly, it was perfect.  I also ordered the Honey Walnut prawns, which turned out to be delightful as well. 

Even the fortune cookies were good! 

This was the best Chinese food Ive ever had!  I highly recommend this!
author: Danielle E.

description: This place was just fantastic. Had the seafood clay pot and Mongolian beef. The wonton soup was great. The hot and sour soup needed a bit of salt, but it was great too.
author: Paul H.

description: Found this place with the Yelp app while roaming the city. Oh my gosh! So good. An unlikely place that surprised the heck out of me. I'm choosy about Chinese food as my friends parents home cooking cannot usually be topped. Well, think again...this is one if the few that could. Would suggest this to anybody. Don't let the surroundings scare you. You're in for a treat.
author: Grace V.

description: I was in town for a week so I wanted to try some authentic Chinatown Chinese food.  I saw a few good reviews about this place so after I got off work I made my way there on foot.  I walked right past the place first but found it on the way back up the hill.  The dining area is upstairs and to the right.  I saw a nice size group of Asian folks at another table dining so I felt like this must be the place.  I wanted to try something different so I went with the prawns.  Can't remember the exact name but they were like Walnut Prawns or Honey Prawns or something.  They were pretty good but a little sweet for my taste.  I have a low tolerance for really sweet foods. The service was good and the people there were nice.  I would definitely go back.
author: Tim W.

description: Good Chinese food in a very ethnic setting. This place isn't a tourist trap. We got quite a bit of food for $14/person. Be prepared for crammed spaces, oily air and good food!
author: Thomas C.

description: Whenever we come to San Francisco to visit, we definitely come to this place in Chinatown. The food is authentic. It is not your typical American Chinese food.
author: Salaish S.

description: This lil place is upstairs, and the food was okay. We ordered two dishes (honey walnut prawns and clams in black bean sauce), and neither were great. Just your average fair of Chinese food.
author: Alice L.

description:
I ended up here on Thanksgiving day because:

1. It was open
2. It was near my hotel
3. The Yelp reviews

The kids and I celebrated TG at my brother's house a few days later on Saturday, so don't think I'm a weirdo for having my Thanksgiving meal here. My sixteen year old son did NOT want to proceed up the grotey stairway to the entrance, but we did anyway. We were seated right away, and were the only non Asians in the place.

It was a little noisy when we arrived at around eight o'clock - I guess real Chinese people don't do the "restaurant voice" thing - but by the time we left the adults were downright loud and these cute little Chinese kids were running around and screaming like it was a playground, which didn't really bother me, but It was freaking my 16 year old son out, but I like it when that happens. A twenty something non-Asian showed up when we were waiting for our food, sat down for three or four minutes, was ignored and left. What a wimp!

We had clay pot duck, salt and pepper crab and a vegetable dish the waitress recommended, but as she spoke no English I have no idea what it was. Bright green and tasty. The service was a little strange but quick. My son thought it was way too authentic and funky, but I loved it and would return again, and maybe try the deep fried duck tongues and the regular crab, which is what the staff was eating at the next table.
author: Kevin S.

description: Just a fantastic experience. We walked up  a set of stairs and I knew we had Gould the right place. The Mongolian Beef and Beef Stew in a Clay Pot were perfect!
author: David B.

description:
I live in LA and LOVE it (no, we're not ALL conceited, vapid, self-absorbed individuals with chiseled modelesque physiques--okay, at least other Angeleans aren't); but I visit our Chinatown only every once-in-a-blue-moon because it (and the Chinese restaurants there) generally, well, sucks.  Coming into SF for the weekend, I've experienced the joy of discovering a vibrant Chinatown and several great Chinese restaurants. This actually saddens me because I don't live in the City. 

This is *not* R&G Lounge, folks.  This is your hard-to-find-because-it's-strangely-located-on-second-floor-situating, hole-in-a-wall-locating, chicken-head-on-the-plate-leaving, tea-toting, free-rice-giving, come-correct-with-Cantonese-speaking-if-you're-Chinese-or-don't-come-at-all, vinyl-table-top-covering, old-school solid Chinese restaurant.  This is the kind of place where you could bring your kids to show them what eating really good food in a hole-in-the-wall place is like.  It'd also be an interesting date place to vet your date, albeit one I would leave for a later--rather than a earlier--one.  We actually saw a guy whip out a bottle of hooch in a plastic bag (mind you, this was lunch) and take a swig.  Corkage?  What's that?

Lunch specials at $4.60...EVERYDAY?!? (except Wednesdays, when they're closed)...are you friggin' kidding me!?!  The portions are generous, and my bud and I had ordered way too much food as we supplemented two lunch specials with a shrimp wan-ton soup (funny enough, I was hungry an hour later.  It must have been that walk up Nob Hill back to the Ritz).  Bring a posse with you, or otherwise you won't be able to enjoy as many of their items as will tempt you on the menu.  We sat next to a table of 8 and they ordered everything I wanted to order (lobster with noodles, fried chicken, clams, walnut shrimp, tofu with brown sauce, and congee).  Forget finger-lickin' good--I kid you not--the kid at the table was licking his ENTIRE HAND.  I was so moved I asked if I could join them.  Sadly, they said "No." 

Sigh, a boy can dream...

-Shrimp wanton soup: your basic shrimp wanton soup, nothing to write home about.  The wanton skin was a little thick and the filling consisted only of shrimp, but it was flavored well.  It would have been nice if it came with some bok choy in the soup.
-Spicy salted pork ribs: I thought this was excellent, with not too much coating and just enough spices to bring out the flavor of the pork.  I could actually taste the freshness of the pork.  A world of difference from Yuet Lee.
-String beans with chicken in black bean sauce: must be me, but I think I prefer black bean sauce only for clams.  The string beans were extremely fresh and cooked perfectly--not having lost the "snap" while still being cooked-through.
author: George T.

description: Very good food.  We had a combination of just about everything and it was all delicious.  Hot pot, fried rice, Mongolian beef, pan fried rice, and Tsingtao beer. With he was very fresh. I feel like I was stepping in Shanghai again.
author: Yeah R.

description:
Great menu of authentic dishes. Service was friendly, although I experienced a few instances where my Chinese (none) and their English (slightly less than fluent, at times) caused some hick-ups.

Overall, it was a great experience that I would definitely recommend!
author: Jeff Z.

description: I get sketched out a bit eating at certain places, especially Chinese food that smells like a pet store. This is not the case here; once you get up the stairs you walk into a smell of delicious food. I recommend the honey walnut shrimp and the curry chicken clay pot. I can't wait to come back and try more!
author: Roxanne R.

description: Ordered spinach with garlic, fish fillet and tofu in claypot, scallop dish. They served us frozen scallops of the worst quality and they come with a weird after taste. This place cooks food for American tastebuds. If you are used to real Chinese food don't bother walking up the stairs. After I told the waitress about the scallops, she told me to order something else next time... as if I am going to return to this place!!!
author: Kara T.

description:
We went here simply because we were hungry and near Chinatown. We Yelped for high rated restaurants and decided on this one. 

We weren't disappointed. I wish there were more than two of us so we could've tried more dishes. 

Here's what we had: tofu hotpot, spicy beans with XO sauce, scallops with veggies and egg fried rice. While they were all very good, three items really stood out. The hotpot with tofu and mushrooms was really good. The spicy beans was especially delicious because the XO sauce was made with fermented shrimp paste - something I've had before and was pleasantly surprised when it was made that way. But my favorite - maybe I was craving carbs after walking around SF all day - was the simple egg fried rice. I couldn't get enough. Just oily enough, just fried enough, just moist enough. 

I would definitely return and try out the other dishes. 

The ambiance was definitely that of a dive. You go up these carpeted stairs. Make sure you turn right. Turn left and you go into the men's bathroom. The people who were already there seemed like regulars and we felt like we walked into someone's dining room. People knew each other. That's a good sign, regulars. So all in all a very good experience. Check it out.
author: Tristan H.

description: Good place for Hong Kong cuisine
author: Alex Y.

description:
Look carefully, you have to find the set of stairs sandwiched between two shops. 
Found this through YELP and must concur with all the positive reviews.  Not a restaurant for ambiance, this is the place to eat for excellent and inexpensive food.  
Portions are huge.  We showed up with a party of 11 at about 2 pm and were seated and served quickly.  Service is efficient and no nonsense.
author: Carmen S.

description:
Been wanting to come to this place in a while since searching for a new place to eat in Chinatown. I thought clay pot sounded delicious so I bookmarked this place. After some attempts of coming here (they close at 3pm and reopen at 5:30pm and they close on Wednesdays) the place was finally open for business when I came out here. Was supposed to come here with a friend but she had other plans but I decided to eat alone since I could not wait for another trip out here. 
I walked up those flight of stairs and the restaurant was to the right. The decor was pretty old fashioned. I thought it was pretty cute how they have some Christmas stockings up on the wall. Kind of a fusion. The atmosphere was nice and I really liked the view of Chinatown's Grant Avenue. I was seated for a table of one but the waitress brought me two menus. Okay, maybe she didn't hear me. As I was looking over the menu she brought me a pot of tea that looked like it wanted to overflow. I asked that I have just water instead and she brought me a kettle of hot water. I felt like they were trying hard to please customers that way and I thought it was a bit too much; I am just one person here. 
The prices are average for the clay pots but I thought it was a little too much for the entrees (for the tourists maybe?). I thought about getting the vegetarian clay pot but I had second thoughts. I wanted the regular Chinese sausage ones with chicken and mushroom in it. So that's what I got. A few moments later the waitress came back with a bowl of ginseng soup which was pretty nice. Then came the clay pot. I was a little disappointed when the waitress told me that the rice wouldn't be included in the clay pot because that's the best part! Anyways I had to settle for the rice not being at the bottom of the clay pot. The clay pot was mostly chicken, garlic, onions, followed by some slices of chinese sausages and a couple of mushrooms. It was fine until I realized how much oil there is in there. I actually felt uncomfortable with all that oil at the bottom of the claypot. It was a couple tablespoonfuls of oil in there! What's the point of them claiming they don't use grease (the sign was right in front of you when you walk all the way up the stairs) when they use that much oil in the food? Eww. So unhealthy. After I couldn't eat anymore I asked for the check and a to-go box to pack up the leftovers. (I know its oily but It's still food) The waitress came back with the check, the to-go box and a bowl of dessert. It was nice and 'sweet' for those complimentary items which sort of makes up for what I was unsatisfied with. The bill came out a total of $11 something. I thought it was expensive. If I wanted chicken rice I could have gone up to Powell St. and got me a box of that with less than half the price and less oil. This is my first and last time here. 
PS: I think this is a touristy place hence the prices and other things.
author: Carmen L.

description:
Very authentic. My family wanted a place where only the locals go and this was it! We tried five dishes and they were all delicious. My son loved the honey walnut prawn.

While the appearance of the restaurant was unassuming as you had to walk up the stairwell when you got there it felt like you walked right into a small restaurant in China. We also enjoyed that the staff spoke very little English which added to the charm. All in five dishes under $60----delicious and reasonable!
author: Bruce H.

description:
It's not exactly a 4 but it is also more than a 3.

If you didn't know to look for it, you would miss it.  It is located on the 2nd floor and only signage up front.  The ambiance is reminiscent of Chinatowns all over the world, slightly sketchy, fluorescent lights, clean eating surfaces but nothing fancy.

The order - Beef chow fun, braised tofu clay pot and salt & pepper pork chop.  The starter was a soup that is typically given at these old-time places.  It's complimentary and given to Chinese patrons.  It usually consists of boiled pork bones, beans, wintermelon and some seeds.  It was tasty and stomach-soothing.  Braised tofu was delicious.  Salt & pepper pork chops were ok but it was heavier on the saltiness rather than spiciness.  There were jalapenos on the plate but the flavor did not make it to chops.

To be fair, I didn't taste the beef chow fun "wet style" as it was devoured by the kids.  So the flavor must be acceptable at the least.  Some odd things I noticed was the presence of black bean and the use of green bell peppers.  The dish typically is oyster sauce-based so having black beans was strange.  The typically vegetable side should be the Chinese broccoli or "kai lan" but they used green pepper instead.  Again, strange.

For those who are Chinese or are familiar, the sweet ending is the traditional sweet bean soup which they offered us.  It was slightly sweeter and thicker than I would've liked but I don't typically like the sweet soup.

This is good place to eat if you are looking for a simple down-home meal.  The clams with black beans that the other tables were getting looked great.  Again, it's nothing fancy but it is good food.
author: Fran C.

description: just fine... the portion is huge but one of the pots i ordered (braised tofu) was too salty and another (shrimp with vermicelli) was too bland...
author: Sarah T.

description: Dirty, greasy, MSG loaded low quality food and not very cheap. We saw the yelp reviews so gave them a try. Total fail. Only positive I can say is that the waitress was somewhat honest in admitting that everything non-veg had MSG. But then when we ordered only one of the two veggie clay pots, she basically forced us to order an additional dish ("Two people and only one dish? You want another one!" she said) Looking for the smallest item to order, we asked if she can make a soup that had beef without msg, she said yes, they'll make it from scratch, no problem. We should have known that of course she would say that just to get us to order. My husband and I are both allergic to MSG, I could tell that the soup was loaded with MSG with just one sip. We couldn't drink the soup that we didn't want in the first place. Our other dish had no MSG but it was just meh.
author: jenn t.

description:
This is my go to spot in China Town for Chinese food. The food is great, and the price is right. The service is hit or miss depending on what kind of attitude the server is in. During busy times this place can get loud (but thats what makes it fun). My favorite thing to start off with are the HUGE delicious pot stickers yum yum yum I am beginning to salivate just thinking about them... 

I think I will walk down now and get me some.  :)
author: Ricky G.

description:
Have you ever tasted a burnt fortune cookie? It's a really bizarre thing, let me tell you. That aside, though...

Honey Walnut Prawns were delicious (Thanks Yelpers!), but almost a little too sweet sometimes where the sauce sort of pooled. Good, just slightly crispy texture and served with a garnish of cilantro, which admittedly buttered me up a little. When it came out, I thought that it was a bit small, but it was actually a surprising amount. I really shouldn't have finished the plate, but daaaaaaang. Not wholly mind-blowing, but satisfyingly tasty.

Jasmine tea was complimentary and delicious. Both people who served me were very kind. The dining room was bright and not very big, but the tables were large and spacious. I felt a little weird sitting by myself at a table meant for five people, but it didn't seem to be a big deal, so, woo!

The place is pretty much only local Chinese folk, and I take that as a good sign... though it might be because the place is hard to find if you only speak English and don't know what you're looking for. 

I'd give it 3.5 stars if I could, but I'm rounding up to 4 because I just got a good vibe all around.
author: Kylyn W.

description: Great food!  Good service. Worth the wait. The fried rice is the best I've ever had.  I also had the Kung Pao Chicken, which was good. And my wife thoroughly enjoyed the Mongolian Beef.
author: Alan P.

description: Ginsing tea, Kung pao chicken, hot & sour soup - delicious, authentic. Little hard to find, just go up the stairs. I eat here every San Fran layover I get. Oh, and inexpensive for lunch too!
author: Don S.

description:
Came here a couple of times. I like it a lot the first time, but a little less the 2nd time. I'm still not sure if I'd go back, maybe when I'm walking around in China town and got hungry. 

Bottom line: the food is tasty but portions are small and a bit too oily.
author: Cindy W.

description: First night in San Francisco, went with this place bases on Yelp reviews.  Couldn't have had a better experience.  Honey walnut shrimp was awesome, fried quail was pretty good and salt and pepper crab was a hit with the family.  Fried rice was also great.
author: Steven H.

description: I seriously dont know how this place has four stars. Our food was not remotely close to the level of other Hong Kong clay pot restaurants I've been to. Won't be back.
author: R C.

description: Good food, good variety. Fresh and tasty. I recommend the curry and fresh seafood. Authentic. Great squid. Yum O.
author: Max S.

description: SUPERRR SMALLLLLL. According to my mom, when I grew up, I use to come here alot, but I have NO clue where we were going. Theres a tiny teeny door leading to this restaurant. It's upstairs, and seems like a house or some sort. The food is by far the BEST I HAD EVER. It's so good. I think it almost satisfys my craving from China. Real-Chinese people in China make good good food. and this Restaurant has GREAT SERVICE but its a tad expensive.. maybe because the food we got was expensive. but great service! They make sure your water is filled and that your experience was good! There's maybe no more than 15 tables. I don't really remember since i'm doing this review like a month or two later.. The crab/ noodles was so good. My little cousin loved the dumplings.. He said it was so-good. Walnut Shrimp, omg -_-x ORDER MOREEE! But I had a great experience, Ill come back here to eat when we go back(which is often), so dont close!! :)
author: See L.

description: This restaurant's food is really great. It's tasty and doesn't cost much $. Love it!!
author: Jackie D.

description: I seriously have no idea why this place would get a high rating. The food was not authentic. I was so disappointed with the meal. If I knew better, I would have gone to PF Chang or Panda Express.
author: Alice L.

description:
Hole in the wall indeed! But what in Chinatown is not?

That said, my experience here was pretty awesome. It was funny and freaky that the 6 people I bumped into the restaurant heard about this place through Yelp too (Good job, Yelp!).

Food is good, 4 stars good. It's a busy establishment and you can't take personal the way you are treated once you are inside. They busy and are trying to get things done, so they may not pamper you as you may like them too. That said, the service is good. 

Probably my favorite thing about this place is the community table my girlfriend and I were sat at. We had the opportunity to meet some really cool people from different walks of life. It's a great idea! 

Prices are not as cheap as you would think for a restaurant in China town, but they are comparable being that you're in SF.
author: Chris R.

description:
A great lunch deal... the Mongolian beef was great, tried the shrimp with bitter melon... learned a valuable lesson: don't watch Bizarre Foods on the Travel Channel before you go out for lunch and decide what the heck, I'll try that... well, now I know I hate bitter melon.  Luckily the shrimp were great and the sauce was tasty.

The service was mediocre if not subtly hostile... not sure what the deal was?  The waitress made a big production of delivering us a set of forks, which I did not ask for... since I was already utilizing my chopstick skills.  Otherwise, efficient service during a crushing lunch rush.  If the food and the price weren't so appealing, I would have taken away a star.
author: Scott P.

description:
The stairway to Chinese food Heaven!
Yes, you need to walk up a set of stairs to this hidden restaurant.  
The food they serve reminds me of my grandmas.

Top items:
Soup of the day (always yummy and healthy)
Scrambled eggs + shrimp
Fried chicken wings
Pork + salty fish patty
Sweet & Sour pork
Black bean + string beans
Salt N Pepper Ribs
Egg white fried rice
Minced tofu clay pot

We go at least once a week for lunch and order family style.  It's never more than $10 per person and that includes tip!  It's a little hard to find.  There is a small sign on the street level with stairs going up.  It's on the 2nd floor on top of a store selling tourist trap crap.
author: J B.

description:
Summary:  Worth finding, and a good value for the money.

This place was full of surprises, noted numerically by [SX] below.

"No Grease - No Grasa" - this is the sign that greets you at the entrance to the dining area.  Written in English and Spanish, en caso de que eres de Sudamerica o de la madre patria, but [S1] not in Chinese.  Perhaps those reading Chinese don't find this positive?  [S2]The food was relatively grease free as advertised.

Pros:
* [S3] The food was actually pretty good.   Chinatown is not known for good quality Chinese food, but my first experience there today suggests that I will be back.  My lunch was flavorful, had fresh ingredients, was not buried in some unknown bottled sauce, and had a low level of oil.  
* [S4] The lunch special is a ridiculous bargain.  It's priced at $4.60 on the menu and your choices include many of the standard Chinese lunch special fare items, including noodle soup.  [S5] It lacked any noodle plates however.  After tax the bill comes to $5.05, and after tip, a whopping $6.00.  Seriously, where can you get a decent, substantial, hot meal for six bucks out the door anywhere near downtown?  What do you get for this price?  You get a very good helping of your entrée of choice (I opted to avoid the low-dollar meats and picked the braised tofu with tender greens), along with a side of rice, some very flavorful tea, and a fresh, individually wrapped fortune cookie for dessert.  Quite the bargain, I must say.  
* The upstairs location of the restaurant gets you above the fray of Grant St, and if you sit next to the window, it's quite pleasant (recognizing of course that you're eating at an inexpensive place in Chinatown).
* The mixed clientele - at lunch it was roughly 75% Asians (locals I suspect) that knew what they were doing, 20% tourists that probably had ended up there the same way I had (yelp), and 5% business people.   An Asian local joined me at my table and we got to talking.  He showed me a different lunch special menu that had a few more items on it written only in Chinese.  The secret Chinese-only menu can be a true sign that the restaurant is worth visiting.  To me it's basically saying "We're authentic, and we can survive without pandering to Western tastes".   Anyway, he ordered a fish dish (listed below) that I'm going to try next time.

Cons: 
* Looks a little dirty / run down, which can call hygiene into question, but hey, my sensitive stomach is fine a few hours later.

While my lunch was good, and worth every penny of six bucks, I spied a number of tasty looking items that I want to get when I go next - with a group to try more things of course:
* All of the lunch special items written only in Chinese, including the fish with tofu skin and black mushrooms ordered by my table companion.  
* The green bean and shrimp lunch special, which looked scrumptious.  
* Snow pea sprouts and potato sprouts (these both looked delicious and were ordered by an obviously experienced Asian group at a nearby table).
* Their famous honey walnut prawns.  

I'm not a big meat eater, and I've had enough cheap Chinese experience to not be tempted to order the meat dishes (it's only $4.60, people!), but I will take the risk on seafood from Asia in small quantities.  That being said, there was no shortage of people eating beef and chicken dishes.  

I'll post again if future research contradicts initial findings.
author: Xaman E.

description: Finding Hong Kong Clay Pot was for us like closing our eyes and pointing to a place on the map, since there are so many restaurants in Chinatown.  We were glad we wandered into this place though, on a chilly rainy day.  We started with the spring rolls which were crispy & flavourful without tasting oily or heavy.  We then ordered the Mongolian beef & prawns, the honey-walnut prawns, & the pork fried rice to share.  Everything was great. The shrimp was tender & succulent, and the beef almost melted in our mouths.  The candied walnuts with the prawns were perfectly crispy & sweet. Definitely recommend.   Inexpensive & friendly - out lunch for two with complimentary oolong tea was just $30.
author: Rachel G.

description: After reading positive Yelp reviews about Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant, we decided to try to find the restaurant along Grant Avenue during a visit to San Francisco. While we were pondering whether or not to eat lunch at the restaurant, a local walked down the stairs and told us the food was delicious. We walked up the stairs to the restaurant, and were motioned to a table by a waiter. We were served complimentary warm green tea while waiting for our lunch. Three of us shared the Hot and Sour Soup, Beef Chow Fun, and the Tofu Chicken in Clay Pot. The Hot and Sour Soup was by far my favorite, as it had a variety of flavors and was perfectly spicy.  We ended up paying about $9 per person (which includes a tip). Overall, we left very satisfied, and remembered the delicious taste of the food for the rest of the day in San Francisco.
author: Lindsey D.

description:
Pretty good but can be oily.  The pea shoots w garlic is generous and tasty and tender but just too oily.  Lunch specials are cheap but taste cheap.  Had the mongolian beef lunch special; flavor was good but the beef was of inferior quality and chewy....and too oily.
Service sucks.  You really have to prod them along to get take-away boxes or tea or your bill.  Tip - do as the regular, old-timers do-- they don't wait for service; they refill their own tea pot. 
Your fairly average, run-of-the-mill Chinese restaurant.  
I'll give it one more try for dinner some time and try their clay pot dishes.
author: Liz K.

description: Americans go nuts here. Asians go somewhere else. Nothing worth coming back for. Food was just mediocre Asian food. The pork bun at eastern bakery was better than this meal
author: Tony W.

description:
This is truly a Chinese restaurant where the masses come to, even tourists have a radar for this spot.

Before 90% of my family moved to New York, Hong Kong Clay Pot was a regular sunday morning brunch spot; while my aunts and uncles talked on and on about anything and everything, my cousins and I would spin the lazy susan and eat (yes, another family affair, my aunt owns HKCP).  It's been a while since any family outing happened there.  The most recent was with two of my friends back in January for the Lunar New Year.

I suppose one would be skeptical when dinning at a chinese restaurant, especially if you're not chinese or asian for that matter.  Such skepticism would be that it is in a touristy neighborhood, and small space. My two friends were a bit skeptical in the beginning, but after how great the food taste and how service was speedy, they overlooked their pre-judgment. 

We were deciding on several dishes, or a set course, more or less - I sort of wanted control.  To be fair, we each ordered 1 or 2 dishes, with white rice of course (rice is a need not a necessity).  I even questioned if we should get soup since one of my two friends has a slight cold, and actually - house soup of the night came with our order (my friends were intrigued with the texture of the ingredients, one of them being dried frog fallopian tubes - which we call snow jelly in chinese).  

I ordered the Honey Walnut Prawns (one of the best and my favorite), and Stir Fried Chicken with Spring Greens (which was really bok choi).  My two friends ordered Ox Tail Stew with Tofu, and Stir Fried Mustard Greens. 

My friends loved the food, and were amazed with how fast and fresh it was.  Now my two friends are not asian, so chinese food is something they have less of, or actually real chinese food (not the take out we all can get from anywhere). 

HKCP is also a great place for dim sum - and I love DIM SUM.  They don't have people pushing carts and yelling out what they have to offer, but a large menu where you note what you want and how many you want works just fine.  Their dim sum is fresh and delicious.

HKCP is a must if anyone is new in San Francisco or just want something other than chinese take out.
author: Alex C.

description:
Atmosphere of a chaotic Hong Kong "deli" is what was enjoyable about Hong Kong Clay Pot. We arrived on a Sunday night around 8:30 looking for Dim Sum because this restaurant came up with "Dim Sum" in the search. The waitress said "no more" which I couldn't determine meant no more for the night or not an ordering option at this restaurant anymore.

Regardless, I ordered garlic crab which was tasteless and the good standbys of spinach & garlic, and Spring rolls. My friend order seafood chow mein which he said was scrumptious - my word, not his.

The kitchen and wait staffs from this restaurant and I'll guess others piled in at this hour and ate mounds of food family style. We remained the only customers which gave us a rare experience of eating with locals.

Food okay, but authenticity terrific.
author: Sally B.

description:
Chinatown SF can be a scary place if you don't know what you're doing. The place is surrounded by filth--just look up in the apartments above all the restaurants and stores. Thanks to Yelp, I never got sick on the food. We ate here for lunch one day. I'd say it was the best lunch we had in Chinatown.

We ordered the Kung Pao chicken--awesomely flavored and delicious. I had the honey walnut prawns (yum) with a side of perfectly cooked, perfectly sticky steamed rice. We were also served a full pot of jasmine tea. The shrimp tasted fresh---it wasn't SUPER fresh with that amazing "sweet" taste, but it also didn't taste fishy. I was very pleased with the sauce. It was extremely filling and cost $7.95.

The servers were nice enough. The bathroom left a little to be desired--the sink looked like it hadn't been cleaned in a while--yellow spots and hair on it.The restaurant is decorated pretty tacky, but it added to the experience. I would say to go here for a no-frills traditional delicious Chinese meal.
author: Lor L.

description:
If you have a high tolerance for being intimately familiar with what you're eating, and don't mind being the only non-Asian in the place (if you are no Asian, that is), than this is a great place.  The hot pot for two (or three or four or eight...) is fantastic and a really great and unique experience.  For $13, you get $40 worth of food, the only catch being you have to boil it yourself in the bubbling hot pot sitting at the center of your table.  

The service is as to be expected, terse and limited, but the food is very good.  For $26 for two people, we got chicken, chicken livers, beef, oysters, clams, shrimp, dumplings, fishballs, eggs and veggies.  All of it was very good, and the boiling stew made quick work of cooking it all to perfection (and cleaning it too!).  

If there were any downsides, it was that it was rather messy (every try to peel a whole shrimp without getting your hands messy?) and so much was piled onto the table it was hard to find space for your beer and tea, but other than that it was great.

Being a round-eyed white guy, I got a kick out of it and of course loved the fact that I was a spot of bleach in a sea of yellow.  Very good, if you don't mind stepping out of your white washed comfort zone a bit.
author: Eric M.

description: I'm Chinese and this is not good food. TOURIST TRAP. Our "snow pea dish" was 60% celery and the chicken curry claypot was made with rubbery and cheap chicken. Don't bother.
author: Lauren W.

description: The food here was stupid good. Good authentic Chinese food.  The chicken fried rice is some of the best fried rice I've had. The lamb wasn't as good, but certainly a great experience. I definitely recommend this spot.
author: Justin C.

description: For what it is...it is great!  Loved the ginger lobster and walnut shrimp.  Authentic and flavorful!
author: David A.

description:
This is a hole in the wall... really. Walking up the stairs, I thought we were walking into an apartment building. I would have never ever noticed this place... Yes there is a sign outside, but it is on an awning that hangs past the sidewalk and you need to be across the street to see it. Clearly, this business runs on referral.

Had the watercress and garlic. Steamed while gently pan fried... Easily passed my expectations of Chinese food veggie preparation. The flavor was pretty basic, but pleasantly so. The broth was clear and runny as opposed to the usual syrup drenching any taste of the vegetable. Also, we initially asked for snow peas and said they were out, then asked for spinach and they said they were out as well... A little annoying, but a good sign that their produce is fresh.

We also had walnut prawns.  I have had sweet prawns before and they are usually dripping with that white sauce (whatever it is) but these prawns were delicately brushed... A much much better version. The walnuts were candied and succulent. We could have licked the plate.

The seafood clay pot was next... Simple, clean, delicately savory with a obvious but not overbearing ginger. The ginger slices (yellow on the upper right) were cooked perfectly so that both an experienced ginger eater and a not-so seasoned ginger eater enjoyed every bite.

I will definitely be back.
author: Hayley W.

description:
Wow!

This is a fully Chinese experience! The restaurant is as authentic as a Chinese restaurant can be out of China. Pretty much everybody was Chinese there. Ok, let's say 90%. The foods are either exotic or authentic, given that the serve frog (among other things). The food is tasty, the portions big, and the more people in your group, the cheaper the price is. 
Additionally everything is clean, which is something that I value a lot because my previous experiences with Chinese restaurants have not been very nice. Try it!
author: Javi V.

description:
Very authentic and cool experience. Not fancy at all which is what we were searching for. Wife had the lobster with garlic l, she loved it. I had hot and sour soup (fantastic) and lamb clay pot. Sauce in pot was great but the lamb was mostly bone and fat. Actual meat in the pot was great. 

In summary, low end dive with good food. Would not order same pot again but would definitely visit again when back in SF.
author: Mike U.

description: Amazing food. We had the pot stickers, kung pao chicken, and the cashew chicken. My favorite was the cashew chicken. The tea was good and the service was good too. If you find yourself in chinatown, you can't go wrong with this place.
author: Mike K.

description:
Awesome place, just awesome. Go there, get everything. It's cheap, it's delicious, and the old waiter is hilarious. 

I've been there about 6 times and have fairly sworn off every other Chinese place in the city (except sometimes Big Lantern on 16th, because it's two blocks away from me and open til something ridiculous like 2 or 3am.) because Hong Kong Clay Pot is JUST. THAT. GOOD. :)

Do it. Go. Go now.

Mmm... I could use some HKCP myself... nom nom nom.
author: Grace A.

description: Excellent honey-walnut prawns, good kung pao chicken. Great price and a neat hole-in-the-wall vibe.
author: Evan Z.

description: This place was horrible.. Brought out my food cold and then took it back...microwaved it...and brought it back 2 minutes later... Because of this I decided not to leave tip and then  she asked me for tip... Basically saying that what I gave was not acceptable even though it covered the bill
author: Sameer A.

description: Mmm..this felt like an authentic Chinatown dining experience. We got hot and sour soup, bbq pork fried rice, sweet and sour pork, and abalone clay pot with chicken. Yes, we could have been more adventurous...but it was all so delicious! We did notice that all the white people tended to sit in 4-top tables by he windows while the chinese families sat at the big round group tables with the lazy susans in the middles. Ah, Americans, we do like our privacy.
author: Angelique D.

description: Best chinese in SF. For $12.95, get the family style. Have all the grub you could ever want.
author: Nikhil G.

description: Hands down the best Chinese food I've ever had in Chinatown or otherwise for that matter!! I would highly recommend!! We ordered an assortment of dishes, the food come out quickly, hot and the service was great.
author: Jordan A.

description: We ordered the Spicy Jelly Fish for $5.50, Chicken Mushroom and Chinese Sausage Clay Pot for $8.95, and one of the Tofu and Fish Fillet lunch specials for $4.60. The lunch special is plenty food for the low price, and the other two dishes were wonderful! I great find.
author: Zachary H.

description: Simple, cheap, Cantonese cooking. Did I say cheap? Fresh greens and noodles and some seafood for less than a Big Mac and a coke. Dishes served family-style.
author: Gregory M.

description:
This is a great place to go for an authentic chinese meal.  It's a place where local chinese would go for dinner, so that's a great sign for those who wants "real" chinese food.  

We came and ordered the "dinner for 4", which came with about 6 dishes, as well as a soup and dessert, all for 48 bucks!  So definitely worth your money, and the food was pretty good.  Nothing too special but sometimes you just want a simple meal that's tasty and with no surprises!

It's a bit hard to find this place since its upstairs, but once you're there, its defiitely worth the trip.!
author: Leo T.

description:
Service is bad; stairway lead to restaurant is dirty.
But the food is cheap & good.
Lunch special is only $4.26 come with rice & tea if you eat there.
We had #14 Spiced Salted Spareribs,a little bit salty side but flavorful.
#15 Mongolian Beef,also very good.
#19 Eggs with Prawn, a bit plain.
You can't beat the value of their lunch menu.
author: chao-ying w.

description: Lousy service, good food. I know customer service is never a priority at Chinese restaurants, but I draw the line when I've been seated and then completely ignored for 20 minutes. Other than that, the food is very traditional and the serving sizes are very generous.
author: M G.

description: Food, service, and atmosphere are all good & worth the visit. Complimentary green tea is a pleasant, inviting touch :)
author: Becca M.

description:
