We picked this one out through Yelp search.  

We showed up about 5 minutes after the 5:00 pm opening time, and there was already one family seated.  By the time we left, the room was full.  

The three of us ordered a pot of jasmine tea, salt & pepper chicken wings, sweet & sour chicken, a seafood claypot, spareribs chow fun, and 2 sides of steamed rice, for $45 total.  

I believe the primary draw of this place must be the price.  The seafood claypot had some prawns in it, but it was mostly grilled tofu.  The last time I looked, tofu was not a seafood.  The chow fun was tasty, and the noodles were exactly the texture that I expected.  

In the future, we'll keep looking for wider horizons in Chinatown dining.
author: David D.

description: the food was a average here but the service and ambiance worked for me. i had the honey walnut shrimp and like many say they were soft but still edible. however my appetizer was wonton soup and that was also pretth average. i wouldnt say dont go but i imagine their are better options in chinatown
author: Josiah L.

description:
I have been here a number of times, and for the most part I have been happy with the food.

Today, we went here for lunch, ordered, and then waited for forty minutes for the food.  We ordered braised tofu and beef with scrambled egg -- if you order these dishes at, say, Capital Restaurant, they will be out in less than ten minutes.  And we were here before noon.  This is not the place for a quick lunch.

When the food did arrive, we found hair stubble in the egg dish.  Not sure how this happened (haircut right before, shaving in the kitchen, ???), but it was weird.

Two stars because the food is pretty good.  Minus the hair.
author: David C.

description:
After all these years of living in San Francisco and not really spending quality dining-time in Chinatown, I now have THE place to go, and it's Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant. I think that this is the most authentic Chinese food that I've ever eaten. We tried each food group; fish, meat, vegetables and tofu, and each one was pretty darned tasty. 

It's a fairly small restaurant on the second floor, narrow staircase opens up to a large room with multiple family-style tables with gigantic Lazy Susans in the middle (why do they call them Lazy Susans?). The place was packed with several birthday celebrations going on and we had to wait about 10 minutes for a table. You can easily end up on one of the family style tables with assorted other diners, but we ended up getting a nice window table for just us two. 

Just remember to be patient once you sit down. Things can get pretty hectic with all the hustle and bustle of hungry people.....and it's well worth the wait. Chinatown here we come.
author: Mickey A.

description:
Today our trip to Chinatown was going so well that we figured why not ruin it four seconds after it started by eating horrible, MSG-laden, Yelp-approved Chinese food.

For serious... we were so stoked to do some goofy tourist-like gawking at the cheaply made, over-priced trinkets and instead ended up clutching our stomachs and butt cheeks in a desperate attempt to keep from crashing and bleeding out in the middle of Grant Ave.

Greasy, salty read:SALTY, sub-mediocre dishes containing that elusive McDonald's circa 1984 quality "chicken" scrambled up with semi-fresh veggies in brown sauce.  That's a perfect description of what you'll be eating at this place.  BARF.
author: Blake C.

description:
Went there with my friend who was visiting me from Hawaii.  She and I always eat Dim Sum or Pho and argue about which place is better as far as food etc.  She last visited me about 5 or 6 months ago, during which time she ate here and said the Dim Sum was great.  She wanted to go back so I could see how it is.

They are apparently called Hong Kong Clay Pot, again.  And they no longer serve Dim Sum according to the man walking around supervising all the girls.  

A somewhat smaller restaurant, it had a lot of flavor though.  Though we were disappointed there was no dim sum, I had what I believe was called the salt and pepper crabs and she had the lobster.  Both were excellent.  

Also, they had what I would consider some of the best made ong choi that I have had in a long time, and thats usually the first thing I order when I eat chinese.  

I definitely ate pretty good.  Its a little pricey for what I am used to, but it was definitely worth it.  .

I will eat here again.
author: Soh Jai R.

description: good stuff, don't often eat in chinatown, good spot to eat, good food!
author: christopher h.

description:
Cleanliness .....not very clean. Everything looked old and unkempt. We go to a lot of Asian restaurants....this one was not that clean.

Food.....sub par. We ordered spare rib chow fun and chicken clay pot. There were literally 5 small meat pieces. The clay pot had so much onion pieces, I could barely make out the chicken! Why skimp on ingredients and screw over ur customers?

Service.....just OK. 

Net net.....nothing remarkable about this pace and sub par food. Pass....there are so many better food joints in San Francisco!
author: Charles J.

description:
Was here on Thursday, everything was sooo nice, had to make it twice... and came back again on Friday.  

Excellent authentic Chinese food at a really, and I mean really, reasonable prices.  And the portions were just right.  Not too much, but not so little that you leave still feeling hungry.

So far we have tried the Beef Stew Claypot, the Seafood Claypot, the Spicy Salty Pork Chops, and the Chicken with Green Beans.  All were perfectly cooked and yummy.  I have no complaints here.  And for entertainment, just observe the Chinese crowd around your table.  They are characters!

For sure we will come back again.
author: Dean N.

description:
couldn't find a better "walnut shrimp" anywhere else.
 so far the best Chinese place for me and my friends. 
the place is small so it's warm (can get hot sometimes) and the servers are all nice.
author: Toan N.

description:
The service was slooooow and sporadic. We sat for almost 15 minutes at our table before the waitress even came by to say hello. While ordering, the waitress kept trying to push additional items with each one I ordered. (I lost count of how many time she asked if we wanted sweet and sour pork). 

The food was okay. The ginger crab had very little edible meat. The walnut prawns were actually the tastiest dish we ordered. 

I would give it another try, but my first visit was not impressive.
author: David B.

description:
Again with the Chinese restaurants, one day after my fabulous dinner at Jade Garden, I came here who is also another great restaurant! I initially chose this place because of the great reviews by the yelpers, but I guess what really closed the deal was that the restaurant is owned by one of my former cadet's family.

We came here as a party of 18 with reservations ahead of time because of our connections, nah they treat everyone the same! Haha, well imagine a bunch of rowdy Chinese kids in a nice restaurant, the hell of it. 

There is an average flight of stairs leading you up to the restaurant itself and everyone was ready as they said it would be. We actually came here for dinner, not really expecting much but for a good time.

We were immediately greeted by the boss, and she was very kind to us and served us with great speed. We chose the family dinner for 8 for both the tables, which was $88. So that's about $11 per person.

The family dinner consisted of a broth, chicken, catfish, peppered pork, honey walnut shrimp, crab, lobster, beef, vegetables, and dessert. It was definitely worth it!

Because I am Chinese, none of this is new to me, but I can safely say that all my team members had a great time and definitely ate their money's worth.

Will definitely have to come back for another team dinner!
author: Jenny L.

description:
Yelpsters you've done it again-Another fine eatery in a land i'm a stranger to.  I'll wrap it up short and sweet-this place has fabulous food and quick friendly service. The tea!  Oh the tea!  Hibiscus I think. Hot leaf tea. I could have left after the tea and been happy but no; I stayed for the hot & sour soup, Peking ribs and Kung pao chicken. Boring but safe choices. Next time the seafood clay pot for sure. The place is a hole in the wall up the stairs over looking China Town.  Nothing fancy. A hot fresh meal for $5!
Just good food. I'm afraid that I'll never be able to eat "Chinese" food again unless I have the real stuff from China Town.
author: Kalipo K.

description: What a great little place to grub! I had the chicken sausage and mushroom clay pot and it was delicious. The service was fast and friendly, we were seated the moment a table became open (which could possibly be a while due to the tiny dining space) and the food was brought out quickly and hot. Very authentic as well.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Came Sunday evening just after they opened for dinner service. Place was empty so no waiting required. Ordered the duck claypot, catfish claypot and the spinach with garlic. All delicious home style authentic chinese cooking. Lots of bones in the catfish claypot but otherwise it was all good.
Ambiance was typical chinese with lots of the wait staff yelling at each other in full blown cantonese. ohh my ears...
author: Michael C.

description: If you go here, don't make the mistake of asking for your food without MSG. We did this, and what we ended up getting was just vegetables sautéed in butter. Not very appetizing. The service was fairly slow, and we were in general disappointed with the meal. I expect their MSG containing foods are somewhat better, however it should be possible to make good Chinese food without MSG.
author: Ryan P.

description: A solid Yelp recommendation. We got there for an early lunch which was lucky as it really fills up after 12. Efficient, friendly service and really decent food. We tried the salt and pepper duck tongues (which were delicious once we figured out how to eat around the bone in the middle), the ginger crab, and the ox tail clay pot. Everything thing was great and well priced. We will definitely be back!
author: Allison K.

description: We were window shopping and souviner shopping on Grant Avenue in Chinatown. With the help of Yelp, we found HKCP. The service was friendly and attentive. The fried quail appetizer was cooked perfectly! Yum! We also enjoyed the sauteed clams w/ginger. The curry chicken clay pot was ok, I was looking for a little more curry flavor. All in all a very positive experience for a VERY reasonable price!
author: Phyllis M.

description:
Very casual Chinese restaurant in Chinatown.  The staff were very friendly and the service was good.  Kids found the food to be quite tasty as did the adults.  I don't know how authentic tasting the meal really is, but found everything to be quite flavorful.

After a full meal, with no room to spare we were handed a bill for about $50.  This is quite reasonable considering we also ordered two appetizers (pot stickers and fried prawns). 

I asked our waitress what she recommended and she stated the walnut prawns.  I ordered those and found them to be quite delicious.  My daughter ordered broccoli beef and the broccoli was described as "Chinese broccoli" and it resembled kale: these veggies stole the show and everyone enjoyed that dish.

Nice environment.  Quick service.  Good tasting food.  Good prices.  I will bring family back when we revisit SF.
author: Gerry G.

description: We enjoyed a very nice meal in a very casual surrounding. The salt and pepper quail for $6.50 is a steal. Also had the green bean dish with prawns and salt and pepper pork spareribs tht were very good. Had a chicken mushroom and chinese sausage claypot which was rather ordinary. chiken was a bit dry and not enough mushrooms.
author: Peter H.

description: "Meh" pretty much describes this.  Had the XO beans and seafood clay pot.  The also have us a free starter veggie chicken broth soup and a black sesame seed dessert soup... Both were bland.  Seafood was also bland but at least wasn't overcooked.  Beans were a big portion size and had decent flavor.  Overall, it wasn't anything better than we get in Boston...
author: Ken Y.

description: Im not going to lie... the entrance from the street kind of sketched me out a little and I almost didnt go.  Once you climb the stairs it was much more welcoming.  The service was slow with only one server working but the food was really good and the portions were so large I couldn't even finish my lunch!  Very authentic!
author: Chip B.

description:
Initially I wanted to try Hang Ah Tea Room when my boyfriend and I first got to San Francisco, but unfortunately they closed early. Looked it up on yelp and of course, Hongkong clay pot was supposedly  the next best thing that was in Chinatown.
Hotel Astoria, which is where we stayed in, is situated right next to Chinatown. At 8 pm, we braved the streets and walked through Chinatown. It gets very sketchy at this time of the night, so it's best that you hold on to your purses and expensive belongings as hobos, weirdoes and muggers come out of the woodwork.
The restaurant was very easy to find. You just keep going down Grant Ave. From Bush st. And eventually you will see it on your right.
The restaurant is upstairs. It's quite small, but has a very homey feel to it. It felt like going to a family dinner. The staff was very nice, and our waitress was very friendly.
The food was great. We had shrimp fried rice and shrimp chow mein, and some fried wontons. They give you a pretty decent amount of food, my boyfriend and I were pretty full at the end.
I recommend this restaurant to anyone who is visiting Chinatown.
author: Samantha L.

description:
When I walk into a Chinese restaurant, I could see how the hostess might want to run into the kitchen and switch out the chopsticks for forks, suggest a sweet and sour chicken for my bland Western palate and dust off the Fortune cookies.

It's understandable and thoughtful, but for my family not necessary. They've all lived in China and were a little insulted to be pegged as frequenters of Panda Express. As if! We were the only folks gifted with fortune cookies at the end of the meal, for instance and on another occasion when we ordered a clay pot were told we wouldn't like it.

Regardless of the hand-holding, in my opinion, the food is great and it's also really cheap. Two things, when combined that get high marks in my book.
author: Eli B.

description:
This little restaurant hidden in the heart of ChinaTown is a gem. You do not expect much from the outside, but once you walked in you know you are in the right place.  The place is always packed, but the waiting time is not too long (especially when you come between 6 & 6.30).
The service can be on the slower site, but the food is incredible.

We ordered Pot Stickers (delicious dumplings filled with a mixture of meat and veg, not too soft, not to dry, just right), Spring Rolls (the best I have ever eaten - Crispy on the outside but tasteful and crunchy on the inside), Beef Broccoli (a must if you love soy sauce), Pork Sweet & Sour (one of the best I have ever eaten, just yummy and delicious) and Snow Pea Sprouts w/ Garlic (my mouth is still watering thinking about these).

All in all a fantastic dinner which always leaves you with an aftertaste of - I want more =-).
author: Angelika R.

description:
Best CHINESE FOOD in SF Chinatown. If you haven't been here, you're really missing out! They have the best bittermelon and your choice of meat with black bean sauce! Great salted peppered fried chicken wings! Great chinese spinach! Just try everything, I'm pretty sure you'll be satisfied. 
Go during their morning hours and until 3pm hour, they have special prices for certain dishes. It'll be worth it. About 4.75 or something for a nice portion on a plate. If you order three dishes, it'll be good enough for 3-4 people.
author: Annie H.

description:
I used to live in SF for awhile and always thought it was hard to find a good place to eat in chinatown.  I check yelp to find something nearby and nothing really stood out.  This place had a pretty good rating so we decided to try it out.  

We went there for a quick lunch on our first day back in SF and it was pretty solid.  Family flew in later in the week and on our last day we were looking for food near our hotel before the flight out.  We came back here and ordered several dishes and had a family style brunch.  I'm from the U.S. but the 5 others in my group were all Taiwanese.  We all thought the meal was delicious and were satisfied before hopping on our plane.  I forget what we ordered; actually they did all the ordering so it's more that I didn't understand what was ordered.  I think it was some sort of set meal for 4 people - $48 for 6 dishes.
author: Michael N.

description: Totally local. The best kind of hole in the wall. Simple and tasty.
author: S And B D.

description:
3.5 stars
Totally a legit place to eat in Chinatown. Ben and I came here on Friday Night after combing the stores on Grant Street. The service is kind of shoddy, for instance, the old man forgot to bring us tea until about 15 min. later when i asked and even then he seemed cranky to bring it to us. Part of the charm of eating in a chinese resturant I think haha. 

We tried ginger crab and the tofu chicken clay pot. Both were delishhhhhcious! Its up in the cuts, but also, part also part of the "charm." 

Left with happy full bellies. Parking is non-existant but at night time can be found within 6 blocks.
author: Amy S.

description: busy during mid autumn festival.  chinese family focused.  probably didn't order their best stuff since had chicken wings, beef chow fun, string beans xo sauce, and fish fillet tofu clay pot but overall ok. didn't see HK rice claypots.
author: Rob C.

description:
May not be the cleanest restaurant in San Francisco, but the food is delicious!  Soup, Seafood, Clay Pot, Canton and Hunan Style Dishes, Noodles and Rice... Yumm-O!

Decent prices and there's no skimping on the portions served.  2 people, 2 dishes (Kung Pao Chicken & Honey Walnut Prawns), soup and rice... lots of leftovers!  The food was so good that it tasted even better the next day, straight from my fridge -- no heating required on the prawns and the walnut stayed crunchy.  

Family Style options are also available, set dishes, set prices.  Open for lunch and dinner, but closed on Wednesday!

Would definitely be back to eat here again very soon...!
author: Celeste M.

description:
Got take out here over the weekend and had a less than stellar experience.  However, the last time I ate in..i had a good time. so the average between my 4 and 1 start experience, I give it a 2.5 star.  

I'm pretty sure the restaurant violate all kinds of fire safety hazards as its packed to the brim and the cubby hold of a restaurant, but i all adds to the flavor that is this place.

I see most folks going for the Hot Pot dinners, but Ive only had their a la carte dishes.  Portions are big and food is good.  Biggest complaint is the service.  I recommend the water cress w/ garlic dish ($6.50) and walnut prawns.  They are known for their clay pots, so I'd try a few of those too.

The whole operation is horribly runned (they make dishes not by order, but try to collect similar dishes and cook it all at once..which means you wait a LONG time for all the dishes to arrive and tables rarely clear).  My take out order took 40 min to prepare...unheard of in a chinese restaurant.  They messed up my order TWICE but let me keep the the soup they made by accident for free. 

I think ~3 stars is about right...i'll come back again an see if they can get their act together and bump it up a few.
author: Kendra W.

description:
Deeeelish! 

My uncle and little cousins were in from out of town and since they live in San Antonio, they don't get to eat good Chinese food very often.  After reading the reviews I decided this would be the place to take them.  They were blown away by how yummy everything was!  We ordered the pot stickers, fried shrimp, salt and pepper wings, spicy jelly fish, sweet and sour pork, mongolian beef, chicken fried rice, seafood clay pot and 4 icy cold beers.  Sounds like a lot, but there were 6 of us.  Total bill came to $75 plus tip.  Ah-mazing!  

Will definitely return and have already recommended it to all my coworkers.
author: Paola N.

description:
I usually get iffy when businesses in Chinatown hands out flyers trying to lure people (mostly tourists) to their restaurant.  In this case, there's an elderly man handing out flyers outside the restaurant and people usually would not care and ignore him, which is a great thing for me and my friends because it keeps the place less busy and we can eat our humongous meal in relative peace.

On weekday lunch, the crowd varies from older generation Chinese, to some tourists that are actually smart enough to eat here, and working people like me that make the trek from the Financial District to Chinatown. 

Cheap, fast and good portions for a good price. As others have mentioned, order the seafood clay pot and you won't be disappointed. We usually get their salt and pepper chicken wings which I love. Also, LOVE the braised tofu that they put on their clay pot dishes. Make sure to bring your friends, some cash (although I think they take Visa/Mastercard), and your appetite. And order the lunch specials but family style (not with rice), I believe they won't charge you extra. Eat up!
author: Rachelle Q.

description:
I was told by Michael C that this place has the best clay pots in Chinatown. Better than Bow Hon and better than most places in San Francisco. Given that he has been working in Chinatown for the last 30 years, I trusted him. There are no clay pots over rice here. It's just clay pots without the rice. You really shouldn't call it Hong Kong Clay Pot then. You should call it Hong Kong Clay Pot without the rice 

The food is really good here but like any Chinatown restaurants it is a bit on the hole in the wall, not as clean, borderline shady side. Overall the food is good and cheap. 

We ordered 
Pork with mustard green with salted egg soup(the best I have ever had) 

Spicy Chicken wings (average)
 
bitter melon and chicken with black bean sauce (if you are into this then this is very good)
 
Oxtail clay pot (a bit tough but the tofu in it was great)
 
black bean sauce clams ( one of the best sauces I have ever had) 

Total bill was 48 dollars.
author: jason g.

description:
As you walk closer and closer to this place, you'd think it'd be an SF Chinatown tourist trap, but then you realize you have to walk up a flight of stairs and aren't sure if the restaurant is to the left or the right.  Then you look around, realize that everyone there is speaking Cantonese, and figure out that it's probably going to be somewhat authentic.  Then you open up the menu and see the misspellings sprinkled throughout and you know that this is a fairly authentic place.

Our meal started with a ginseng and pork spare rib soup which worked nicely on a cool SF evening.  We order quite a bit of food for five people, including a fish clay pot (pretty good), lobster (not bad), walnut shrimp (okay), stir fried vegetables (okay), and steamed chicken (a little overcooked, but decent flavor).  

The food here was good, but not fantastic though the price is definitely very reasonable.  Parking around the area can be tricky depending on the time of day, but I lucked out and got a spot right around the corner on Jackson.  I'd probably come back again if I were trying to eat something on Grant Street, but might not drive back to Chinatown for dinner.  Yuet Lee, down the road, serves up similar fare that's a bit better.  If you can get a table and are willing to spend a bit more, R and G Lounge is definitely your best choice.
author: Josh H.

description:
This place was a 4 star on food and value, but lost points in other key areas:

Service - Although she was prompt, she was not friendly, did not smile, and walked up to the table chewing food twice.

In addition, I bit down on a staple in my tender greens, most likely from the vegetable's packaging. If I had swallowed it, I could have seriously jacked up my insides.

I wish I could give a better rating because the food was very tasty, the tea was perfect and to get lunch specials for only $4.60 is insanity!
author: C B.

description:
I have been here a few times and am confident to say that this is one of the better places to eat in Chinatown.  The quality is great and the prices are reasonable.

Many people reviewing this restaurant have praised the seafood claypot, and rightly so.  There were generous portions of succulent squid, scallops and shrimp and it was overall, quite yummy.  

We also tried the braised tofu clay pot, fried pea sprouts with garlic, ginger crab, and salt and pepper pork spare ribs.  While these dishes weren't nearly in the same league as the seafood claypot dish, they were still very solid options.

Service was fine and we ended up paying $17.50 for a tasty, yet filling meal.
author: Bowdoin S.

description: Very reasonable price with big portion! Complimentary house soup and dessert! Unbeatable!!
author: William C.

description:
It's what they call one of those "hole in the wall" places. Actually, the ambience was good for a "hole in the wall". 

I took my date (who was previously unimpressed with Chinatown restaurants) here for more authentic Chinese cuisine and fresher seafood in Chinatown on a budget. The seafood claypot met our expectations.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I really liked this restaurant a lot.  It's a little hard to find--look for the sign and, apparently, there's usually a man standing at the bottom of the stairs telling people to go up there.  

I really wanted to try a lot of the food on the menu but I only have one stomach.  I ordered the Quail in Clay Pot which was really amazing.  I love ginger and galangal and there was a lot  of galangal in the dish.  My wife ordered the Kung Pao Chicken which neither she nor I was amazed with.  It wasn't bad; it just wasn't anything special.  I have a feeling that all of the food in the clay pots is really good although some of the other reviews say how good other food is.  I really want to order the dinner for 4 when some other people come and eat with us.

I'm not going to complain about servers unless they're just terrible people.  Our server was constantly running around to make sure that everyone was eating their food and had something to drink.  I really like it when servers don't come by your table 400 times asking if you need more whatever.  We had to ask him for extra napkins and water and he brought all of it right away.  

If there weren't so many restaurants in San Francisco, I would totally go back there immediately.
author: Jack T.

description:
After reading reviews wanted to give this place a try. From the reviews I was expecting worse in everything but the food quality. It's not the nicest place, but looks clean and is alright. The place was almost full but wasn't really loud. Able to have normal volume convo with the other four people at my table. Waiter was nice and service was good. Real friendly staff.

I got the seafood in clay pot and really enjoyed it. Friends got pan fried noodles with chicken and kung pow and it was also very good. Really decent prices. Went out for coffee and dessert somewhere else after this and spent the same amount there as I did here. I live close by so I will return and try new dishes. I think I found my new go to place in Chinatown.
author: Wes K.

description: Talk about a hole in the wall! Almost literally!!! Passed it twice and didn't see it. Its just a set of stairs in between a few vendors. Look for it using the address! Once you get to the top of the stairs, you enter a small little restaurant. Very tight! but its authentic! Food was pretty good! The reviews on yelp were pretty accurate. I'm not sure about the women's bathroom, but the guys was TINY.
author: F P.

description: I read through the reviews, found the location on a busy Saturday night and was placed at large table with two other couples. Ok, communal seating, fine. I ordered 2 beers, steamed rice, salt and pepper shrimp, and a beef stew hot pot. I was served two beers and hot tea first. As the lady cleaned the table and the tea cups with the same dirty tag, I passed on the tea. Then 2 minutes later came a small plate of shrimp...ten minutes later, some rice, and then 5 minutes after that a beef stew clay pot. Very strange way of serving as the shrimp were cold by now. The shrimp we ok, much more salty than peppery, and the beef stew should be called tripe and tofu stew because that made up 80 percent of the dish. I'll definitely pass on this place next time in China town.
author: ian c.

description: I came here with three friends (2 asian, 1 white) and our waiter lady saw him and offered him a fork instead of the usual chopsticks. We refused because he's actually a world class chopstick user, but she came back a minute later and was like "just in case!" and dropped two forks on our table and ran away. We almost died crying.
author: Jonathan H.

description:
This place is by far the best Chinese restaurant I have ever eaten at! We were in San Francisco for Labor Day week and we found Clay Pot via a search through Yelp. The reviews are spot on! So amazing and the price, you just can't beat it. 

My friend decided to order a highly reviewed item, the Honey Walnut Prawns....OH MY GOD!!!!!!!!! The best dish ever!!!!! My husband really wanted some salt and pepper squid, it wasn't on the lunch menu but our waiter said they'd make it anyway. The best salt and pepper squid in the world!!! Sadly I can't remember the other two dishes ordered because it's been a while, but I know they were good. Clearly the Honey Walnut Prawns and the Salt and Pepper squid were the stars. 

I highly highly highly recommend going here on your next visit to Chinatown in San Francisco! You will not be disappointed!
author: Angie H.

description:
Seafood clay pot sounds delicious... LOVE seafood plus I heard it's a popular choice.  The pot is here and filled with sponge size tofu, like 12 pieces and like 10 whole garlics!  BARF!  (among 4 pieces of shrimp, 4 scallops, and large cuts of squid????)
The menu doesn't even have a description!

staff is very friendly
author: Mimi P.

description: The place was packed! They took our reservation for 12 people. After we all got seated our server felt bad for us because we all looked "squishy" sitting around one table. So she cleared out 2 tables next to each other to make us more "comfy". BTW- did I mention the food was excellent.
author: Allen S.

description: I wanted good chinese food while staying in Chinatown during my most recent trip to San Francisco. This place was just down the street from my hotel and it served well. Good soup! Good service!
author: Paul G.

description:
Gross. 

I went with a group of people. We ordered the family meal that serves 8. It came with catfish, crab, beef ribs, steamed chicken, soup, one veggie and spring rolls. 

I ate the rice and spring rolls for dinner. 

Too much corn starch in the soup (with tofu, and who knows what else).

Everyone else seemed to like it. I am too polite to bitch about food when I'm eating it. I'll wait for Yelp. 

We got there at 6:00pm and got a table immediately. Around 7:00, there was a line out the door. In order to access the restaurant, you have to walk up a flight of stairs. The restroom inside is bizarre as it says for women only...and you have to enter it through a curtain. It's not particularly clean. 

I honestly thought it was the worst Chinese I've ever had. It was greasy and just...gross.
author: Hilary A.

description: Simple Chinese food. Tofu mushroom vege claypot, and shrimp fried rice (had a bunch of shredded lettuce! and egg). Pretty good!
author: Clarissa L.

description: The food was excellent and the service was pretty good. it's kind of hidden away (on the second floor and all) but once you're in you'll notice the aromas are kind of heavenly and everyone there seemed to really be enjoying themselves.
author: Jesse M.

description: I saw the review on yelp and thought I would give this place a try. This place completes my Chinese foods experience in SanFran. I saw a lot of Chinese families there having dinner so I knew I came to the right place.  I really enjoyed the clay pot dish and the salt and pepper crab. Worth a visit!!!
author: Violet K.

description: We had a party of 25 and everyone went away happy! Was impressed with freshness & tastiness of each dish. All the entries were very light & everything was cooked perfectly. Very clean & service was good, too! Try a clay pot dish!
author: Jane A.

description: This is an amazing, low-end hidden venue, stairs going up to a 2nd floor right off the street. Always packed with Chinese families. If you have a group, you can eat a dinner for 8, for example, at $10-15 a head, which includes lobster and some other remarkable dishes--most notably the ginger chicken. Superb quality for the price.
author: Jan J.

description:
This is the place to go for clay pots! I used to come here frequently with my family. Everything on the menu is delicious, especially the pigeon clay pot. It's a Chinatown gem. And definitely a yes. 

Nom nom nom!
author: Regina L.

description: We were on a city tour and someone had mentioned that she really enjoyed the food here. We yelped it and decided to come by here and eat before leaving back to Southern Cal. This place is very hidden. There's just a yellow sign and a door that has stairs that leads up to the restaurant. Walking in, it felt like you were walking into someone's studio (meaning someone's home). There were just 2 other tables that were occupied when we came. Since there were 6 of us...we decided to get the $88 for 8 people combo. We got there about 11:30. By the time we were done eating, the whole place was completely filled with people waiting to be seated. The food was good and the service was great. Definitely worth coming back and eating again when I'm up in the Bay area.
author: Cindy V.

description: Excellent food. I went with my husband and parents.  We each ordered something completely different and everyone LOVED all of the food. I highly recommend the walnut prawns and the curry chicken clay pot.  I'm usually not a fan of Chinese food because of the grease.  That's not a problem here.  Everything is well cooked and flavorful, but NOT GREASY. Only criticism was the service.  It wasn't bad....food came quickly.  They just were not very hospitable.  We had our sixteen month old daughter with us.  I asked for milk and they did not have any.  Still, it was a great meal and I WILL go back!
author: Kristen F.

description: The wait was over an hour at 8pm. We got in at 7, after 30 minutes. But every minute was worth it! Excellent Chinese, and the clay pits looked awesome (missed it unfortunately).
author: Jason M.

description:
Went here the other day for lunch and the specials menu is a great deal.  Most of the items are around $4.60, making lunch very cheap.  

We ended up getting the pork porridge, salt and pepper chicken, tender greens with prawns, and salt and pepper spareribs.  The porridge is a heaping portion for the price, although there's little meat in it.  The salt and pepper items at lunch weren't as well flavored as they were at dinner the other time and the tender greens with prawns were on par with the rest of the places in the area.

For a quick lunch in Chinatown that's got food at a great price, Hong Kong Clay Pot is your place.  I'd go back for lunch when I'm in the area.
author: Kelvin V.

description:
Best Chinese lunch deal around!

A couple co-workers and I decide to make the quick trek to Chinatown for a weekday lunch...we dine here for the first time and were impressed with price for the quality you get.  We split our bill and it came out to be $5.75 including tip!  We even had some leftovers!

We ordered the lunch rice plate specials:
* Ox Tail w/ Mushrooms (this item should be re-named to "Ox Tail w/ Tofu garnished w/ Mushroom" because there were only 2 pieces of mushrooms and lots of fried tofu)
* String Beans w/ Chicken (my favorite dish that day...had black bean sauce.....yum!)
* Tofu w/ Prawns (lots of prawns and tofu)

Although the menu said rice plate, the rice came in a separate bowl and the items were served family style so we were able to share everything with ease.

Place wasn't busy, probably due to its location on the 2nd level.  I'd definitely be back, but I think I'll order the String Bean w/ Chicken just for myself =)
author: Michelle N.

description: My mom and I have ate here twice and both times we were impressed.  Its nothing fancy just plain good food.  Both times we got Pan Fried Noodles with Shrimp and Kung Pao Chicken.  Its just so good.  We were one of the few non Asian costumers who were given forks, but oh well.  We went in the summer time and found out they had a fire and were closed.  Not sure if this is still true.  Recommend this place to any traveler.
author: Michelle C.

description: Great food, great prices, nice people. I love this place. The fish filet clay pot is really good. Also, the Mandarin chicken and prawns. I think everything here would be really good. Probably the best option in Chinatown.
author: Malvika S.

description:
Coming here I felt like I was in someone's house having dinner.  It's a small restaurant up one flight of stairs that I immediately felt comfortable in.

The service was great.  They were friendly and quick.  The food was great as well.  It was hot, fresh, and tasty.  

We had the beef broccoli (chinese broccoli), chicken chow mein, honey walnut prawns (YUM), snow pea greans (weedy), spring rolls, and pot stickers.

For me personally, this place would be a 2 or 3 ONLY because I'm picky and like my Americanized Chinese food.  But, because I cannot complain about the quality or taste of ANYTHING we had it gets the 4.

Definitely would eat here again.
author: Jennifer M.

description:
Other than those steep steps up and down the restaurant which is a knee killer,  I really enjoy this spot...

First of all, the soup is basically flavorless, but it comes in a large bowl.  One time, there was a unspecified penis floating around in my soup.  Rest assured, I didn't partake...

I like the tofu with chicken with rice.   This place gives you a whole container of rice with your meal.   The tofu is fresh, just the way I like it...

It's closed on Wednesdays...

The pot stickers are decent...

The kung pao chicken is tasty, but they seem to put a whole red onion into it...  Next time AY orders this dish less the onions...

The tea is usually hot,  which is a good thing...

Michael C. turned me on to this joint.   There's a ton of  Michael C.'s on this site.   He's on my friends list which has less than ten people...

The lunch special is a measly $4.60.  You can get out of this dive for 6 bones and that includes a buck tip which is 20%.  

A good spot for budget minded eaters...
author: Randal P.

description: I am not a big eater but one clay pot did not fill me up at all. I love frog clay pot but they told me I had to wait 30min for it because they had to go buy it so I just ordered the Chinese sausage (which I didn't really want).
author: Annie Y.

description: Good and cheap Chinese food, definitely a solid option for Chinese food. They have lots of good dishes for lunch, with most rice plates being just $6. Try their chicken with brokoli or beef chow fun
author: Try E.

description:
My co-worker always talks about place..so we decided to check it out for lunch today. In front of the stairway to the resturant (its on the 2nd floor, so you have to go up the stairs) a old chinese man is greeting you and handing out menus. We got there right at noon time, and we got seated pretty quickly. Everyone that's eating there are the local old school chinese people.

The lunch menu is great -$4.60 each! We ordered the beef stew (which came with fried tofu and mushrooms) and the bittermelon w/beef. It dosnt come in the usual: half entree, half rice plate - they give u a giant bowl of rice, then we get our two plates of food! Of course they are lunch sized portions..but they give you a good amt of food! Some other people around me were ordering full sized portions and they were HUGE! I mean one regular portion could easily feed 2 people! The food was super tasty and not oily like some other chinese places! While you are waiting for your food they also bring you some plain soup stock for you to drink. Total bill came out to exactly $10 bucks. and we had at least another meal to bring home (which we did take in a to-go box).

This isn't your fancy americanized style chinese food here. It's straight up traditional cantonese style chinese food. I reccommend coming here with more people and sharing the plates of foods! All the plates, cups, bowls and chopsticks we used were clean too. And there was a good flow of people eating and picking up to-go orders- def. a good sign of a good restaurant.
author: Betty S.

description: We ate thee last night because our first choice was hosting a red egg party (New Asia on Pacific Avenue).  The food was bland and the service was mediocre.  Portions were small.  We left hungry but did not want to order more food since we did not enjoy eating there.  I was born and raised in SF Chinatown and so expected so much more.  This may be good for tourist but not for locals.
author: Rob N.

description: We went to San Fransisco several years ago. The China town in San Fransisco though small is much cleaner than ours. The restaurants are cleaner as well. Maybe I enjoyed it more because it wasn't in NYC in our filthy China town. The service was gracious and warm. I had a lamb hot pot and my husband had a bitter melon dish. I did read some complaints about cleanliness. In San Fransisco you are spoiled. The restaurants here are filthy. Hong Kong Clay Pot was clean compared to anything in any of our China towns. Anyway it was a treat for us. Though as  I said  it could have changed since we went it was good when we went! If it was in NYC I would give it 5 stars but I have come to expect higher quality from San Fransisco. It would be great for NYC and mediocre for San Fransisco. I hate to admit anything is better than here but it is!
author: Pinky And The B.

description:
I know you're not supposed to go to Chinatown for Chinese food, but I wanted rice, and we were too hungry to take the bus to the Richmond District. We wanted to try R & G but the wait was 45 minutes on a Sunday night. We read some good reviews about Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant and ended up here. 

Food was meh. Portions are small. Service was borderline not rude, unlike other trendy Chinese restaurants in the area (which are completely rude).  The Seafood Clay Pot was disappointing, with chewy squid, maybe four tiny shrimp, and huge squares of tofu. Dish was bland. The Kung Pao Prawns had about 5 small prawns hidden in the onions. Hot and Sour Soup was good... very spicy. We asked the server for water three times, before we even got the food, and each time he gave us a curt nod. Food came. We asked the other server for water and she gave us a polite nod. Sipped the spicy soup. Finally, we asked a third server for water which she delivered promptly. If you're ordering spicy food and know you'll need liquid, better order a beer or soda -- something you pay for -- they'll probably give that to you right away.

Boyfriend accidentally grazed his finger on the scalding clay pot as soon as it was delivered, and I heard the sizzle  (I guess they figure that you know not to touch it, so unlike other restaurants they don't bother warning you that it's hot).  

Price was ok, but I was still hungry afterwards. Won't go back.
author: C Anne D.

description: a hole in the wall. ABSOLUTELY AUTHENTIC. i say this as a true chinese, cantonese to be specific. the price is so worth it. everything i tried were fantabulous. lunch special was so cheap and delicious i absolutely recommend it.  the place was small tho. every time i leave the place was full and people need to wait in lines. ate here 3 times during my 13-day trip in san fran. you must come!
author: Ruby L.

description: I stumbled upon this place one day by the toothless man at the bottom of the stairs handing out menus. You have to walk up stairs to get to this place. Every time I've eaten here its been delicious. The pot stickers are great, the honey walnut prawns are great, and the dishes with the clay pot are so good
author: Isabella E.

description: Super delicious and authentic Chinese food. And the other reviews are absolutely right, the Honey Walnut Prawns are incredible. Other than that, just order a few different entrees and share them. You won't be disappointed.
author: Matt D.

description: Clay pots are quite tasty. Although I preferred the other dishes (chicken was especially awesome)
author: Nick W.

description: Thanks to Yelp, I had lunch here, and enjoyed every moment of the experience.  We were the only people speaking English in the place, which just added to the charm.  The food was tasty (we had string beans with prawns and Mongolian beef, both fantastic), fresh, and served hot and quick.  One of the best parts, lunch for two cost us only $13 (including tip)!!  After paying $3 for a stinking 8 oz. bottle of coke on the Wharf, this was such a nice change of pace.
author: Deanna T.

description:
Relatively good and cheap Chinese food. This place is kind of hidden away due to it having a small entrance and being located up a flight of stairs. Despite that, people seem to find this place just fine. Came in here a little early to beat the dinner crowd so the wait to sit down wasn't too long. By the end of the night the place was packed and the hustlin and bustlin of a typical Chinese restaurant began to commence. I guess they anticipate large groups coming in, because a party of 4 came in, but only a few big tables remained. They ended up having to wait for one of the smaller tables to open up instead of being seated at one of the larger tables that might fit about 8 or so people. 

The food here was simply delightful. All of the food was flavorful, but not over seasoned, not too greasy, and had generous portions. I ended up ordering the house special chow mein, honey walnut prawns, and mongolian beef.  The honey walnut prawns were my favorite. Generous portion of both walnut and prawns. Unlike other places, the sauce was not too thick or too sweet, but just perfect. Also, the chow mein had an ample supply of mixed meat and was not overly greasy. I hate how sometimes you order chow mein and it's like your slurping up oiled noodles... nasty. The mongolian beef was just OK, i've had better. All in all, it was good and I would definitely return. Service was kind of slow once seated, and despite it being a small room two of the workers decided they wanted to talk to each other.... ACROSS THE ROOM. So here I have one lady screaming right next to my table and then from the other end having another guy screaming back at her. I guess it's kind of expected and typical, but geez.
author: Steven T.

description: Not very impressed.  We ordered stir-fried beans, clam and wine soup, clay pot lamb, and honey walnut prawns.  Our clay pot lamb turned into ox tail somewhere along the way, and the other dishes were not that great at all - kinda brown and mushy.  However, the restaurant was slammed tonight because of the Chinese New Year celebrations.   Still, the food was very underwhelming and the service was mediocre at best.
author: Danny W.

description:
I have to give Hong Kong Clay Pot 4 stars. I have tried taking my in laws to many restaurants. It is hard to meet their expectations because they go out a lot and they have high expectations for Chinese food (taste, price and value). I came here with my friends last week bec' my girlfriend heard great things about this place, so we decided to check it out. We ordered the pot stickers, seafood clay pot, steam oysters in black bean sauce, bittermelon frog, noodles with mushrooms and scallion lobster. All the food met my expectation. The lobster was fresh and the meat even tastes sweet. Service was ok (typical asian restaurant standard). 

Since I had such a good experience last week, I decided to take my in laws here tonight. They loved EVERY dish they ordered. We had pot sticker, oxtail claypot, seafood claypot, stir-fry sliced fish with green, soup for a total of $47. I think I found "THE" place to go with them now. yippeee!!!
author: Ervinna L.

description:
I don't like Dim Sum......

BUT SUMTIMES.....

An exceptional experience has the power to alter what you like.

I like Hong Kong Dim Sum. 

 I thoroughly enjoyed the food here.  The atmosphere was bright and the place was decorated more than most chinese restaurants.  White walls make food taste bland...I know there should not be a correlation...but there really is.  The enthusiasm put into the creation of the atmosphere is definitely a reflection of the enthusiasm put into the food...

Anyways...I try dim sum about once every few months hoping to enjoy it and for the first time in my life I enjoyed it here. 

Great place for first, or second, or 100th time dim sum eaters.  

My favorites were the sesame balls and the chive shrimp pot sticker dumpling things.

Enjoy!!!!
author: Emily C.

description:
I was in chinatown and I was hungry. We wanted an authentic chinatown experience and Clay Pot was just that. It's buried among a row of awnings and shops so you wouldn't notice it if you weren't specifically looking for it. You walk up a looong flight of stairs and turn the corner and you will see a crowded room of locals enjoying their meal. Waiters are yelling across the room, big round tables have 12 people seated eating their family dinner, and  the food looks fresh and very good.  We were the only non-Chinese people in the place, which to me, means it's authentic and good.

We ordered the pot-stickers (very good, crisp outside, tender meat inside), the tofu-chicken clay pot (because every other clay pot had animals we didn't want to try...frog, oxtail, lamb etc), and the scallop-cashew dish. Definitely order a claypot dish..the tofu was silky and smooth like flan...and steaming hot. I highly recommend it (even if you're not a tofu fan).  I noticed most of the tables had whole crab in a curry- it looked really tasty (but messy). Another dish that looked quite good was the steamed whole fish. 

Downside- the place doesn't feel as clean as I'd like, but you're not coming here for ambiance.
author: Sonia S.

description:
Thank you Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant for giving me a reason to believe that in times of an economic downturn, you can still get a wonderfully satisfying and delicious meal for $6 dollars.

Yes, you read it right. 6 freakin dollars. Thats cheaper than a gallon of milk and loaf of bread! 

They have lunch menus 6 days of the week (closed Wed.). For $4.60, there are over 20 options for lunch which comes with soup and rice. And for once, cheap food does not mean inedible food. In fact, everything tasted so authentic and home-y. 

Now is the time to look over your cubicle and act nice to your colleage. "Hey, wanna have lunch today?". Then you guys can head over to Chinatown to enjoy and share several dishes. I did this with 9 colleagues and we split 10 dishes. When it came time to split the bill- $6 per person. At this rate, I might have to be nice to them everyday....
author: Nancie T.

description:
I could give this place a four on the crab alone because seriously, some of the other dishes would bring it down to a three.  So 3.5!  I'm a tough judge when it comes to Chinatown, especially if they've got someone standing outside handing out fliers.  It's just so tacky, but I guess you need to for the business.  It's so competitive...

Came here for dinner the other night with some Yelpers after a very long day of alcohol consumption.  We ordered the set dinner menu.  Some of it was a surprise since we can only read a little bit of Chinese.  

Westlake Soup - not my kind of soup.  Too gloopy.  *gloop gloop*

Seasonal Veggies - so garlicky.  Hours later, I was still burping that deadly scent.  

Crab (Ginger/Scallions) - YUM.  And the shell was soft enough, so it wasn't necessary to get the hands all covered up in sauce.  While a little small, quite delicious.  *THUMBS UP*  

Shrimp & Walnuts - very typical dinner menu dish.  Personally, I love it.  It's not a dish that's easy to mess up.  Just make sure you've got fairly fresh ingredients!

Tofu/Seafood in Clay Pot - the tofu was delicious!  And the dish was flavorful, so the tofu really soaked it up.  *THUMBS UP*  I have been raving on about this clay pot to the parents because my mom loves that sort of thing.  Might just have to come back for this and the crab.

Salt/Pepper Ribs - we replaced our Sweet & Sour Pork.  This one was just okay.  We still finished this dish off, so it must have been decent.  Or we were just hungry.

Red Bean dessert - the warm soup-like dessert.  It was much too sweet.  Plus, we were all so stuffed that we didn't really need dessert at this point.  

There might have been one more dish, but I can't remember.  ALL FOR $39.  Divide that by 5.  Teehee.  I'm a little afraid to break the boundary and try the dim sum.  What if it will affect my rating!?  OH NO!
author: Tinna H.

description:
Hong Kong Clay Pot is one of those places I've been walking by for years but for some reason have always passed up... until recently that is. This is now my new favorite lunch spot and a must try for anyone that's close to Chinatown! 

I've been here with groups from 2-8 people and each time have enjoyed every single item ordered. The lunch specials are awesome... $5 for an entree and rice! 

This place really doesn't look like much but the tasty food and great prices speak for themselves!
author: Thel D.

description:
this place a little hidden but when you do find it GO!
you might have to wait a bit because it is a small place
the service isn't the fastest but if you don't mind waiting a few minutes you should be fine
try the kung pao chicken - very good
all the food is great. if you like seafood they have a lot of interesting selections.  the prices are average my boyfriend and i went and we got 4 dishes and two beers and it came out to $40. not terrible!
author: Mariam T.

description: Came back for more delicious and inexpensive Chinese food! Disappointed they did not have the salt and pepper crab for $17 while others charge $41 for. Seasonal they say!
author: Liz Y.

description:
Good place for lunch plates.

$4.60 ~ what a deal!  Choose from a list of soups, porridges, and rice plates.

The entry way is easy to miss.  It's up a small staircase on the 2nd floor of the building.  If you get a table near the window, you can see the action happening below on the main tourist strip of Chinatown.
author: Cathy K.

description: Kun poa beef 98, pork w/egg noodle 62, hot and sour soup 15, steamed rice x 2, tea - all very decent - many locals - would go again
author: Brian B.

description:
You guys don't even know.

I like secrets, or things that i perceive as a secret.

This place is upstairs, thats cool. So you walk upstairs and see how not cool looking this place is. Intimacy involves more than just candles and faux flower decor. 

For me it's like I have no problem to sacrifice things to eat something awesome.

The dim sum  is NOT BROUGHT OUT ON TRAYS/CARTS. You order it from a menu. This means that the dim sum is fresh, but fresh alone does not finalize my five stars. 

This motherfuckin place has to be best of the fresh. Real tough competition. I sacrifice the whole experience of mobile servers to eat here.
author: Douglas C.

description:
I'm not exactly sure why, but I just love a good clay pot!  There's just something magical about the way that food cooks in a clay pot...totally inexplicable!  Ahhh...but here's wiki weighing in with an explanation:
http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clay_pot_cooking

So, here's a restaurant in the heart of Chinatown...blink and you may just walk right by the sign that directs you up the stairs.  It's a small dining area, and chances are, it will be totally packed with all Chinese people.

The lunch specials were crazy inexpensive...a long list of different options for just a measly $4.90.  My friend ordered a braised beef tendon dish, which was super tender...albeit a bit on the lukewarm side.

I opted for the Seafood Clay Pot off the regular menu...still a bargain at $8.50. It was chock full of shrimp, squid, scallops, and huge pieces of tofu!  It looked like a big portion, but we didn't have any difficulty polishing it off!

I will definitely be returning again. Maybe I'll discover the mystery of the clay pot one of these days!
author: Evelyn K.

description:
Based on the Yelp reviews The Wife and I stopped by for lunch on Friday.  When we got there the place was pretty empty but by the time we left the place was hopping!

We decided to check out the $4.90 lunch specials so I went with Chicken and Bitter Melon and The Wife with Shrimp with Bok Choy.  Preparation was perfect for both of the meals.  The were plenty of shrimp with the bok choy and both of the veggies in our dishes were cooked just right.  You get the small bowl of rice and tea with your meal so $10 was the total before tip.  I'm not sure how they afford to pay everyone back in the kitchen that way but as long as they offer it the people will come.  

Don't let the appearance from the exterior keep you away.  Brave those steep stairs and enjoy good food.
author: Joe B.

description: Bless You Yelp! We followed the recommendations and  Everything was delicious.  We were the only non Asians there and might not have tried without the note about the sketchy stairs.
author: Raphy H.

description:
Struggling between 3 and 4 stars for this place. It really only earned 3 but we had a really awesome lunch here so it would be an emotional 4.
  First of all, we walked right in and got a table for 8, no problem. Then we realized we were the only non-Chinese table there, which is a good sign. Menu is in English also and the waitstaff was cool with our ignorance so ordering wasn't tough. 
  Lunch specials are $4.60 to $6.50. My date and I ordered a clay pot duck $8.50, potstickers $4.50 and a special sweet N sour chicken for $4.50. We all ate a little of what we ordered and then tasted everyone else's food.
  The honey walnut prawn are awesome. Beef stew too. The duck and ox tail are a little too boney for my liking but the flavor was good. 
   And oh lord, the table behind me got a lobster thing that looked amazing. 
Street parking is $3 / hour but it's SF Chinatown - what do you want? 
Anyway, great lunch here. Good flavor. Local atmosphere. Easy for non-Chinese. I'll go right back here.
author: Mike L.

description: Not much to say that hasn't been said.  Its good, worth the money, and actually has plenty of seating for crowded Chinatown.
author: Raman S.

description: While wandering around downtown on foot, my stomach started to complain. After consulting Yelp (duh), I ducked into this tiny second floor establishment. The decor might not be exciting, but you'll never notice because the food is delicious (and quite easy on the wallet). Yes. I'm a fan.
author: Matthew S.

description:
I came here on a whim while my sister was in town.  I live on the cusp of Chinatown and never actually eat in Chinatown... ever.  My sis wanted Chinese food so instead of trying to find some Asian fusion fancy pants place in another neighborhood it dawned on me that the best we can get is right in our backyard.  So... onto yelp I went, and found this place.  I was hoping for the most hole in the wall dive place I could find (as they're usually the best and most authentic) and Hong Kong Clay Pot definitely fit the bill.  

We arrived (six white girls) to be not so surprised to be the only non-Chinese people in the place.  No big deal though, that's what we wanted.  Our service was oooooookay... I mean, the food came hot and fast, but I swore they literally avoided us the entire night.  But I mean, it all came with the package so I wasn't offended.  

The food was good, chow mein, amazing.  Pot stickers, amazing. Tofu clay pot, amazing.  All served on a lazy susan... aaaaamazing!

We all left satisfied and proud of our San Francisco moment.  I'm not the biggest fan of Chinese food so I'm not sure if I'd come back on my own, but it was perfect for a group and to show out of towners what the Real Chinatown is all about.
author: Alice H.

description: This is a hidden gem, literally. Tucked in between two Chinatown junk shops up a set of dingy stairs, and absolutely wonderful. My family of four ordered hot and sour soup, potstickers, fried quail, two clay pot entrees, and honey walnut prawns. It was all delicious, but the standouts were the Chicken Tofu Clay Pot and the Honey Walnut Prawns. Wow!
author: Michelle L.

description: Typical Cantonese style chinese restaurant.  Everything we ordered was really good, especially the Seafood clay pot.  The food tasted authentic as well.  Prices are decent.  Not dirt cheap but decent.  I waver between 3 1/2 stars and 4 for this place.  You won't be disappointed by the food but it's not really a place that you crave to go back to.  There wasn't anything unique about the menu.
author: Lisa L.

description:
My sister and I came to this restaurant after reading these excellent yelp reviews.  It's definitely easy to miss if you're not paying attention.    (as others mentioned, all you see is a long flight of stairs and an asian woman handing out menus.)  However, the nice thing is that there is a parking garage on (I think) Pacific.  Rather convenient if you're driving and don't want to deal with finding a parking spot.  

I wasn't sure if they spoke mandarin (i expected cantonese for sure, but I can't speak cantonese), but luckily they did.  We ordered more food just to be able to try a variety of dishes since it was our first time there:
- seafood clay pot - the chinese name of this dish actually is seafood tofu clay pot.  Very delicious!
- salt/pepper pork ribs - pretty darn good
- large pea leaves - garlic was in one piece which I loved (so I could avoid it easily, but still reaped the benefits of its flavor) and the pea leaves were tender and not all stem.

I guess my mandarin is improving because the gentleman taking our order asked us if that was it.  I was a little puzzled and asked him if that wasn't enough.  He laughed and said "rice?".  we laughed as well and ordered rice.  He still looked at us expectantly, but I couldn't figure out what else he was thinking we needed.  

And then, he brought us some soup.  Of course!  You always need to start the meal with soup!  This was some sort of house special which was VERY tasty.  Clear broth with some ginseng-scent, peanuts, tendony type meat (I couldn't tell what it was, but it was good).  we tried to figure out what this soup was, but couldn't tell from the menu.  We later described it to our aunt who thought it wasn't listed on the menu,but was a daily-hey-what-have-we-got-special (her guess: oxtail soup).  Whatever it was, it was delicious. 

I'll definitely be back.  in fact, a family was peering up at the restaurant when we left and the woman finally asked me if I recommended the place.  I told her two thumbs up!
author: J L.

description: Had the potstickers and duck clay pot. The potstickers looked great and had a slightly spicy red sauce. They tasted great but had a little too much dough for me. The duck was very tender and had just the right amount of 5 spice for my taste. Everything was hot ( temp), straight from the kitchen. Yum
author: Dan W.

description: Hidden place, go up the stairs into a fairly drab restaurant that dishes out surprisingly good food. I've been here a handful of times now.  First time, it was raining, we were drenched and hungry and took shelter up the stairs.  We ordered the Walnut Prawns and the Mongolian Beef - so delicious.  Nothing matched this first meal.  The subsequent times were good as well, but just not as fresh and good as the first.  Once, the rice was pretty dried out.  Other things to know: no A/C and apparently no heat.  This can be a little uncomfortable, but grab a cold beer or hot tea and enjoy.
author: Catherine W.

description: In any other city, I would give this 3 stars. But in SF's Chinatown, this doesn't cut it. Very average, however, I did not get a clay pot, which is the namesake. Maybe I ordered the wrong thing.
author: Jeff P.

description: I ordered the Seafood Clay Pot. It included fried tofu, which was  unexpected, and did not include a wide variety of seafood--I got mostly fish filets and some octopus. But for what it was, I found it delicious and reasonably priced. Also, I sat next to a large and noisy group having the best time, which added to the experience :0)
author: Lisa W.

description:
Never knew this place existed in its current state after the fire at Clay Pot City. I was skeptical at first considering there were barely any guests at 10 AM on the Sunday morning I visited, but the dim sum here is not bad. The dim sum is cooked to order (no carts or ladies with trays walking around) which means everything comes out nice and hot.

The steamed dumplings are pretty tasty with decently thin skin, but you there's not much difference between the scallop dumplings and shrimp dumplings... everything basically has shrimp in it. Steamed rice rolls and chicken feet are pretty good and tasty though, which is usually a good sign. I thought it was interesting that the beef balls came in a soup instead of the usual steamer... a refreshing change if you prefer things on the light side. I even braved trying the salt & pepper duck tongue... which was interesting.

All in all a decent place, and pretty cheap and reasonable.
author: Andrey C.

description:
Wow, thank you yelpers!  With my dad in town, I wanted to give him a true San Francisco experience by taking him into Chinatown and I followed the Yelp suggestion of checking this place out.  So why is this place great?  A) The food was not greasy at all the the flavors were just spot on, B) Huge selection on the menu, C) Fast, fast, fast service - I pretty much heard it come off the pan and straight to my plate, D) Soo cheap - we could not believe how low the bill was, E) Comfy atmosphere - we were the last ones to leave and spent the last 30 min with the entire family - teens talking about school, the younger kids doing homework, etc.  

I will say that I felt a little sick after this meal, but I think that was mostly because the food was so good I just couldn't stop eating.  If you are in Chinatown this is the place to go for sure!  I just hope you have better will power than me.
author: Kate J.

description: The best pot stickers I've ever tasted. I also had the chicken clay pot. Wow, delicious!
author: Lola G.

description: Was going to have the hot pot here with friends. But they aren't serving any hot pot after April. Oh well... ordered bunch dishes instead. So good! Lamb clay pot, garlic snow bean, salt and pepper quails and steamed frog. All delicious and not like some other places oily. Will come back again if I ever come back to SF again. Thumbs up!
author: Flora F.

description:
8-8-10
We ordered two soups which were yummy and hot. Also had Mongolian Beef and shrimp & vermicelli clay pot which were very good.  When w walked in, or rather up the stairs, heads turned and felt like we were in the home turf- a perfect situation--the food was very good and we will return.    Brian & Lynda.
author: Brian C.

description:
White meat chicken, yay!

Everyone needs to venture into Chinatown every once and a while and explore.

We popped into the HK CP Restaurant for dinner the other night and it was good. I mean, let's be honest, it's pretty much just typical lunch-style Chinese food. I have to imagine there are some scary places in Chinatown so this place was good, cheap and easy.

Doooooooo it.
author: Derek B.

description:
This is quite the nice find. A friend of mine heard about it through her friend so we decided to check it out. The place is tucked away up on the second floor so finding it wasn't too easy.

For five people, we ordered a seafood clay pot, oysters, lobster, frog with bittermelon, and a noodle dish. We even ordered pot stickers to hold us over since we were quite hungry. The food was good and the bill came out to $60 (before tip). That's pretty cheap. Service was decent.

This makes for another good Chinese option in the city. The only thing is that getting there (Chinatown) can be a little rough.
author: Barney M.

description: I gave 5 stars since it really is that good. The food are very yummy without being so salty as most other Chinese restaurant . The clay pot dishes are good, vegies are good, the seafood( steamed catfish) is very fresh. The free soup they gave to us before meal is super . And the price is low. I really like this one and will come back again and again. I found many local people come here, despite it's on a 2nd floor .
author: Ying X.

description: what a crazy area of san fran!  we went right before the Chinese New Year.  it is very authentic, full of asians which to me tells you have hit a gem to have lunch!  we had the chicken fried rice, YUMMY!  a seafood dish that i liked parts better than others but the broth was excellent and spring rolls that were very good.  It was packed at lunchtime and we enjoyed the atmosphere of an upstairs row house, windows open, lots of talking and although not much personality of the staff but it was just what we needed after a fun night in san fran!
author: cheryl m.

description:
I have eaten lunch here three times over the last 7 or so years.  It is definitely a hole in the wall as was described earlier.  The service in here has ranged from fair to downright hostile many years ago.  Years ago my buddy asked for a fork and was rather rudely told he was in Chinatown.  He responded that they were in America and to get him an expletive fork.   I almost fell out of my chair laughing but was a little worried that they had not brought out our food yet.  That being said most really good Chinese places I go the service is spotty.  
Now the reason this place gets 4 stars is the food.  It is always good and the prices are great.  A mostly all Chinese clientele and that is usually a good sign.
author: steve p.

description: Not the best or worst that Chinatown has to offer, but the food is decent and prices are reasonably.  I highly recommend ordering any of their fried rices, it's really delish!
author: An N.

description:
In the heart of Chinatown, tightly tucked between two awnings, you'll find the small entrance to this gem. Just inside the door you'll have to climb a steep flight of stairs to get to the restaurant itself.

The interior of the place is basic and unassuming and might feel a little cramped to some. During peak times, the staff will try to maximize space by seating smaller groups together at the larger tables.

Everything I've tried has been tasty and fresh. The pan-fried pot stickers are a favorite because of the chunks of ginger inside. They are definitely some of the best I've eaten.

The prices are very reasonable - two people can leave very satisfied for under $20.

Bring along the address and the place will be much easier to find.
author: FrOg SoU P.

description: I must say I almost didn't go in to this place because it looked kind of creepy. You go up the stairs to their entrance and don't know what you are getting yourself in to. The place is small and loud but the food was delish! We had the seafood fried noodles and kung pao chicken and both were great. I really like the havy spice they use on the kung pao. Service is decent, very friendly but super busy. I want to come back and try one of their lobster dishes.
author: Adrienne P.

description: Minus one star for the mediocre service, but the food was fantastic! This was the best meal we had while on a three day vacay to SF. It was such a shame to see the non-Asians around us ordering panda express items...they don't know what they're missing out on!  We had the hot & sour soup, spicy jelly fish, salt and pepper crab, abalone claypot and garlic chicken. The crab and chicken were def the stars that night lol. I look forward to coming back for the lobster next time. :)
author: MissusBugatti J.

description: This place is very cozy with its second floor locale. You can tell its a local favorite. There is nothing big and ritzy about this place. Just good food and lots of paying customers. We ordered the Spring Rolls, Chicken Fried  Rice, Shrimp Dumpling Won Ton Soup, Lamb Clay Pot and Broccoli Beef. The bill came up to about $50 for all of that and we left feeling like we had eaten a mountain of food. The food came very fast. The portions are great. I didn't experience anything being greasy or oily. The only negative part of my experience is that the broccoli was Chinese Broccoli and the Chardonnay was a very cheap tasting chardonnay but hey, it's not a wine bar right? Overall, I enjoyed our dinner and would recommend them.
author: Eve R.

description: Probably the most authentic chinese joint ive been to. Absolutely delicious. Everything was fresh. Scallops n garlic dish was out of this world. The Kung pao chicken was slamming as well. Would definitely go back
author: Sean d.

description: Great food, low price, few tourists.
author: JP P.

description: Really good food, good and fast service, they give you soup and dessert for free. Only downside is that its a small area. We had to wait for like 15 mins to get seated but after that food came out quick. Would definitely come back.
author: Lude I.

description: vegetable claypot is delicious, far more tasty than the seafood claypot, which is fine but without a rich and flavorful sauce that gets soaked into vermecelli noodles.
author: Di Yin L.

description: This place is legit. Fcuk me silly, but this place rivals the best of SF Chinatown. I have not had a bad dish here the many times I ate here. Just thinking about it makes me want to go feast.
author: Jerry H.

description:
This place caters to more tourists than locals, but that's okay. My friends and I stopped by Hong Kong Clay Pot last Saturday during the Autumn Moon Festival (wanted to get off the street from all the crowds); the guy at the front door was amusing, giving us a thumbs-up and saying "Good stuff!" in his thick Chinese accent. 

Ascend a staircase and then, the restaurant appears--small, on the second floor, but seems to seat a decent amount of people. Service was so-so, but I expect that at most Chinese restaurants (it's all a different culture after all; that's how "my people" roll). Lunch specials were served on the weekend, thank goodness! The rice plates are served family style, so be sure to choose a mix of meat and vegetable plates if you are dining with someone else. My friends and I made the mistake of all ordering meat dishes...so in turn, we had to share three meat dishes. I felt I lacked the nutrients from vegetables in that meal.

I probably will not go back to this restaurant, not because I disliked it, but because I rarely frequent the Grant Avenue part of Chinatown. Too many tourists; already have to deal with them while working in Union Square. /tangent
author: Helene K.

description:
This is my new favorite Chinese restaurant. I came here on a recommendation from my roommate that the hot pot was amazing, but I was longing for some clay pot!

Showed up with a non-Asian friend and we started with the potstickers. I was wary of the order because no real Chinese people ever order potstickers (or appetizers for that matter), and when they showed up they were huge (which usually means they're bad.. potstickers are supposed to be small!), but I was really pleasantly surprised! Perfectly fried, good filling and the sweet n sour dipping sauce was pretty tasty.

Seafood clay pot was delicious!  Lots of seafood and a pleasantly sweet sauce.  The beef stew clay pot wasn't so good because it was like beef intestine stew or something (don't let your non-Chinese friends order.. ugh).

I would suggest ordering one clay pot and another dish for two people.  Two clay pots got kind of boring and the tastes weren't complimentary.  I was drooling at a nearby table because they got lobster and some nice looking sauteed bok choy.  Definitely will come here and try the whole steamed fish next time! :)
author: Wendy T.

description:
My family absolutely loved this place. As Hong Kong-neses, we all agreed that this place's food was authentic, or at least the dishes we ordered.

We had the seafood claypot (thank you, Yelpers! When my parents were looking at the menu, I kept reminding them "Don't forget the seafood claypot. Wait, guys, the seafood claypot is very important.") , the lamb claypot, the sweet and sour pork, and the salty fish over pork and bokchoy. 

I was most surprised by the sweet and sour pork. A thin, lightly-fried covering coated tender pieces of pork. No chunky, thick fried dough here.

My fave of course was the seafood claypot. Melt-in-you-mouth pieces of scallops, tender shrimp, juicy black mushrooms, OH and this AMAZING soft tofu that was lightly pan-fried so it had this crispy casing on the outside and heart-warming soft white tofu inside.

The lunch specials here are only $4.50 per plate, and they have big portions.

Including tip, we paid $34. Man, I wish I took pictures. Just imagine four big, satisfied smiles, utterly thankful for the taste of familiarly good foods.
author: Meohmy H.

description: Easy to miss this place if you're not looking for it. But a co-worker recommended it and I went for dinner. Ordered the seafood tofu claypot - excellent. Succulent shrimp, scallops, and squid cooked perfectly, not at all rubbery. All simmering in a delicious gravy that goes perfectly over white rice. Also had the Peking pork chops - with just enough fattiness and crispiness to complement the tangy and sweet sauce coating the chops. Meal came with complementary ginseng chicken broth and sweet soup at the end. Bill was about $8/person. Pretty extensive menu, too, have to go back.
author: Susan H.

description: Super decent prices and super delicious claypot!!had the fish and tofu claypot,salt and pepper frog legs which were my fav,Peking spare ribs was so so,must try when in San Fran
author: Maybelyn L.

description: hard to find, but tastey tastey food, well worth the wait. A fine find of Chinese food.
author: Bert K.

description: I think the service is good. When I had ate lunch there today,the food was delightful. The soup had a very good taste. I think the beef noodle is has a very good taste,too. They also gave me a small can of coke. I will certainly go there again.
author: William Z.

description: Good hole in the wall place. There were no other white people so we knew it would be good food. Service was what you would expect. Food was good and the price was right.
author: Austin O.

description:
