I found this place on YELP and a BIG THANK YOU!!! We were visiting San Fran last week and went in for dinner. When we first found it we were apprehensive to say the least, you walk up some less than clean stairs and enter a what-you'ld-expect Chinatown diner....however, the food was fantastic!! 

Very authentic! The hot-sour soup was some of the best I've had. The broccoli was better than most, but the real treat was the clay pot dishes. Highly recommend them. The seafood and the duck especially but I would guess they are all amazing!! 

Can't wait to return!
author: sophia w.

description: This is a split review. We ordered the honey walnut prawns which were freaking delicious the walnuts were super good the prawns were cooked perfectly. Then the other order came...we got beef chow mein which was avg and greasy...nothing special or bad. Then we got the beef clay pot....ew! First off it was more tofu then beef and second it had like some funky flavor like cinnamon or something...it was disgusting! I had to try to get rid of the flavor with pizza! The beef in the pot was nasty...it was more tendon and ligament then meat and it was not tender either... coupled with the cinnamon flavor it was awful. I would come back for the honey walnut prawns but would say the beef pot was disgusting. Also if youre an avg sized guy the prices aren't that cheap cause the portions aren't that generous. Im 175 lbs and I wasnt too full after about 27 bucks worth of food between me and my much less hungry gf. But maybe it's because I didn't eat all the beef clay pot?
author: Benny C.

description:
Had dinner here one evening while looking for the "Chinatown experience." Well, this place delivered. 

We started with the pot stickers and wonton soup which were both just about perfect (maybe it was my extreme hunger talking). My boyfriend ordered the lobster in clay pot which was quite tasty (the noodles were a nice touch). However, I got the lamb in clay pot which was a mistake. I guess you could say it was a little *too* authentic, as it had lamb stomach and all the other bits. I should have thought a little bit more before ordering it (I did say we were looking for the "Chinatown experience," right?) but it's all good. I just stuck with the lobster, and I was fine. Service was super slow, but that's to be expected. If I ever go back, I'll order something else.
author: Monica T.

description:
Really 4.5 stars.

Very discreet location, so if you're not paying attention you'll walk right by it.  In fact, the lady standing by the entrance who's handing out menus won't wave you down if you're not Asian (wait I'm Asian...).

Walking upstairs, you see a mid-size restaurant full of Chinese people.  I went with two friends who were visiting from DC.  We sat down and looked around at what people were eating.  Yes, we were those annoying people.  The table next to us had three great looking (and smelling) dishes.  We guessed: kung pao chicken, bok choy with something, and chow mein.  Correct answer: something frog, something green, and chow mein.  So we chose what we guessed.

If you like Chinese mall food, this place is not for you.  It tasted genuine and delicious, even though we chose Chinese mall food entrees.  Service was nice and prompt, but really you can't get over the food.  Very VERY *VERY* good.
author: Edward K.

description:
I went here with my dad's cousin and his wife (both avid 'authentic Chinese' food lovers) so I was worried since as a resident of the city I know the best Chinese food tends to be in restaurants not in China town.

The place: A little bit of a hole in the wall. Pretty clean. Mostly Chinese ppl there, few outsiders. Looks out onto Grant if you get a window view (nice!). Had an all over 'authentic' feel (I haven't been to China so I could be wrong, but it felt homey yet distinctly Chinese)

The service: A+. My dad's cousin tends to crack silly jokes with anything and anyone (it's a family thing). The waiter actually laughed and cracked his own jokes, he and the other waitstaff were attentive yet not overbearing, which I've heard is very chinese in style. All the waitstaff were kind/inobtrusive and we never felt like outsiders at all. Food also arrived relatively quickly and our seafood was wonderfully fresh!

Beverages: One of my guests had wanted a juice/ iced tea alternative. I realize this is not typically Chinese, but just note that they only have beers, hot tea, and sodas -  not sure if there's something like iced coffee??? In any case there was no beverage menu.

Food: fantastic!!! Gigantic portions, great quality and pretty good value for your money. We ordered 5 'main' dishes, one appetizer and 3 tsing tao beers and we spent $49 (w/o tip). We stuffed our faces till we hurt, had leftovers enough for 2 ppl. I am rarely impressed by restaurants, but this was so good I had to sign up for a yelp acct.

 We ordered:
--wonton soup (gigantic!!) with deliciously sizeable won tons- fantastic
--spring rolls - fresh veggies inside, freshly fried. wonderful even heated up
--salty fish in chicken fried rice - this was the 'test of authenticity' for my uncle - and he LOVED it. Not too salty, just perfect
-- bitter melon beef (in black bean sauce) - the beef was good but I apparently don't like bitter melons. overall tasty
-- beef chow fun (spelling??) - this was the only reason I took off a star, the 'flat noodles' weren't well separated during cooking. And although the taste was great it wasn't the best dish. I felt I could have gotten a slightly better version at R&G lounge for example.
--seafood clay pot - PIECE DE RESISTANCE!! amazing!!! I am very picky about my seafood but this was a totally fresh succulent dish. I'll come here with all my friends and guests just because of this dish.

Overall we came out of this lunch with very satisfied bellies and my san francisco visitors were very very happy with the experience. I would have liked to give them a 4.5 - but since I've only been here once I'll keep it at a solid 4 for now.

Hint: go towards the next block (south on Grant) to free tea tasting (look for a dude called Kenny - great showman)
author: Acid B.

description: Wow, the best Chinese food I have had since I moved away from the bay area. We stumbled on this place accidentlly. We walked up some stairs and into a room where a few people were eating. The amount of food was  was huge and way to much  for two people to eat although we gave it our best try. The only thing we had a hard time with was getting a glass of ice water. It was hot in there and the tea just wasn't going to cut it. Liked this place a lot!!!
author: Likes To Travel R.

description: This place looks like a crappy hole in the wall on first glance, but the food is actually really great. I loved it so much I went twice in 3 days. The banquets are awesome. I don't even like seafood that much and I enjoyed it. Plus, it's cheap!
author: Lara C.

description: Thank you Chie!!!! I loved the lobster ginger.  Where else can I eat a tasty whole lobster for $15.95!!!  Warning: lobster brain does not taste like crab brain.
author: Wakako U.

description: Menu in English and Chinese, so it was easy to order. Food came out and everything was excellent. Staff was also very friendly. Most of the tables (all except one) are big tables, so if you are a small party, make sure you don't mind sharing.
author: Victor P.

description:
We were walking around & saw this old man giving out menus of this place. We walked further but came back since the price seem cheap. Ordered a lot of dim sum, most of the steam ones were good. When we got the bill, my friend checked it & the waitress conviently add on a tea ($2.50) even though she asked if we wanted any & said no. She only took off $2 & later told us that tip is not included in the total. My friend hates it when people say that. The food is good but asking for tip is so unsophisticated & rude. 

*** stars for the food.
author: Precious C.

description:
Totally undesrcipt from the street, this place blew my away.  

Go for the Prix fix meal  - it was well worth it and amazing.  Don't be turned off by the frontage or agressive menu pushers - it's Chinatown, what do you expect?
author: Leia K.

description: By far the best sweet and sour chicken I've ever had. Authentic Chinese restaurant, we enjoyed that it was not a touristy place in Chinatown. I found it funny that we were the only customers serviced a fork and fortune cookie!
author: Carrie A.

description: Great foods within the SF Chinatown.  Hong Kong style@
author: Tuan N.

description: Can't go wrong with the cheap Chinese food here. It's nice authentic Chinese food and will leave you full and satisfied. The seafood pan-fried noodles was very tasty and came in a very generous portion.
author: Janice H.

description: Eat here if you want to eat RAW chicken wings. When I informed the owner, she was rude and did not even apologize. She said if I get sick, then to send her the medical bills! I will never come here again!
author: missy m.

description: Found this place on Yelp and by the reviews thought it must be good. Getting service was hard, they got the order wrong. Asked for hot mustard... Sorry we no have! so they gave us runny plain old mustard. Looks like they did not even shake the bottle because half was water. Overall I would not go back, the food was sort of bland and try to figure out the bill. I just paid hoping it was right. $90 for 6 people. Went with friend from Texas. We all were sort of disappointed overall.
author: Robert C.

description: Small 'hole in the wall' literally, and service a little slow. But despite this I still have to give it 5 stars because it was just SO yummy.  By far the best Chinese I've ever had. Definitely worth putting up with the lack of elbow room!  I recommend the honey prawns - I wish I could go back to SF just for another taste of them!!!
author: Kimberly L.

description: Thank you yelp for an awesome find. It is always a good sign when there are a lot of chinese people at a chinese restaurant! Everything we had was delicious (walnut prawns, duck tongue and house noodles). Service was fast and friendly. The ambience and food was very much like the restaurants we visited in the Suzhou area. I always said that I only like chinese food in China, I stand corrected:)
author: Nicole F.

description: The claypot is awesomely good. Everything else on the menu is pretty terrible, but I think they still get 5 stars because they are called the clay pot restaurant.
author: Liye Z.

description: You know you're in the right place when your group is the only non-Chinese speaking party in the restaurant! Hong Kong Clay Pot Restaurant is at the top of a steep, narrow staircase on Grant Street. It is not flashy in the least; the decor is understated and simple. The room is furnished with simple tables and chairs; tables by the window allow patrons to look down on busy Grant Street. The food is outstanding and the service excellent; our party of 4 - 2 adults and 2 teens - went in for lunch based on Yelp reviews. We were not disappointed. My husband had the House Special Noodle Soup, which was filled with meat and vegetables. A generous portion indeed! My son had the beef chow mein, again, a generous portion of noodles, vegetables, and delicious beef. My daughter had the egg flower soup, and claimed it was some of the best she has tasted. I had the porridge with seafood; rice in broth with seafood. It was delicious! I would go back to Hong Kong Clay Pot again in a heartbeat!
author: Rene R.

description: Hidden gem above the storefronts in Chinatown.  Although the decor isn't fancy, the food was very good.  We ordered the pot stickers, cashew chicken and Mongolian chicken with prawns.  There was plenty of food and the quality was good.  A Chinese version of a "greasy spoon" restaurant.
author: Staci C.

description:
I was really pleased with this place.  I only wish we would have gone back a second time.

It's clean, the staff is friendly, the food is very authentic, and the locals eat there!

We had the following items:

1) Salt and Pepper Duck Tongue: I've never had this before, but it was good, a little chewy and crunchy, good flavor, but greasy.

2) 1/2 Steamed Ginger Duck: It's served cold on purpose and they include the chicken head.  This didn't gross me out, it was very authentic, and not repulsive.  The chicken itself is kind of bland (think boiled chicken), but the ginger/oil sauce that it comes with was incredible.

3) Tofu Clay Pot: It was served with a wonderful broth, mushrooms (dark, chewy, and meaty mushrooms), and bok choy.  All in all, a great dish, and the broth was excellent on rice.

4) Rice: White rice
author: Noah B.

description:
Ive eaten at this place numerous times, the food is pretty authentic Cantonese cuisine, the frog with bitter melon was pretty good but the pieces were from a very small bull frog, I prefer bigger meatier pieces.

One of my favorites is the catfish cooked with salted black bean sauce and a pot of rice to go with it.
author: Mr Bolo B.

description: VERY authentic. I think it's a good sign when there are locals who eat there instead of all tourists. Big portion servings, the curry clay pot was really good. Beware that there is frog legs on the menu.
author: Becka S.

description:
The food and service here isn't as good as we thought it would be.. But definitely better than other filthy foods we've tried in Chinatown.

We had the chicken and tofu claypot dish and catfish with black bean sauce.
The claypot dish was mediocre.. Lots of tofu and a little bit of chicken. It needs to be more flavorful!!! Same for the catfish...
Service was slow.. maybe because the place was so crowded...
Good thing the food was really cheap... Otherwise we'd say that this place is totally not worth going to!

We're willing to give this place another shot if we're ever in Chinatown again..
author: Roland R.

description:
tried this place for the first time last night. potstickers were spot on and tasty. honey walnut prawns were good and plentiful, but i would've liked more honey flavor. steamed spinach with garlic is exactly as it says it is and the beef noodle dish was alright.

major props for serving us so late - we really appreciated it.

i'll be back to give it another whirl and give myself adequate time to sit and enjoy without feeling like i was imposing on them.
author: laura f.

description:
This is one of the few times Yelp misled me!!  I had a craving for hot and sour soup and based on the reviews, I came here on a Friday @1PM. 

The hot and sour soup was watered down - neither hot or sour.  The tea had more flavor.  Zero stars.

Next the pot stickers - the filling doesn't taste fresh!   Taste like they used left over meat or something.  Though there's was quite a bit of dough, I did like the texture.  Al dente & not mushy.   Two stars.

The bittermelon with shrimp rice plate was okay.  The best item of the my meal.  Three stars.

Not coming back, that's for sure.
author: D C.

description: Greasy but all-around tasty food.  Went with a group recently and had one of the best Chinese meals in a long time.  We ordered the meal for six and it was more than sufficient for six-- there was a considerable amount of food left over.  Highlights of the meal were the honey walnut shrimp, the fish hotpot, and the crab.
author: John M.

description: Wow don't expect atmosphere but this place is GOOD! Beef Stew Noodle Soup: very tasty broth and wonton noodles. Lamb Clay Pot: succulent, tender and aromatic. Take a walk up those long scary stairs, real homestyle no frills Chinese cooking is waiting for you.
author: Anthony B.

description:
This is the best Chinese food I have had in SF... I grow up in LA with a family who new great Chinese food and it took me four years to find this place! Everything is good that I have had so you can't go wrong! 
ENJOY!
author: Kara S.

description: Good stuff.  Not amazing, although I'd definitely try it again and maybe I'd be more excited about it.  Had the honey walnut prawns and they were very good.  Also got the spicy jellyfish just to try it.  Very good flavor, but the texture and cold temp was not my cup of tea.
author: David P.

description: So we were walking aimlessly one Thursday evening in Chinatown & didn't know where to eat. Everyone knows that it's always a hit or miss with restaurants along with "tourist pricing" anywhere on Grant St. But lo & behold, this quaint nook on the 2nd flr of some run down building was there to surprise us. With no one in front harassing you with fliers (which most of the time you really don't know what the fuck they're talking about?!). All they had was this sign, mostly in Chinese characters & some pictures of their food. So we went up this narrow stair case & immediately heard loud people talking. True enough it was packed with locals & probably no more than a dozen tables inside.  Needless to say the food was exquisite & cheaper than most restaurants there. We went crazy over their Garlic Bok Choy & fried chicken wings. Then came back a couple of days later for their Lobster over noodles. It is true what my Chinese friend said...  just look for a restaurant full of Chinese locals & rest assured that they won't only have good food, but it'll also be hella cheap! This is quite a GEM in the middle of Chinatown.
author: Jays D.

description: Went here after moving, delicious cheap good quality Chinese food which is harder to find in Chinatown then you might expect.
author: Kelly O.

description: I have to premise this with the fact that my husband and I are tall white tourists from SoCal and MI and this is overly tourity Chinatown. However almost everyone in there this Friday night was Chinese. The Honey Prawns with Walnuts were awesome. I've never had that dish before and it was a great combo. Cashew chicken was solid as was won ton soup. Wasn't too excited by the fried wontons but not sure why my husband ordered it. Spelling mistakes on menu kind of made the experience too!  And friendly service which you don't always get when you stand out like a sore thumb in some touristy ethnic areas. Plus I like how it's upstairs overlooking Grant St.
author: erica u.

description: This place is probably a 4+ when you take into consideration the lunch special prices and the quality of food. Unfortunately, the service, as with most Chinese restaurants, is sub-par. Whatever. I'd still give it a solid 4 for delicious, cheap, Chinese food. I come here often, esp for lunch. :)
author: Simon L.

description: Great seafood clay pot!!! This is an interesting location upstairs. I need to go back to try more!!! The wontons where huge and filled with great flavors. The dipping sauce actually tasted homemade, which is a nice change from the red corn syrup they usually give at restaurants. Give it a try if you are in the area.
author: Kevin D.

description: BEST CHINESE FOOD I'VE EVER EATEN!!! visited from san antonio, and will definitely come back!! we ordered chicken fried rice, potstickers, cashew chicken, and mongolian beef with honey walnut prawns. DELICIOUS! total bill $30 that includes three sodas! lil chinese lady was so sweet. We went to pot sticker the next day and totally regretted it. yuck.
author: des m.

description: Absolutely love this place. The Orange Chicken is to die for. It was litte noisy when we got there, but besides that it's definitely a place worth checking out!!
author: igy c.

description: Had the seafood clay pot and potstickers. Quite possibly the best food I had on my trip to SF.
author: Ryan P.

description: Fantastic food! We had the chicken and abalone clay pot, very reasonable, and the restaurant was full of locals.
author: Cheryl B.

description: After searching yelp for good place to eat in the Chinatown area of San Francisco my family decided to try Hong Kong Clay Pot.  The location was great being at one end of our grant street trek and near the fortune cookie factory.  At first we were not too sure about climbing the stairs, as well as the ambience of the surrounding area, but the extra climb paid off.  When we arrived we were promptly seated at one of the large round tables.  The lady that greeted us was very nice, and very to the point, in fact everybody who helped us were quite friendly.  The dinning room was decorated with simple yet traditional décor.  My family and I ordered the Mandarin family dinner for four which came with won ton soup, sweet and sour chicken, prawn fried rice, pot-stickers, garlic prawns, and Mongolian beef (which we substituted with chicken chow mien), and beef with greens (bok choy).  I also ordered the curry chicken clay pot as well.  Let me start off with the pot-stickers, which were the first to go.  The size of them were huge compared to many other restaurants, and both orders were cooked perfectly; crisp on the bottom warm filling and soft on the top, yes we ordered more.  The curry chicken was also outstanding; it came out still boiling in the clay pot filling the table with its aroma.  Overall every plate of food we had was great.  All of the tastes were fresh, the bok choy tasted like fresh bok choy, while not being masked by the beef gravy.  The sweet and sour wasn't heavy or greasy, the won ton soup light and flavorful.  If I could give four and a half stars I would.  Overall great food, great price worth the stair climb.
author: Robert M.

description:
be advised that this restaurant is no longer called HK clay pot city restaurant but rather HK dim sum somthing or other.  my friend and i walked back and forth down grant ave looking like lost tourists until we finally called her sister and got the phone # and confirmed the correct restaurant identity.  apparently they changed the name, b/c they now serve dimsum.

the claypot here was really good.  we got a medium one w/ chinese sausage, dried duck, and this other cured meat.  the medium one is huge and can easily feed a family of four if you order other dishes.  we also got the seafood chowfun, and we had enuf leftovers to fill up two styrofoam take out containers to the brim (each easily weighing 2 lbs!).  

service was if-y, but what do you expect at a chinatown restaurant?
author: Helen T.

description: Delicious!  Tried this place out with my mom who is here visiting because we wanted some authentic chinese food in Chinatown.  It did not disappoint.  We tried the pot stickers, which I loved!  The honey walnut prawns were delicious!  My sweet and sour chicken was good, although not much different from what I could have gotten at Panda Express, in my opinion.  Good food, reasonable prices.  Would go again!
author: Jenni H.

description: Would have missed this place as the sign was very small.  Lots of Chinese families were there for lunch which is a good sign. I had the beef stew--which I wouldn't recommend. My wife had the prawns with walnuts, which were excellent!  A great place for those wanting to get away from the Americanized Chinese food shops.
author: Matthew P.

description: Legit! As authentic as it gets and very good. Had the seafood in clay pot, which was delicious. It's prepared in a mild sauce, so if you want something more spicy or exciting, perhaps try something else, but it was lovely. Started with salt and pepper quail -- tasty, but cumbersome to eat.
author: PJ D.

description:
i'm chinese, but I hardly ever eat Chinese food unless my parents are around.  Not because I don't want it, i just don't ever have any idea what I should order when I'm at restaurants, so I just avoid them all together...and i LIVE in chinatown, so the fact that I wasn't even eating in my neighborhood was a little mind boggling.

so i finally tried out this restaurant after checking out some reviews on yelp and have to heartily agree--this place has some wonderful food.  When I got there the entire place was chock full of chinese families, the service was quick, and the food was yummy without having that heavy or oily quality that some other "fast food" chinese restaurants tend to have.

try it out...and as I try more places around in the 'hood I'll let you all know which places to hit up.
author: jozilla w.

description: super duper cheap, food is kind of awful. it's americanized cantonese "authentic". i think we will be paying $2 more and get something better tasting at hunan homes ro bund.
author: Fiona S.

description:
This is a great hole in the wall restaurant with a wide varsity of dishes.  Besides the usual standard Chinese fare, they had a wide variety of unusual dishes for the American pallette.  I had the abalone clay pot dish and it was very excellent.  

The restaurant is located upstairs from the street level, but still managed to do a bustling business on a Sunday night (always a good sign).  The ambiance of the interior was nothing fancy, but we were here for the food.
author: Matthew J.

description: This is the best Chinese restaurant in Chinatown.  Price is extremely reasonable.  Even though the place is small, but the food is good, seafood is fresh.  They serve good tea (it's important to have good tea when having Chinese food).  Both the owner and the waitress are friendly, courteous, pleasant and generous.
author: Alice L.

description:
I signed up for Yelp, just so I could tell everyone how much I loved the food at this restaurant.  

We had a group of three and decided to order a couple of the dishes, just so we could try a little of everything.  As many recommended before me, the Honey Walnut Prawns are a must. We also had the Salt & Pepper wings, Hunan Beef, and a Vegetable Claypot.  It was just the right amount for us and everything was delicious.
author: Rebecca G.

description: Usually when I am in this area I cannot resist a stop at Sam Wo about a block away. This place features a $4.60 rice plate menu for lunch that was quite creative. I went for the prawns and tender greens. Just wonderful! The dining room is clean and the service very attentive (for a $4.60 rice plate, even). Definitely give this a try.
author: George S.

description: Hong Kong Clay Pot is awesome. I've been there twice and everything I've  ordered has been really good.  The atmosphere is great. Its a fun place to eat. Everyone in there seems to be having a good time. So far, I haven't ordered anything too adventurous but looking around at other people's tables, there appear to be a few whole fish dishes that I plan on looking into.   Until I've tried everything on their menu, I don't really see any reason to try to find another Chinese restaurant in Chinatown. Their prices are cheap and they have lazy susans.  I like everything about this place and the food is delicious.
author: Rajay P.

description: Recommended by my friend who grew up in Hong Kong. Love the snow peas stir fry and the lobster noodle there. If you don't mind a hole-in-wall restaurant, it's awesome!
author: Jub N.

description:
sorry clay pot, but your gonna get chopped down in this review. honestly, the food was barely....BARELY decent. our dishes were kung pao shrimp, sauted green beans, cashew chicken and a plate of egg rolls. My date and I both agreed that every dish we ate lacked flavor and quality. we were both hungry and got some advice from locals to check this place out, save yourself the trip because im sure there are better chinese food spots around town. 

on another note, we heard alot of people around us order pork dishes, so its possible the place may be just good at serving up good pork dishes because the place seemed to have a good street cred, but sadly the food just didnt stack up. 

specifically, the green beans they used were your ordinary green beans you find in the supermarket as opposed to the more delicious chinese green bean variety ( tastier, trust me). 

the cashew chicken was the worst dish we had. it had little flavor and was pretty ordinary (just chicken, pea pods, baby corn and cashew). nothing exciting or worth bragging about.  

the shrimp kung pao was decent, but nothing more than that. big pieces of shrimp but it lacked a lot of flavor and didnt taste so fresh.

on the plus side, the prices are very reasonable so check this place out for its prices at best. otherwise, go spend 8-10 dollars more and have a flavorful meal somewhere else.
author: kareem r.

description: A great dive.   Decor is non existent  Had shrimp dumpling soup and the dumplings were made fresh.  the broth was excellent.  Had a platter of pea pod shoots with lots of garlic which was extremely fresh.  Then had prawns and when I wanted them out of the shell the waitress was eager to accommodate.  The vegetarian clay pot was very tasty.
author: margaret r.

description: The seafood claypot and quail are some of the best I have ever had, and I grew up deep in Asia. Really good stuffs, and cheap also. I will try the lobster and other seafood more. I love these hole-in-the-wall places that are cheap but have excellent food. I bet to those people who rate expensive suave restaurants five stars this. I buy food from HOng Kong Claypot, I repackaged them with nice plates and stuffs, sell it in a cool-looking restaurants with a high price, and they will rave about it, giving 5 stars like crazy. Good thing is you dont have to pay a lot for honest good food. Here it is, Hong Kong Claypot.
author: Glenn S.

description: I'm not sure what the hype around this restaurant is, but it's hardly worth going to. There are much better restaurants around and the food either features extremely flavorful meat or bland noodles. Head elsewhere.
author: Chris R.

description: One of my friends who is originally from Hong Kong took me here after I complained of how Nor Cal Chinese restaurants are sub-par compared to those found in San Gabriel Valley in So Cal. Not expecting much beyond the typical Americanized Chinese food found at other places in SF Chinatown I was pleasantly surprised at how good all of the dishes were. We ordered a clay hot pot, fresh fish and clams. All the food was very well prepared and tasted delicious! As for value, the prices don't get much better than this in the City as our total bill came out to be about $30 for the two of us (meal also included soap and dessert!). In the end, not sure whether i just set my expectations so low, but I do know that I will be coming back for another round as soon as i get the chance!
author: Steve T.

description: went to this place 7/2010 . the restaurant is older and the service is slow. the food however is very good and cheap, actually most of the customer during lunch time were construction people and Chinatown office staff. looks like a tourist place but more locals looking for a cheap no thrill lunch.
author: Howard J.

description: Super yummy food at really reasonable prices. Also a small Chinese child seated me and it was mostly only Chinese in the restaurant which always makes me happy. The seafood clay hot pot is only $8.50 and has tons of shrimp and calamari. The Mongolian shrimp with chicken was also quite tasty and the pot stickers were huge and only $4. Will definitely be returning here.
author: Sophia D.

description: Loved the food here!  I went to this place just because of the reviews I read here.  I had out of town guests and went to Hong Kong Dim Sum for the dim sum.  Prices are great, food is great, staff is great!  Whenever I want dim sum this is the place to go.
author: Erica N.

description: Five stars for the price, I would say a solid 4 for the food.  We ate lunch here with a group of 5 people, and the bill out the door was just over $30.  I really have never seen such a small food bill.  Family style eating, with a lazy susan.  Small and packed with locals, in the heart of China town.
author: Rachel S.

description: Can't say that I love it. The Beef Chow Mein was good, but everything else was average.
author: Sami K.

description:
more like 3.5
food is good and very familiar from my canto background. 
a busy place, but easy to get seating on a friday night. 
we had the oxtail clay pot. that was very good. the wonton soup was small. the price is ok, a $$. for us, spending over $30 is a lot for 2 people at a chinese restaurant, but we had a bit of leftovers. portion size is average. but definitely a go-to place if we don't feel adventurous.
author: Sheryl L.

description: We were wandering around chinatown yesterday with some relatives  from L.A. Saw this HongKong Claypot restaurant. Read the review in yelp in got interested. Ordered Chicken with tofu and Beef in claypot amongst the other food (Shrimp with walnut, Peking spareribs, Yang Chow friedrice, sweet and sour chicken), I would give it  5 stars for the saltiness, MSG, and oiliness of the food.  But for real authentic good chinese taste, this place doesnot come close. I would give it a 1 star.
author: Leya P.

description: No way I would have found this without Yelp or a recommend. Great Hot & Sour soup, and I enjoyed the ginger crab and sweet & sour pork. Will definitely be back to try more dishes
author: Steve A.

description: This one is easy.....they have CLAYPOT RICE (Bo Fan)!!!  Nice variety and even offer a variety of sizes.  Everytime I go I never have to wait.  It's on Grant so park in the Chinatown playground lot and you're all set.  Everything else on the menu comes with a healthy portion and the bill is never an eye popper to me.  I don't know why but I ALWAYS have to get an order of Wor Tip (potstickers).  If you love claypot rice and are hunting for a place who still actually serves it (THE RIGHT WAY), then here you go!
author: Stephanie D.

description: Found hair in one of my dishes. All dishes ordered taste mediocre. Won't be coming back. Sauce is too thick, too much starch used.
author: Robert S.

description: Grab the flyer and head upstairs. The authentic dim sum is very hot and fresh and not too greasy or expensive. You order off the checklist menu, which is almost as fun as the carts. Do any Chinatown dim sum places have carts? They should.
author: Brandon R.

description:
very good dim sum for cheap!
its on the second floor so its a little more peaceful despite being in the heart of chinatown.
author: s s.

description:
I went back and forth about whether to give this place 4 or 5 stars. I don't eat Chinese food that often, and when I do, I'm never really that impressed by it. Two of us went here today, and for the first time, I was amazed with Chinese food! The server was apathetic, but based on previous reviews I wasn't expecting much from that department. The food really took my hangover away! 
We had wonton soup, mongolian beef and sweet and sour chicken (all for well under $20). The only reason I knock off a star is because the wonton soup wasn't the best I've had. Although the wontons were good, the broth was a little bland. I've definitely had better. 
We were the only non-Asian people in there, so the place must be authentic - is that what that means?? Don't really know since, again, I don't eat much Chinese food. Authentic or not, my tastebuds approve. I would love to try the clay pots next time. The chow mein also looked really good.
author: Adelle W.

description:
One of few restaurants in the area specialised in authentic Cantonese clay pot.

They serve individually prepared food in individual clay pots, rather than simply filling the clay pot with pre-cooked food.  Therefore, it takes a little long (15 minutes or more) for the food to arrive, but the fragrance when you open the lid is wonderful.

For lunch, I order rice clay pot, which is a substantial meal by itself.  The rice is cooked in the pot itself, resulting in the wonderful crust around the pot.  Some of my favourite toppings are frog legs, salted pork, and a raw egg dropped into the pot after it arrives so that the egg gets cooked just enough...  Yum.
author: Anonymous M.

description: I love their "preserved meat clay pot", ong choy with shrimp paste and salty fish, tofu with chicken clay pot.  Their clay pot dishes are comparable to the ones that you can get from Hong Kong.  Price is cheap too.
author: Jaquelina L.

description: This place serves amazing Chinese food in great portions at very reasonable prices. Average entrees are between $8-12. The space is a bit crowded, but for the quality of food, I'll take it! The food is cheap and delicious and the service is good - couldn't ask for more! I recommend the Honey Walnut Prawns and Kung Pao Chicken.
author: Willy C.

description: So far my favorite Chinese restaurant in Chinatown.though it took me some time to locate it even though I walked past it few times.the reason being it's located in the upstairs between two stores.the price was very reasonable though it's for large groups and not a single person as the tables are big.
author: Yelp F.

description: Stopped by for a quick supper - salted fish/chicken fried rice & tofu/chicken clay pot. Generous portions, good value. Both dishes were tasty. Definitely "hole in the wall" decor though restroom was surprisingly clean (for a Chinatown restroom). Got seated immediately but it took awhile to order. Restaurant wasn't full - Sat evening 7pm. We'll try it again
author: s k.

description: went here for dinner just because of the high ratings on yelp. very disappointed. the food tastes bad and old. won't visit again. also, not sure how come this place could get a high rating by any means.
author: Shane X.

description: Came here for a late lunch on Saturday based on mostly good yelp reviews.  Restaurant was kind of small on the second floor.  Quite a number of steps so it might be hard for older people to walk up and down on it.  It was already past 1:30 but all the smaller tables were still full so we sat in a shared-round table with this single diner.  I'm not a stranger to communal dining so it was no big deal.  I saw one male and one female waiter/waitress.  It took a few minutes for us to get the menu and for them to take our order.  It took even longer to get the food!  We ordered three lunch specials for $4.60 each:  spicy salt/pepper pork chops, beef hot pot, and Chinese broccoli with beef.  The dishes were kind of small but for lunch, it was just the right portion.  The veggie was good but the beef were a little bit tough.  The pork chops were a little fatty but good.  My parents loved the hot pot though.  The beef and tendons were tender and the tofu was great, had a lot of flavor.  Also, this restaurant cooks their rice really well, fluffy and tender.  Good place for a not-so-quick lunch.
author: Annie C.

description: Pot stickers was pretty descent. It would have been a lot better if they fried both sides. The fish clay pot was very good. The hot and sour soup was off the charts. It wasn't "americanized" for tourist. I would have never walked into the place if it wasn't for yelp. Service wasn't the best but the food made up for it.
author: Mickey D.

description: We took out of town guests to Clay Pot for lunch.  The restaurant was a cafe/diner atmosphere up a flight of fairly steep stairs. The restaurant was full of local Chinese patrons eating lunch.  The place was busy, so I would recommend reservation.  The food was authentic and very good.  We had several dishes, and we liked all of them.  One thing unusual, but good, was the fried rice.  It wasn't the sticky rice, so it was harder to eat with chopsticks.  The location was good for Chinatown shopping after.  I will definitely go back.
author: Robin B.

description: Great Cantonese style restaurant. For groups of five or more, order the family style prix fix menu.  To all the non-Asians who were made to feel out of place by the wait staff: we had a party of six with five Chinese, one of whom who spoke Cantonese dialect, our service was probably not better than the adjoining tables where non-Asians were the majority.  Luck of the draw.
author: Tim Y.

description: The food is okay but the service is abominable.  It's the first time I was ever (EVER) asked to move my table in the middle of a meal, basically in the middle of chewing.  From one side of the room to the other.  We thought they might give us a free glass of wine or something to make it easier, but no.  Take your earplugs when you go, too, it's like being at AT&T park.
author: Mizu H.

description: Pretty damn good chinese food, fairly quick, cheap!, and good service.  It's also right in the center of Chinatown and is a great place to people watch if you can get a window seat.  Definitely recommend checking it out.
author: Kevin O.

description:
Apparently, Hong Kong Clay Pot has had a bit of a rough year or so. A fire is enough to close a place down permanently, but losing the cook too!? Not a good sign...

Now, I've just given this place a try within the last 2 weeks, and I have no comparisons with their offerings of Dim Sum in the past, which they apparently no longer serve. But this place has become my defacto lunch standard. I work downtown near Market and 3rd, and even though it's a little bit of a walk, 2 of my work buddies and I brave the elements twice a week to enjoy their fresh, plentiful and inexpensive offerings.

Recommend the seafood stir-fry and the seafood porridge. We'll share our orders, come out of there stuffed and only paying $6-8 a piece including tip. Can't beat that for lunch!
author: Rob R.

description: HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE, HORRIBLE SERVICE! I was so looking forward to eating here after the seeing the reviews. My husband and I made a trip to Chinatown to do a little shopping and stop at the HK Clay Pot to eat. The man at the bottom of the stairs that handed us the menu was very cheery and all seemed well until we got into the restaurant. The waiter was abrupt and rude. He brought the tea that comes with your meal and never brought our waters we requested. I asked him a 2nd time after seeing him pass us several times seating new people, wiping tables and other little things. When I asked a 2nd time he mumbled ok and looked bothered, still after 15 minutes never brought water. I had to get it from another server. He never once came to us after he served us. The other server noticed he wasn't helping us after another customer yelled at him for the same thing and she told him to give us our check. He finally brought us our check almost 25 minutes after we were done eating. I have never experienced such terrible service. I must say the food was good but the service was so terrible it was not worth it. I would never go back there again!
author: Honey B.

description: Visiting San Francisco from New York, and I tried out this restaurant based on the reviews, and I have to say I was very disappointed.  The tofu seafood claypot was bland and a gooey mess and the portion was tiny.  The pork egg noodles was similarly drenched in a goo of corn starch.  They must think my brother and I are ABC's who don't know what good Chinese food tastes like, because they brought us forks immediately without anyone asking!  We didn't get any soup or oranges, probably because we didn't order enough.  Service was also very slow.
author: Yvette C.

description: This will be my "go-to" restaurant in Chinatown. Not touristy at all. Everything was very good, hot and plentiful. Sort of hidden since it's up a flight of stairs. I wish it was closer to my workplace so I could have lunch there!
author: C. F.

description: I came here for dinner and ordered the clay pot, a vegetable dish and a plate of jellyfish.  It's decently priced and you get decent portions.  Otherwise, it's a typical restaurant in that they have paper placemats and waitresses who communicate easier in Mandarin/Catonesse than in English.  It also looks pretty clean.
author: Raz R.

description: I saw this place on a travel channel and I was looking forward to their clay pot dishes.  We ordered Ox tail in clay pot and a lunch special shrimp with tender greens. They were okay. Nothing remarkable. But lunch special was only $4.60 or something like that, so you can't beat the price! I'm not in a hurry to come back here again.
author: Iihae S.

description:
My husband aand I were craving chinese food while staying in the city. We went to this restaurant bacause of all teh yelp reviews but were bitterly disappointed. This place is on the 2nd floor after climbing a flight of steep stairs and is truly a hole in the wall. The room is cramped and crowded with too many tables and chairs and there is hardly any room to walk. The restaurant was busy when we went there but we were seated right away. 
It took 1/2 hour for someone to just come and take our order. We ordered soup (hot and sour) and two main dishes - lamb claypot and honey walnut prawns. 
After waiting 45 mins. for the food my husband asked the waitress and was told that it would be another  1/2 hr atleast before the food came. 
And she was true to her word - an hour later they got the soup which had no flavor and just tasted of salt. Then half hour later came our
entrees - the honey walnut prawns were  ok but I have had much better. The lamb claypot was not cooked fully and the lamb was tough. 
We have always enjoyed good authentic chinese food and this was a big disappointment. Will never go back.
author: P From CA C.

description: A couple of friends took me to this obscure hole in the wall place along Grant Ave.  I haven't been to too many 2nd floor restaurants in Chinatown...I usually don't notice them, but I was game for something new.  My friend said they served great clay pot dishes here.  I think this place must've recently changed names from HK Clay Pot Restaurant to HK Dim Sum House.  I was surprised to be handed a dim sum menu at 9pm...which I'll keep in mind if I'm ever hungry for it at that hour.  They apparently still had clay pot dishes.  Their menu was actually pretty short.  If I could read Chinese, I would have been able to see all types of dishes posted on the wall and not on the regular menu.  The perks to knowing another language...someday.  We ordered up: a clay pot dish with frog legs (yes, they do taste like chicken) and Chinese sausage; scrambled eggs and prawns; lobster with ginger and scallions; beef with bok choy; and an order of Westlake soup.  All for about $60, which included a couple of Tsing Taos.  The food was good, but I guess I'm used to bigger portions.  It's still within reason, considering this is a tourist area now.  I'd eat here again...with a translator in tow.  Beats succumbing to House of Nanking. :P
author: JeFF T.

description: I came here while on vacation with my family. My wife is from taiwan and we always search out vacation spots with a good chinatown. Everything we had here had great flavor and was served immediatly. The seafood claypot had great flavor and I highly recommend it. We even came back a second time during our trip meeting some of my local relatives. The wait staff can be a little slow but the food made up for any issue.
author: Jeff L.

description: Favourite Chinese restaurant! Great food and low price make this restaurant a great one. The fish claypot is a must-try dish. This restaurant comes with a house soup and dessert with every dine-in, so you can ask for them if they are not served.
author: Bak C.

description: Great platters at reasonable prices.  I am often left looking at the bill thinking surely they've made a mistake and missed something.  But no they really are that tasty and inexpensive.  The food always tastes great and the service is prompt, even when they are full with 10+ per table at peak times.  It is worth the drive from Oakland.
author: Christopher H.

description: This place was surprisingly good.  We had the quail as appetizer, steamed oysters with blackbean sauce, snow pea leaves with garlic, crab with salted egg yolk, chicken with green beans, and walnut shrimp.  They also give you some red bean soup for dessert.  The best part...it was affordable.
author: A M.

description: upstairs, low price with quality food. but place is small and very crowded.
author: Freya-Loki O.

description: The seafood claypot and chicken/tofu claypot are great. It was a mistake to order two claypots at one time, because it got a little repetitive. Overall it was a good meal though. Very authentic.
author: kirin r.

description: good and not greasy foods.  generous portions. very affordable.
author: Truc N.

description: this isn't a rating but update.  they have apparently changed hands, no more clay pot rice!
author: Silver C.

description: i always leave there satisfied!  their clay pot is delicious but i heard the chef left.  been there probably about 1000 times.  love their salt and pepper deep fried duck tongues. mMMMmMMmmm!
author: Beck S.
